item.title: Opeth.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4527" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="kenny g"]
[/caption]
'Opeth' Sold Out! at the Wiltern.Los Angeles.
[caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="read it & weep..."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4569" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="'Chicago', Jonny, & Scott in line."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4568" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="chow"][/caption]
Guitar genius-Mikael Akerfelt & landscape genius-Scott Ward
[caption id="attachment_4528" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Sound check"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4529" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="'Blackwater Park'"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4530" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="'Opeth' ruling!"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4531" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="'Ghost Reveries.'"][/caption] Scott Ward turned me on to 'Opeth' sometime in 2008. 'Opeth' are from Stockholm, Sweden & have nine CDs to their credit. People simply have no concept of how great 'Opeth' really are. They are like 'Steely Dan' on steroids & crystal meth. They are a huge storm hammering a vulnerable coast. They are the greatest death metal band to ever grace the world with their presence.Mikael Akerfelt --the genius guitar master of Opeth-- has more musical talent in his toenail clippings, than 90% of the idiotic ear pollution out there. In December, 'Opeth' announced a nine day tour to celebrate their 20 year anniversary. They would be playing six shows starting in Stockholm, then Essen, Paris, London, New York & ending in Los Angeles. They would be playing the masterpiece CD , 'Blackwater Park' in its entirety. 'Opeth' would take a ten minute break, then come back for a list of rare songs from the catalogue. Only 100 VIP tickets would be sold as well. These included a 'meet & greet' with the band, sound check, a special signed DVD/CD & other goodies. Scott thought this too great to pass up & bought us a place in history. Over the last months, we've eagerly anticipated the show. We drove up to LA on Friday afternoon. We packed a lunch & ate on the hood of the Subaru. We met some great people as well. Jonny came down from San Jose area for the show. He made us laugh the entire day. We were sitting in line & a stretch limo pulled up. This guy climbs out with a Subway sandwich & a Pepsi. He asked if this was the VIP line.  I looked at him & answered, "You're the one getting out of a stretch limo dude, not us!" We quickly learned that he was here from 'Chicago', so that became his name. Once inside, we met the band & were able to hang with them, ask about the chosen songs on the set list, the upcoming album they are working on & basically see the Gods of Death Metal in close proximity to us. We were definitely unworthy. 'Opeth' played for 3 hours & my head was spinning afterwards. They were perfect. In a side note, I saw Jazz & sappy saxophonist, 'Kenny G' at the show. I never really cared for his music, but after seeing him at an 'Opeth' show...I still probably won't be listening to his music. However, I don't think him such a 'dickweed' any longer. It was rad & we had a blast. Death Metal rules & 'Opeth' are the kings. Check out 'Blackwater Park'.Thanks to Scott Ward. You made it happen. Peace to Jonny & 'Chicago'. You guys are rad!  Skate-Ozzie http://www.opeth.com/

item.title: Marlon
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4541" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Marlon in 1977-Sick!!!"]
[/caption] [caption id="attachment_4547" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Marlon- BS edger 1977"][/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Marlon- FS deathbox."][/caption]
Vanity tag?
My pool pal, 'Marlon' has been riding the roundwall for many years. He came to Salbaland last year, toting a carload of East -coasters; Andy, Bulldog & 17 Cory Cory. It was epic. When Marlon slams though, the pool feels it. He's currently on the 'DL', but is hoping to get out in the backyards soon. Here is a quick tale of Marlon finding a small piece of skate history. "Back in 2002, I was leaving the 'Old School Skate Jam' at Skatelab. I just finished my last drink and was  saying my goodbyes, when I see one of the worker kids throwing a license plate in the trash. I freak out and grab it. I figured that a drunk 'Badlander' left it. I can't remember if it belonged to Charlie Ransom or Steve Evans. Anyway, after several calls I eventually got it back to rightful owner. A real piece of skate history in my hot little hands, if only for a moment..." Awhile ago, Marlon sent me a few images of his skate collection. I posted it on 'Blue Tile Obsession'. As you can readily see from the image, he has more than a few classics in his house. Great boards & better friends. Marlon has my back & I have his. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: la fin du monde
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4553" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="refuse from a disturbed mind"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4551" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Jay Adams w TA -Fruit Bowl 1977. notice knee pad 'skate nazi' logo."][/caption] 'The end of the world.' In April, 1945, Adolf Hitler cowered in his Berlin bunker, as the Russians pounded the city with rockets & mortars.  The cold springtime sun, was a pale yellow orb, barely visible through the smoke. It mattered little to Adolf. He had been awake for days & was sweating, paranoid & trembling in fear of his end. His Generals, soldiers & staff were jumping ship & abandoning him at every turn. The 'Thousand Year Reich' was lurching to a bloody halt & Germany was burning to cinders around him. He still held out hope that SS General Steiner could turn his Panzers around at the Danube, throw the Russians back & liberate Berlin...rescuing 'Der Fuehrer' to rebuild the shattered city again. Alas- it was not to be. The Russian people had suffered tremendously under the heel of the Nazi black boot. It was time for retribution. As the Russian- Third Shock Army, ravaged, looted, raped & butchered anything that moved, Heinrich Himmler of the SS, had already seen the writing on the wall. Behind Adolf Hitlers back, he made overtures through Count Bernadotte of Sweden, for peace with the allies. When Hitler heard the news through his teletype operator, he broke. Spit sprayed from his mouth as he stammered & swore.  Wildly, he flew into a paroxysm of rage, denouncing his soldiers & staff as "defeatists & traitors". Falling back into his chair--abandoned-- in the dank, moldy bowels of his bunker, Adolf knew that the end had come. His next actions could have come 12 years earlier...if you ask me. He married his mistress, wrote out a 'testament' --for posterity--which was a vehement diatribe against the 'Jews', and then shot himself in the mouth. He did everyone a favor. It was the end of the world, for him & his like-minded goons. Darkness no longer held sway over Europe. Tyranny & hatred has no place in our world. In the 1970s, I saw photographs of Jay Adams with Swastikas on his skateboards & kneepads. I wondered if he was simply being 'punk'. He was asked & said that it had nothing to do with Nazism. It was just to be gnarly...skate punk.  Jay was really radical. I don't think Jay Adams ever really gave things that much thought & I doubt he was a believer in Nazi ideology. Like the image above, when Jay placed a Swastika on his pads, I think that Jay was just being...Jay.  However, I think that the resurgence in National Socialist thinking throughout the world, is a bad idea, in a long sad history of bad ideas. The world is too diverse & convoluted to have that type of mentality governing people. We need a whole bunch of tolerance & we need it now. Remember your history. People don't like to think about such things, but genocidal activity is occurring all over our modern world today! Sixty-five years ago, Hitler killed himself & Nazi  barbarity was uncovered, for the world to learn from. Pay attention or we will be repeating history & that will not be cool.  Skate-Ozzie "When history looks back, I want people to know that the Nazis could not kill millions of people with impunity." Simon Weisenthal

item.title: 'onward into battle'
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4599" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Scott McCraniels. Hollywood, Florida -July 1979"][/caption] I was attempting to upload a recent writing/post that I had completed & the images were too damned large. I couldn't figure out how to make them smaller, spilled my 'Sobe' water on the floor, stubbed my toe while scurrying to grab a towel, then kicked over a stack of books & manuscripts. Hopping around, holding my toes & swearing fitfully amid all this mess, I started laughing. What a complete moron! I phoned my pal Scott, who told me that we could re-size the images tomorrow, cleaned up the mess & sat back down to sip some hot Chai tea. I put a 'Smiths' CD on the stereo & became 'happy' with my depression. Tomorrow will be another day of 'life on lifes terms'. If this is the worst my day can become...I should consider myself lucky. 'Onward into battle.' Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the image. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Dogs
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4605" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Jon Spooner & the only dog I can barely tolerate- 'Smokey'."][/caption] I hate dogs. Reason; they eat their own feces. Anything that takes a crap, then licks its own ass....shouldn't be your best friend! I was waiting outside of a restaurant recently, and this lady is standing there with this absurd- looking little dog in a sweater. It sniffed around this grassy area, squatted & took a dump. I was fairly disgusted, especially when she didn't clean up after the dog. Funny thing is, people stopped & began petting the dog. In a 'sing-song' voice, usually reserved for baby 'humans', she said, "Foofers got the dookers." Everyone looked at her knowingly, nodding their heads & smiling, like they were sharing some intimate secret that only the dog owner should know. I felt contempt & bile rise up in me. So, I go inside, order dinner & drink tea. The same lady is sitting nearby with her stupid fur -ball. The dog is on the floor and--much to my horror--is licking its ass! Dinner, will probably not be eaten now, I am sure. I am disgusted to the 'nth' degree. Gross. I peer over at her again. The dog is on her lap & she feeds it rigatoni off her fork! I paid the bill & departed before my dinner arrived at the table. I left. I hate dogs. They eat their own feces. I am sure that their are good dogs out there & great dog owners that clean up after their pets. I am also sure that their are innocent Nazi SS Concentration Camp guards...Nah! on second thought.....Thanks to MRZ for the image. Skate & clean up after your dogs. -Ozzie

item.title: doug kinkade
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4609" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="doug- rock-n-roll boardslide shallow deathbox"][/caption] Doug Kinkade continues to surprise. I have skated with him over the last year or so, but had heard his name long before. Whenever we ride together, Doug will pull some crazy trick or line with the super -smooth style he is known for. He has a long history of great skating & we seem to know all of the same people. Doug has been finding, draining & riding a huge list of backyards lately. I am on the permanent 'invite list' & thank him here & now! Thanks Doug. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: the hunters
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4634" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="adam12"]
[/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Salba"][/caption]

abandonment
[caption id="attachment_4635" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="bathtub"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4636" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="not so much quality there dude..."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4637" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="bluetile contemplating unrideable blue tile"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4638" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="lance & samwise-contemplating rideable blue tile."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4639" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="i don't think so."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4640" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="ahhhhhh...."][/caption] We hunt. We are 'Der Jaegers'. Its what we do. I was taught by Salba & I try to pass it on to Samwise. He is learning well. During the week, I will be working & receive a text on my cell phone. Its accompanied by an image. Its usually a sick little nugget of backyard joy-- somewhere --that Sam has found. At such moments,  I am very proud. The only way to find pools is to look. One must seek. I love searching for pools. It takes great dedication to do what we do. Backyard pool skating is NOT for everyone. Just because someone can ride the 'Vans Combi pool' well, does not mean that they will be able to shred in a backyard pool. They are completely different animals. Over the years, Salba has proven to me & anyone that skates with him, that he consistently kills backyard pools. He pulls the raddest lines & strings the gnarliest things together. For me, pool skating is the most soulful & OG part of skateboarding. However, one must hunt first. Make it happen for yourself. BTW-If I were to choose an epic list of  backyard pool 'crushers', it would have to start with the following. (in no order)  12, Swope, Dyke, Salba, Farmer, Partain, Tyco, Reul, Pete the Ox, Wrex, G-man, Torshia, Hewitt, Hitz, Bailey, RobSlob, Zask, Toby, & Dansas. That will be a good start.. ...for now. Thanks to Samwise, MRZ & Peter King for the images. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Here today...gone tomorrow.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4657" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Salba"]
[/caption]
adios
[caption id="attachment_4658" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="here today, gone..."][/caption] Saturday morning, I woke up, drank coffee & badgered Samwise until he was up & about. We decided to drive the grid & check on some 'possibles', 'has-beens'  & 'old favorites'. We drove by 'Vanko bowl' & I wasn't really that surprised, when I saw the house. The lawn was green & perfect. Well-manicured flower beds greeted potential buyers. The house was repainted & the entire property gone over. It shined like a brand new quarter. I hopped the side block wall & stealthed inside. It was early. The pool had been repainted blue, and the entire area cleaned up. It was a 'swimmer'. They even removed the diving board & slide as well. I took a few pictures for the files & quickly exited. Samwise & I just tripped over the whole thing. It was such a dump before! Regardless, we took the fun away & left only grind marks. Thanks to MRZ & Samwise for the images. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: 'Pro-tec/Vans'-Combi contest is coming.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4667" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Lance Mountain-full tilt 'Lien air'"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4668" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="'everybody, everybody, everybody....'"][/caption] The greatly anticipated 'Protec/Combi' contest is May 20th & 21st this year. With the newly revitalized & restructured Combi pool, it will prove to be a contest not to be missed! Everyone that I have spoken with, has reported nothing but great things, regarding the new pool & its insane ripping surface. I heard some slight grumbling about the coping, but otherwise nothing but fanfare. Get there & get some. Pretty soon, the heavies will be throwing down & clocking some air time in preparation for the big contest. See you at 'The Block'. Thanks to MRZ for the images. Skate -Ozzie

item.title: Mixx.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4678" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="the night hides a million sordid things."]
[/caption]
Marlon proving that 'night' is right.
I pass by the golden glow of windows, lulled & confining the sad inhabitants to this concrete city. A pagan place of the non-descript, yet all ethnic diversity. Oh, so sad to say, even with the throngs that mass the sidewalks slow, little do they know...hmmm. Glass glitters & chrome loans, reflecting naught in those that trudge & trample, checking their reflections, worried only about the outside. Time worries away the foundations of even the most solid lies. In the end, we send ourselves away, in tears, decay, we cling to the sun that shines, returning to thistles & to vines. Thanks-Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Blood.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4695" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Me-Baldy 46th BD"]
[/caption]
the start before the end
I was working the Oncology/AIDS unit at a local hospital. Time slows & the clock seems to --almost-- move backwards, when you deal with the dying. I had just finished my paperwork & shift reports in the waning hours of a 7pm-7am shift. I was staring out of the 8th floor windows that overlooked the sleeping city. Neon & streetlights seemed to waver & wink. It looked inviting, but I knew that the night held a thousand horrors. I knew that someone was bleeding in an alley somewhere. It was almost 5am & I had to start obtaining blood from my patients,  for the --unending-- tests they invariably suffer through. I don't care who you are, nobody wants to be awakened at 5am for a needle stick! Its unpleasant, but required. I entered a patients room. I could hear him softly breathing & pulled the curtain around his bed quietly, then turned on the small bathroom light. It made waking the patients, a bit nicer & less startling. This man was a 'frequent flyer' on the unit. He had been diagnosed with AIDS  years before, while living in Chicago & his recurring illnesses had brought him into the hospital every few months. His blood levels of AIDS virus were extremely high. He was actively dying & there was little anyone could do except keep him in comfort. This Hispanic man was very thin, spoke little 'English' & was alone during his stays. I never saw visitors. It was as if life had forgotten about him. Yet, I would never forget this man. I woke him & attempted to place an IV in his arm. At the same time, a young resident MD came into the room to see the patient. He stood by the bed, while I worked quietly. As I inserted the catheter needle into his vein, the patient began having a seizure. His body began jerking & the catheter ripped from my fingers, out of his vein & his flailing arms drove the bloody needle, back up & into my thumb! It nearly came out the other side! Horrified, I slammed back against the wall...staring at my thumb & the rivulets of blood running onto the floor. I just couldn't believe it! The resident MD was dealing with the patients seizure & when I locked eyes with him, I could see the look of  'panic' in his eyes. His eyes told me that I was 'doomed'! With the patient stabilized by co-workers, I was rushed down to the ER & a frenzy of activity surrounded me. Luckily, I had wrapped alcohol & 4x4 gauze around the site & applied pressure up my arm. I was in a vacuum for days. I walked around 'already dead'. I just couldn't grasp it. In my minds eye, I saw the skeletal shrunken body of the Hispanic man with my head attached. I was looking myself in the eye...not so good. I barely slept & ate little. When I did manage sleep, I was feverish & woke up shouting... desperate. A specialist placed me on some strong anti-viral medications & the hospital tested my blood-religiously- for years after. Thankfully, I have never contracted the AIDS virus. I guess that I was lucky. You haven't lived until you've almost died. I saw that the man passed away a few weeks later. I went to the chapel at the hospital & had the Chaplain pray for his soul. Truthfully, I don't know how altruistic my intentions were for doing that. Maybe, I thought that I needed all the help I could get. The entire episode forced me to face  a few dark, ugly truths in my life.  Hate & anger. I found myself angry with the man for having the AIDS virus. I hated AIDS  & almost everything else. I found myself despairing of taking care of people ever again. I was forced to look at my own fears & motivations. I realized --exactly-- what is important in life. Inner peace & happiness is 'priceless'. Skateboarding gives me both. I ended up moving into another area of health care. The dying & despair can become far too great a burden for me to handle. I admitted before, I have terrible 'coping skills'. I will never forget that morning or that man. I hope he is in a better place. Somehow, I am. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Dawn patrol.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4700" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Sunday- 6:30am..."][/caption] We could be kings. Who's to say? I awoke & fumbled about...knowing that I needed to get my act together. I drank coffee, ate a  'Powerbar' & drove into the dawn. At my age, I know my window of 'progression' has long-ago closed. I won't be thwarted. Every molecule that makes up my body, tells me that if I want something done...I better do it myself. Its not often that I count on others to find, drain or clean pools. I went to this one that we know of. 'Riverside Sean' found it awhile ago. Its a gem. Grocery carts & refuse were piled about the curb & rolled up carpeting was stacked in the driveway. The entire place stank of urine & festering trash. I checked the house & property for 'threats'. Pity the poor man that decides to target me for anything. It will be his undoing.  I grabbed my gear &  started bucketing. Bucketing is quieter at this time of the morning & its a peaceful way to get my day started. It took about an hour to sweep & bucket this wonderful little 'Blue Haven' left-hand kidney. I saw the sun glimmer over a nearby cactus & the surrounding rooftops...it made me happy. What were you doing at 6:30 am on Sunday morning? Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Lance Mountain on 'OG Combi'
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4704" align="aligncenter" width="449" caption="Salba sadly watching 'Pipeline' Combi pool demise. "][/caption] I decided to post once a week on the OG 'Pipeline' Combi pool & the past 'Vans' version of the 'Combi' pool to lead up to the Vans/Protec contest in May. I thought, why not ask some of the people who were at the OG 'Combi' & the 'Vans' version, to share a memory about them. Lance Mountain is the first to relate this little tale & image. Thanks Lance! Enjoy. "It was Christmas eve 1988, and my ankle had snapped at a local mini ramp. My foot looked like a used 'G.I. Joe' toy. Neil Blender carried me to the car and we drove to the emergency entrance of the hospital. The admitting nurse asked what happened & Jason Jesse piped in “we had a sky- diving accident”. The nurse --not amused-- let me sit in the waiting room for as long as she wished. She was not going to have a bunch of 25 year olds,  make a mockery out of her job... I guess. Yes  --once again-- I believed this to be the last day, that I would be able to stand on a skateboard. I had a broken fibula to be repaired with screws,  two severed  tendons along with another completely torn from the bone. It was going to be a 'full leg' cast for me, for quite awhile. To set the story, we had grown up in the concrete skate parks of southern California. Kids were left to run free and wild behind the doors, through the arcade and pro shops. There was nothing but banks, bowls, pools,  full pipes and time. In the past few years though, our youth was fading.  Park after park had closed down and we moved onto backyard ramps, putting on demos & contests to get by. Soon after though, it changed for the better, with contests in  the big arenas and convention centers.The tide had turned & the money became great for awhile... but then it started to change again. We didn't need parks or  contests to skate, because just outside the door was a whole new world. We had the 'Ollie'. Now, benches, rails, blocks, everything ...was skateable. The 'Pipeline' skate park with the 'Combi' pool, was the last park standing.  To be honest, we were too scared to ride it on a normal basis anymore. It would eat you alive, and-- at best-- you could walk away from a session there, with only a heel bruise lasting a month. The 'Pipeline' opened in 1977, two years later, they tore the freestyle banks out to build the 'Combi' pool. After it was built, I remember seeing it full of water, while the concrete cured, just waiting to be free. The greatest level of skating  went on there, and  it was the gnarliest 'proving ground' of it’s time...or of anytime. I am unsure of the date 'Combi' was destroyed, but I still had my cast on. February 1989? The Pipeline and its 'Combi' pool were being torn down. I could not ride, so I shot photos. I believed that this was the last day concrete would be skated. It took years, but how wrong I was!"-Lance Mountain

item.title: undertow
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4716" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Aaron Astorga"][/caption] Did you ever feel like your baggage is dragging you under the water? There's nowhere to go, when you're drowning in a river...Sometimes, my emotions pour out & fall like toothpicks, to lay in jumbled heaps about me. I can't figure out if I'm coming or going. I think that the older I get, the less I understand. In fact, sometimes, I feel like I am a thousand years old! I was listening to Lisa Gerrard-- 'I am your shadow'--this morning. My soul wept. I wanted to go away forever. I wanted to tunnel beneath the pyramids in Egypt & listen to the ghosts of the long-dead Pharaohs'. I thought about squatting in brooding, Eastern fields of rice, to learn from Mongol dead. I wished to be untouched by problems, friends egos, responsibility, and strife. I wanted to be a kid again...innocent & not so jaded. Alas! it wasn't to be. I drove from the Badlands & went to work. 'Life on lifes terms'. Damn! Thanks to MRZ for the image. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Guest-Jim Howell
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4723" align="aligncenter" width="449" caption="Jimbo-1978"]
[/caption]
Jim & his son 'Clayton'. Baldy pilgrimage -October 2009
Jim Howell "It was sometime in January or February 1977 when I bought my first skateboard magazine. It was the April 1977 edition of Skateboard World, and I bought it at a local drug store called Rae & Derrick. That magazine is still in my extensive collection-- to this day-- and continues to bring me joy and excitement. I had been skating for about a year by the time I bought the magazine, but nothing prepared me for what was to come. When I got my first look at that cover my heart skipped a beat. The cover had skater Ray 'Bones' Rodriquez, doing a tail tap at the Lakewood skatepark, in the infamous, half pipe. He was riding the aluminum, 'Quicksilver' Powell board with white bones wheels. When I first set eyes on that cover, I knew I was onto something special. However, I didn't think it was going to change my life forever, a change for the better... I might add. When I started to turn the pages, my eyes widened and my heart was beating super fast. I gazed upon skaters riding parks, pipes, and yes, those powder blue tiled, backyard pools that southern California is famous for. I couldn't believe my eyes. To say I had 'blue tile obsession', is an understatement. I was hooked! My life changed from that time;  from that day on I was a skateboarder and it's all I wanted to do. To this day, whenever I have a bad day, or if I'm so angry that I want to punch a fucking hole in the face of the world, I take that magazine out, and it calms me instantly. It's like my own re-set button. It reminds me of a more innocent time when all that mattered in the world was my skateboard and skating. I've seen & done my fair share of skateboarding, and in that time, I've noticed that some skaters think they're better or cooler than others. Their egos get in the way of a good time skating and the moment is lost forever. We're all in this together. At times we're all assholes, cool guys, great skaters, and yes, ego- maniacs, but don't ever let it alter a good session. Remember, we are all we have." Skate safe, skate rad, Peace, Jimbo

item.title: Donvale pool- Australia
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4734" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Noel Forsyth"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4735" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Chris Hattan"][/caption] Sometimes, I receive emails & things from other like-minded pool pals out there. I recently received an email & a few images from 'Noel Forsyth' in Melbourne, Australia. I thought that you should check it out. Thanks. -Ozzie "Hi there. Not sure why it took me so long to find it ('Blue Tile Obsession')….great classic and new images, nicely written – a bit of a gold mine really. This pool had it’s own set of difficulties- like 4-5 feet of flat vert on the face wall, and several feet of rotting rubbish to be extracted when we first turned up." "We actually made an attempt to clean it up considerably, even started painting it so it didn’t look so derelict….at which point the demolition team dumped several tons of bricks into the shallow end. So we only got to skate it 3 times, once in the last 5 minutes of light, same thing for maybe 15 minutes the following night." "By the time we arrived to skate it in daylight that weekend, it was like 95 degrees and the newly deposited bricks made getting enough momentum for a solid facewall run pretty tough. Anyway, it was fun for a couple of days…."Next time we came back it was filled in." "Cheers, and thanks again for your excellent site, it makes for really great reading." All the best, Noel Forsyth P.S. "If you’re interested in Aussie skate background, my local skate history site is" www.vicskatehistory.com

item.title: 360 Sportswear/Oasis contest.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4828" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="360/Oasis contest advertisement."]
[/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="432" caption="Oasis San Diego / 805 overpass"][/caption]
Dave Andrecht- Oasis half pipe
[caption id="attachment_4589" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Oasis skatepark. Easter weekend 1978. Pro riders group shot."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4590" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="1st place winner- David Hackett. FS Air."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4591" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Steve Alba- FS Air-4th place overall. Oasis 1978."][/caption] On Easter weekend in 1978, skateboard pros descended on San Diego, for the greatly-anticipated '360 Sportswear/Oasis'  skateboard contest. Under a snarl of overpasses & concrete, in Mission Valley, the Oasis skate park squatted in the shade. Stories were later told of Bert Lamar being forced to stop riding in the middle of his contest run, (Oasis contest 79), as passers-by on the freeway ramp above, threw soda cans into the pool. 360 Sportswear threw more than soda cans at the contest. They ponied up $10,000 in cash & prizes for the contestants. The money was a huge draw for the skateboard pros & it ended as a veritable 'Who's Who', that showed up contest day. Dave Hackett ended in 1st place, Dave Andrecht in 2nd, Doug Saladino in 3rd, & Steve Alba claimed 4th just one point behind Doug 'Pineapple' Saladino. Salba stated that he thought this contest was in 1979. He told me that the contests went as follows. "The Hester I series started in 1978. The first contest was  'Spring Valley', then 'Pipeline', 'Newark' & 'Big O'.  In 1979, it was the '360/Oasis' contest, then Hester II started at 'Del Mar', followed by, 'Winchester', 'Lakewood' & 'Pipeline'. After this, the Gold Cup started." Salba also stated that there was a 'half-pipe', 'bowl' & 'obstacle course ' in the 360/Oasis contest. All riders participated in the three events. Salba remembered, "I did not like that pool (Oasis park pool) too much for lack of real vert. It had funky coping on it...when you rolled in you had to 'Gordon Lightfoot' over the back of the coping which was kinda- flat then rolled up and over the bullnose......it was like a long wait!" "Layne Oaks did 'shove-its' for the 1st time...Pineapple did long rock -n- roll slides.......him and Chris Strople did the longest ones back then." "I don't remember much else. We did stay in  'hotel circle' and wished we could skate the hotel pools." I laughed at Salbas comment. When I lived in San Diego, I would say the same thing to Rhino & Andy Mac. There are some crazy pools in 'hotel circle'! Dave Hackett was definite about the 360/Oasis contest being in 1978, however. He pointed his finger into the air & recounted the events from that day.
"The event was a combination of the Halfpipe and Pool. Andrecht was the points leader going into the finals followed by me, Pineapple and Salba. The day of the finals (April 14th, 1978) Andrecht tired out and made some mistakes." I nodded -fascinated-& thought back to the images I had seen in the magazines. Dave continued, "I kept my runs fast, clean, no falls and ended up winning the overall and the   Cross Country 3- man team (obstacle course relay),  with Dennis Martinez and Steve Schisler."
"I remember trying to create a new move on my initial drop in on the half pipe- which for me was front side- I would drop in and blast an Alley-oop Invert, which at the time no one was doing... but it was a weird twisty- kinda thing which not many people noticed."
"I remember in the end, Andrecht and I tied in overall points for the Pool and Halfpipe- Pineapple in 3rd& Salba 4th, but when the judges looked back at the score cards, I had no falls and because of that... I ended up beating Andrecht at his own park! He came back the next year at the Marina Dogbowl Pro and beat me at my Park!"
The final results of the 1978 Oasis Pro Bowl contest:
1st - Dave Hackett  $1000.
2nd - Dave Andrecht $650.
3rd - Doug Saladino  $450.
4rth - Steve Alba     $150
5th - Dennis Martinez   $50.
6th - Bobby Fraas
7th - John Walker
8th - Brad Bowman
9th - Layne Oaks
10th - Scott Dunlap
One must remember that this contest took place over 30 years ago! Also, these riders have ridden in countless contests over the years & -more than once- I was told that these contests started "blending together" in their heads. Memories & events become confused. Whatever the case may be, David Hackett, Dave Andrecht, Steve Alba & the others killed it & did so, before many of us. I thank them here & now! Thanks.

item.title: Power!
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4800" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="power"]
[/caption]
Me interviewing GEF in NYC--2001
[caption id="attachment_4801" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Glen E. Friedman, Jeff Ho & C.R. Stecyk III"][/caption] I am a collector of 'power' ...but not in the political or tyrannical sense. I really believe that energy flows from & into all things. When there is a heavy session going on, one can sense the energy & tap into it. If someone throws down a gnarly bottom turn & goes up & over the box, the energy expands & pulls you in as well. We feed off each others 'energy'. I interviewed Glen E. Friedman in NYC sometime in 2001. We prowled around the city & ate at some of the best vegetarian restaurants I have ever been to. GEF kept up a running dialogue on music, art & skating. The man is a wealth of awesome knowledge. He has been on the forefront of so many 'culture-defining' moments, that its hard to imagine how he is not a direct descendant of 'Nostradamus'. The group image of GEF, Ho & Stecyk was taken at a 'Dogtown/Z-boys' book signing in Santa Monica. C.R. Stecyk & his early Dogtown stories are what made me want to become a writer. I am in awe around that man. During the filming of the 'Z-boys' documentary, Stacy Peralta, Stecyk, Agi Orsi, TA & I, went out for Sushi after a day of filming at a capsule pool in Simi Valley. They had filmed TA being interviewed in the shallow end stairs of the pool. There was a wooden 'tiki' statue if I recall....During dinner, I sat there with those fine folks & a realization hit me. I took a sip of water & pinched my leg under the white linen tablecloth. I was having dinner with all of the people responsible for making me what I was up to that day! It would be like a martial artist from Pennsylvania, having dinner with Bruce Lee & Check Norris. It was a humbling moment & I will remember that evening forever. Power! We receive it from others. We can receive it from things. Obtain Glen E. Friedmans' books & see the images that burned themselves into our brains ...they gave us power. Skate-Ozzie www.burningflags.com/

item.title: falling apart
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4823" align="aligncenter" width="432" caption="Ellen Berryman-1977. Doing what Iris Chang should've done."][/caption]

[caption id="attachment_4816" align="aligncenter" width="325" caption="Man...I'm glad that I don't have such a capacity for hatred."][/caption] The current times are nuts. I can't understand how people blast through life like they do, yet are completely unaware of the futility of it all. Things could go down the drain 'double-quick'. I was reading a book this weekend called, 'The Rape of Nanking' by- Iris Chang. Its a gnarly history lesson in the brutality of humans over one another. After seeing the Nanking pictures, Iris wrote: "I was suddenly in a panic that this ... reversion in human social evolution would be reduced to a footnote of history ... unless someone forced the world to remember it." Iris Chang forced the world to notice. When the Japanese took the Chinese city of Nanking in December 1937, they reveled in a six week orgy of blood lust & mayhem. The sordid details won't be uttered here, but suffice it to say ... it wasn't pretty. Rape, mutilation & bayonet practice were the norm on the streets. Not so good. Sixty years or so have passed & people seem to forget these sorts of things. They say, "It can't happen again. We are an enlightened world now...more tolerant." I beg to differ. Our ultra-thin crust of civility can quickly be eroded, exposing the barbaric human heart for what it truly is capable of. Fear, religious fervor & race hatred can quickly turn everything ugly. It does so daily. We simply turn our eyes --blindly--away. I heard someone say, "Love is the answer." I don't think for one second that they meant the sweating, grunting limbic-system type, some people accept as 'love.'  I think they meant a love of each other, devoid of anger, yet full of tolerance. I see it at times, but not often. I've seen it in the way my friends forgave my past poor behaviors & follies. I saw it in the hospital, when I worked there. I also saw greed & resentment in the same room, as families squabbled over property & 'things.' It made me sick. For every step we make forward, we slide --further --in the opposite direction. This is what I have experienced. I ponder these things & wonder where we are going as human beings. Futility. Love. Brutality. Tolerance. I was terribly saddened  when I heard about Iris Chang & the fact that she took her own life-- 09 November 2004. Depression ate at her, until the pain made her do the 'unthinkable.' Somehow, I understood. I've  wallowed in self-pity & have looked longingly into the empty void. We all get down & feel overwhelmed. Skateboarding saves me at such times. I wish Iris Chang had skated. It might have  helped. Thank you to Jim Goodrich for the image of Ellen Berryman at Long Beach arena. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: its almost too hard.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4840" align="aligncenter" width="432" caption="Greg Weaver-Oasis 1980."][/caption] Sometimes, its almost too hard. Do you know what I am saying? Sometimes,  I go to skate & cannot ride if my life depends on it! Its like I have a mental disorder & have forgotten the basic function of my body.

item.title: It's almost too hard.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4867" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="aint that the truth!"]
[/caption]
Screech- maintaining my faith in 'broken' humanity.

Screech
Sometimes, life is almost too hard. My  friend Scott, was overwhelmed by the madness of life this past week. He scheduled appointments with clients, only to have them call & reschedule, show up late & be indecisive. They took up all of his time, then asked for the discounted price on materials & huffed when he refused it. People must think that small business owners-- like Scott--are a 'charity'. "We don't need to make any money...what-so-ever! We are here to cater to your self-serving, entitled needs!" Laguna Beach & the surrounding area has more 'concentrated money' than most places in the state. Yet, sometimes you wouldn't know it...not in the way people act. I have a hard time keeping my tongue behind my teeth, when a guy driving a Bentley, wearing  a Rolex & 1500$ Italian leather shoes is asking the landscaper for a 'plant discount'. It makes me want to skin someone with a rusty coat hanger. I'm just saying! This is what we see & experience sometimes.  Scott & I periodically have to go see a 'death metal' show & take out our aggression. Its probably healthier & less risky than--lets say--skinning someone with a coat hanger. Anyway, I am done with my indignation. I am sending  a thank you to Erich Lehman for the artwork & MRZ for the images of Screech just utterly destroying. . Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Lance Mountain...getting radical!
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4879" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Lance & me....Friday morning fun."][/caption] Sometimes you just have to laugh. I went on a pool mission recently with Lance & Samwise. We used Sams' camera because I dropped my camera on its nose a few months back. I was shooting pool pictures-of course! Anyway, Sam uploaded the pictures & then sent me this little gem, complete with his captions. I laughed for an hour! I kept thinking of how gnarly Lance is & his unreal part in the 'Flip' video...it made the captions that much more humorous. Anyway, make sure you laugh & skate. Its a good thing. Thank you to Samwise for the image & the humor. Ruling it! -Ozzie

item.title: jeff tatum
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4596" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="jeff tatum- kona bowl 1977"][/caption] I am currently speaking with Jeff Tatum about his place in skateboarding history. Many people are unaware of the fact that Jeff Tatum was one of the first to pull BS & FS airs, tail taps & other skateboard tricks  in pools. He did all of this during the 1975-1978 heyday. I have seen some insane images of Jeff in 'Kona bowl' & other SD hotspots just killing it! I will be completing a small retrospective of his deeds & posting it soon. Remember, just because someone was pulling tricks somewhere for the 'first time', it doesn't mean it wasn't being done somewhere else as well. More on that later. Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the image. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Going back to Cherry Hill.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4854" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Alan 'Ollie' Gelfand- Cherry Hill 1979."]
[/caption]
me- 1979. nice OP shorts....
Been there...
Cherry Hill. Its name is legend. Anyone that remembers 'Skateboarder' before it became 'Action Now', remembers when Stevie Caballero rode elbow pads as knee pads because he was such a grom & recalls that --arguably--the best wheels came in a cardboard cylinder & were green, blue or red...wanted to ride Cherry Hill Skate Park. Those that rode it were lucky & will certainly brag about its awesome surfaces & the sessions there. I have touted Cherry Hill on several occasions & the times I spent there are some of my greatest skateboarding experiences. Jim Goodrich gave me this photograph recently. Its of Alan 'Ollie' Gelfand in the 3/4 pipe coming into the half pipe. There was a bowled- in end on the 3/4 pipe and the half pipe elbowed in a 90 degree angle at the other end. It was amazing. I learned rock-n-rolls just a few feet away from were Alan Gelfand is riding. As I looked at this photograph, my mind burned. The lights faded & I had a moment of deja vu. It was strange. Jim Goodrich was speaking to me about that day at Cherry Hill, but I didn't quite hear his words. I was somewhere between here & somewhere else. This image defines my youth. I lived for my moments at Cherry Hill. I sat in my class rooms at High School, daydreaming of the right hand kidney & the egg bowl. I passed the 'jocks' in the hall ways & they taunted me, pushing me into the lockers as I skated by. I just hissed at them & skated away. Back then, there hadn't been anyone that skated in my area so I could cruise the halls to classes. I was a pariah in school, but I always had Cherry Hill. That place never let me down. Seeing this image clarifies who I am. I am a skateboarder  & I am proud of it. Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the image. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: VE Day-1945
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4884" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Arizona pipes-1977"]
[/caption]
Nazi Wilhelm Keitel surrenders Germany. 5-08-45
[caption id="attachment_4885" align="aligncenter" width="304" caption="insanity silenced forever."][/caption] VE Day. 08 May 1945. Victory in Europe. I write about history & human savagery quite often. The human condition is immensely fascinating to me. I always wonder why it is that we do the things we do. Sometimes, I think people are simply on 'autopilot' & have no idea exactly what is going on in their lives. People really wander around & care nothing for others. Its strange to me. 'Empathy.' I guess some people never received that 'chip' when the module was installed in their head! Sixty-five years ago, Hitler-- the ego-maniacal ruler of Germany--blew his crown apart & his henchmen surrendered shortly afterward. Their egos were so inflated that they wanted" special accommodations & treatment" after the surrender! I know. I know. That information is difficult to digest. You would think that the Nazi 'elite' would have other things occupying their thoughts....like how do they explain the death camps?! I wonder if the six to ten million victims of the Third Reich harbored such thoughts as they were loaded into trains headed East?! I would think that they had heard enough regarding "special treatment" to try & avoid such things at all cost. Anyway, just a few thoughts to ponder over. The image of the desert pipes seemed fitting in the sheer scope of their size, emptiness & the magnitude of  their use. It reminded me of images of all those cattle cars in Nazi Germany after WW II.... Thank you to Jim Goodrich for the image. Huge respect to the veterans of WW II. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: The universal language.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4913" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Going skating..."][/caption] Over the weekend, Riverside Shawn & I drove to 'Hensleys' in Leucadia for the Brian Fick/Lance Mountain art show. We rode a good backyard kidney enroute, so I was content to sit at 'Hensleys'  & eat fish tacos, taking in the scene. The art work that Lance displayed was stellar. Brian displayed some fantastic images & the backside Smith grind of Peter Hewitt caught my eye...amazing! Shawn & I were sitting there & I remarked to him that if there was a natural catastrophe in that building, skateboarding would never recover. I saw so many great riders under that roof. Alphonso Rawls, Chris Gentry, Dave Hackett, Duane Peters, Andy MacDonald, Cookie- Head Jenkins, Neil Blender, Grant Brittain & a whole slew of other notables. Good lord! We drove back to 'Ridiculous' & talked excitedly about all we witnessed...like two kids. Sunday, a few of us went to Fontana 2 & rode with Salba & Malba. It was a great session. Everyone was tearing it up & yelling for each other! After, I drove back to 'Ridiculous' & Bob Burnquist was there with a crew. Bruno Passos brought a bunch of guys along. Marcello Kosake & Eduardo Braz are from Brasil. They speak very little English & it was rad skating pools with these guys. They were so unbelievably stoked...we were all feeding off their energy & vibe! Salba, Toby, Adam 12, Bad Billy, Michael Serna & Perez, along with a few others, pushed themselves hard. I looked around and realized something. While the rest of the world ravages one another because of their differences, here we were, so many backgrounds, lifestyles, ideologies, faiths & upbringings, yet skateboarding brought us all together like nothing else! We couldn't really converse too well, but pool riding was the universal language & we all understood. Thank you to everyone involved. Thank you Toby Burger for capturing the image. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: dead end
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4919" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="all fled, all done"][/caption] There is something terribly wrong inside of me. I wander through life & continually look at others to see how to act. I don't like what I see & I feel that in order to conform & become 'normal', I will have to become a money-seeking puppet like the others around me. My TV screams that money is the only thing that can make me happy. The church genuflects before a tired God that won't listen or hear. Alcohol & drugs do their best to wrap me in their cotton-like womb...I pay no mind. There is nothing inside. Emptiness. I am a cipher. Nothing. I have no religion, no close family or friends. I have a strong aversion to women & the lies they offer as 'love'. I saw a sign today while driving. It said 'Dead End'. So it is. -Me

item.title: Vans Protec Combi contest.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4934" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Duane Peters- OG Combi / Pipeline- 1980."][/caption] On Saturday May 22, 2010, the greatly anticipated Protec/Vans Combi pool contest will be going on at 'The Block' in Orange. With the newly refashioned pool, you can rest assured that 'the fecal matter will hit the rotating oscillator!' Many of the top vert & pool riders have been at Vans polishing their tricks & developing new lines. See you at the contest! Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the image. Go skate-Ozzie

item.title: Something's wrong.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4939" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Eddie Chang- in trouble..."][/caption] I awaken to --what ends up being-- just another day of madness & mayhem. Sometimes, I am at peace, but then I have interaction with others of my species & 'peace' is quickly eroded away by ego, pain & conflict. There are times when I have little hope for anything. I put things aside, I deceive & delude--even myself--into thinking along lines better left alone. I pass by a TV set in the coffee house. Its just another day of money woes, poverty, disease, dying children & some elitist ego-maniacal star in 'trouble' again! It seems that we keep meeting the same challenges & failing miserably. Somethings always wrong. Is it me? Am I the twisted gear in this spinning cog of misery? If 'Russian Roulette' is the problem, the solution isn't to participate less often...the solution is to get rid of the gun! If the end is coming, let it get here soon. The bible states that, "...in the end there will be wars, rumors of wars, plague, pestilence & disease." Well, we are meeting those requirements today. So, come on! I'm ready for a bit of oblivion...  Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the image. Skate & when the world burns, I  hope I'll see you on the other side. -Ozzie

item.title: sam3
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.excerpt:encoded: Take away the fun. leave only wheel marks.

item.title: hometown letdown
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4950" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Samwise-post injury- skating against medical advice...."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4951" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="uselessness"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4952" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption=""I've seen the light""][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4953" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Take away the fun. leave only wheel marks."][/caption] Sometimes I get reckless and/or hopeful. Blinded by the light, I convince myself something is perfect. Ignoring common sense and red flags, I submerge myself-- deaf to the world-- seeing only what I want to see. If you have nothing, sometimes you settle for anything. It turns out the same everytime. But hey, even the worst pool I’ve ever skated was still fun for-- at least --a few moments. That logic works great when pool skating, but it's best left there for me. At the end of December, while cruising the grid, I noticed a familiar house looking very abandoned. Cars all gone, trash littering the yard, Christmas lights partially dangling from the roof. It had --what looked like-- a great little amoeba out back.  I had even swam in the pool in my adolescence. I dreamt of this day many times. I casually asked some friendlies in the neighborhood if the occupants had moved out, and they informed me that they had, the week before. Now, it seems that I made plenty of bad decisions from this point on. Still, with a few days left in the month it would be safe to say, the occupants still had the month to finish out. The house was built in ’84, so its likely the pool was going to be pretty bad as most post- 1960′s pools are. The water was a little low but fairly clear, and had quite a bit of dirt in the bottom. We don’t drain “swimmers” and this was pretty borderline, but I convinced myself the house was going to remain empty. Like I said, I kept making bad decisions. So, the next day I leave work early to start pumping the pool out. I back the truck in behind the house unnoticed, set up and start draining. My pal-Kevin gets there shortly and starts helping out. The pool was terribly over-chlorinated and the walls were covered with film. We were scrubbing as we go and draining into a vacant backyard next door. Soon a lady comes out of the 'presumed vacant house next door', upset that I am flooding her yard!  I apologize and run the hose out front. At this time, I see the people across the street are uneasy and on the phone, I’m sure they are calling the tenants. The sun is setting and I am contemplating whether I should finish up or call it a day, when the tenants pull up and block me in. They don’t speak English but I manage to explain to them that I’m here for a realtor to winterize the pool. They start going through the house but keep me blocked in, so I keep draining. Shortly after,  I see a flashlight poking around and notice the police have been called out. I tell them the same story, “Alan Gelfand from Keller Williams sent me out.” I explain that the house is in foreclosure and this is what I do. With my lack of paperwork, but the property in obvious disarray, the officer informs me I have to leave. At this point, the sun is almost set and I would have already been  gone if I wasn’t blocked in. So, I pack up and head out. I decided to let it cool down for a few weeks. Well, January 10th I smoked my knee, so I have only been keeping an eye on the pool over the last months. I know of no other serious pool skaters in the area, so I just wait. Recently though, I noticed some kids hanging around the property, and knew what they were up to. One day I went to talk to them as I noticed they were draining it. Already, they had managed to borrow a tiny pump! A small pump is slower than proper bucketing, but easier. They had definitely skipped a 'right of passage' as this was their first backyarder. They should have bucketed! I gave them   the 'run -down' and some tips. They did a pretty good job of cleaning what was a muddy green mess, much better than I did on my first muck pit. The pool ended up being pretty terrible. Three feet of vert most of the way around, the box wall was well over vert, steep incline from the shallow all the way to the deep. The two mid pockets looked pretty good but just sent you flying into a worthless facewall. The wheel marks showed that they had fun with it, so not all is lost. I just keep hoping for a local gem. Skate and undestroy. Kill Mosquitoes. Keep your pools clean. Save lives from drowning. Keep Rolling. Leave only wheel marks. Take only what you brought.- Victorville Sam http://skatethrashbeer.wordpress.com/

item.title: dead lady
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4961" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="biohazard"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4962" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="the sweetest view"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4963" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="a tall order..."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4964" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="...her view since about 1970."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4965" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="...and out the door it all went!"][/caption] As always, I bring you more life, death, detritus &  ongoing woes.There is a small run-down home nearby where I live. I've known about the pool behind it for about 3 years but have never been able to obtain permission from the owner. She was something like 200 years old, deaf, blind & mentally no longer of this earth. I don't blame her. I think of leaving often....anyway, she was quite old & probably shouldn't have been living there alone. When I say alone, I speak of 'human company'. It seems that her home has become a 'cat sanctuary'. She was being kept company by cats. With her eyesight, hearing & health declining, the property had began to deteriorate as well. It honestly looks like it hasn't been cleaned or repaired in over twenty years- by my estimate. A few months back, I was driving past & saw Sheriffs Department cars, Haz-Mat vans & other such emergency equipment pulled up around the dilapidated home. I stopped, feigned interest & found out the gruesome news. It seems that someone had stopped by to deliver something, smelled decay & phoned the authorities. They found that she had been dead for days. The cats had little to eat..... so....you know the rest. I hope that she didn't suffer. It seems a shame that her family never really checked on her. I bet this story is more the 'norm' than the 'exception'. Anyway, her story wouldn't have been told unless I told it...so there we are. The pool is very steep & unrideable. I'm glad of that. It would be a disservice to her. I took these images at twilight because its a melancholy place back there. I wanted to convey that to everyone. I saw rain-soaked filthy piles of mail, dating back to 1958. I saw old mouldering books on Catholicism. I saw giant rusted parakeet cages, brooms, pet toys & clothing from another century. Her life. Fini. R.I.P. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: deadlady4
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.excerpt:encoded: ...and out the door it all went!

item.title: shameless
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4971" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="...and don't you know it?!"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_4972" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Indio gem."][/caption] My best friend in the world is really rad! Over the years, he has kept me high, sane, troubled, sober, truthful & insane….and Jim Howell has talked me off –more than –a few ledges. He tells me the truth! He says, “Play it safe & be a mediocre ‘cool guy’, or be yourself- Ozzie .”   “Make your own way.”  He asked me why I started the pool blog. My answer was simple. The ‘Blue Tile Obsession’ is about a ‘life’ & not just skateboarding. I want to connect﻿ with everyone using realism. I say what I ‘feel’ and  not what I think everyone wants to hear.  I am  using these words for myself as well as you, sharing it because I know it is pure. I am sure that it  can be uncomfortable to read, just as its painful for me to live & write about it. Its like sleeping with razor blades. Sometimes the cuts don’t wake me… but man, do I bleed! My life, my beliefs, skateboarding & how it saves me…Jim Howell helped me see all this-clearly. Make my own way. I will continue.-Ozzie

item.title: Buster
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4981" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="buster"][/caption] Since I won't have time to post this Wednesday, I am doing so tonight. Buster Halterman & Chris Miller. Comparisons between the two are commonplace. Style. Power. Flow. Another level. The Protec / Vans Combi contest is approaching. Buster rode the Combi pool with me a few years back. He would have shamed --more than--a few of the current people riding it. Buster won't be there competing this year...but Chris Miller will. I --for one--cannot wait! Here is one of  Buster at Kelly Bellmars 'clamshell'. I stood on his roof & Buster just hucked a FS corner air....I was like....Good Grief! Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Wes 'Bulldog' Humpston
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: When I lived in San Diego, I made contact with Wes & we started hanging out once in awhile. This was in the late 1990s, before he reintroduced BDS to the world. He was working as a graphic artist at the time. Wes brought his kids over to the Mission Valley Skate Park when I had events there & we all drove up to Gonzales pool together when I had my birthday session there. It was amazing to be sitting there in 'Gonzales' backyard with him & the others....I was tripping. Wes doesn't suffer fools easily. I have seen & heard him slay people for various infractions at one time or another. You don't want to be on the losing side of Wes & his wrath! His artwork is iconic. He has made legendary boards. I have already started working on a Wes Humpston interview post & will be getting together with him in the future for a Q & A. Thanks Wes for all you've done. Thanks to Rudy Manheim for the images. Skate & remember your history.-Ozzie

item.title: Eye of the tiger.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_4990" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Darrell Miller- looking the judges in the eye....."][/caption] Sometimes during a contest, I will see certain people who seem to have tapped into some crazy reservoir of 'power'. I will witness skaters pushing everything to the very edge, sliding further, going higher than they can handle, yet staying on. I see riders over-amping & beyond stoked, feeding off the crowd. I see people sketch, bonk their wheels & still commit. Its not even a matter of commitment actually, because the thought of 'bailing'...never occured to them! I've seen Jake Piaseki skate like this at a 'Basic Bowl' contest. He rode like it was his last few minutes on the earth! I mean, Jake seriously 'destroyed' for like 20 walls! Just killing himself.....'eye of the tiger'. Actually, if I recall, they took Jake away in an ambulance that day! I've seen it all. However, in all that time, I've rarely seen a skater stare right at the judges like Darrell Miller did at Del Mar in  July 1979. I mean, he's looking at Don Hoffman, Curt Kimbel, Ray Allen & D. David Morin....straight in the eye, just 'daring' them ....not to give him first place! This photograph is insane....Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the information & the image. Thanks to Darrell Miller for reminding all of us what its like to be in 'the zone'. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Doing what most will not.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
First of all, I know I'm going to hear 'flack' over this one, but it's tough to get skateboarders to work...at --virtually--any endeavor. Unless it involves smoking weed, drinking or chasing skirts....skaters are --generally speaking--pretty unreliable in the 'tasking department'. Back East, we had to create our own scenes. We had to build things to ride. We had to fight weather & the old-fashioned ideals of the local people in order to skate. Its that way in many areas of the country. Here in California, people don't get out of bed early in the morning to do 'squat'! Unless there's money, a trophy or an 'ego boost' involved...it aint being done. Finding, draining & cleaning pools!? Forget it! Now, before you get 'butt hurt', I know that there are exceptions, mind you. I know of small crews that build spots, hunt & drain pools as well...but these guys are the exception to the norm. To those that do the 'work', my hat goes off to you. Samwise & I hit the grid pretty frequently. We are going out Saturday morning and are systematic & thorough. We know what to do, what to look for & we have a 'ready story', if cornered by irate homeowners or nosey neighbors. Salba taught me well. I taught Samwise. We do what others will not. We do the impossible. We consider ourselves fortunate. While many sit at home, resting on lies & excuses, we create our own world & destiny. Skate-Ozzie
"Its kind- of fun to do the impossible." -Walt Disney

item.title: Michael Serna Jr.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5013" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Michael & 'Smokey' at 'Ridiculous'"]
[/caption]
Michael- crushing a frontside air- 'Bellmars'
[caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Michael- Baldy pipe/ A Badlands tradition."][/caption]
Michael at 'Joes pool'
[caption id="attachment_5018" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Upland, Badlands, Serna Skate Clan."][/caption] Michael Serna Jr. I met Michael through Salba & the other Badlanders that I skate with. He was always quiet & unassuming around me...he didn't say much. Then I saw him ride a skateboard &  realized that Michael doesn't have to say much. His skating does the talking for him! Power, style & Mach-5 speed is what he delivers! He is the son of legendary Upland 'Pipeline' local, Big Mike Serna. Young Mike was taken to many of the spots in & around the Badlands. He rode an old park in Claremont & started riding the Ontario 'Vans' park, after it opened only minutes from his home. Once 'Fontana' opened & he grew older, Michael started traveling around the area & riding as many places as he could. He flows effortlessly & easily handles the Combi pool, Bellmars, the full pipe at Upland or any backyard he can find; Michael always finds a way to tap into the speed & power that awaits us all. Thanks to his Mom,  Pop & the Serna Skate Clan for helping him be who he is. Thanks to ALX, Peter King, MRZ & Brandon Wong for the images. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Oko's last Hoorah!
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5047" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Trennie-ripping like no other '11 year old' in the world."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5046" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Art Miranda- rock-n-roll."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5045" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Kevin Burke- taking a break from photography to crush the deathbox."][/caption] In the 'Badlands', we treat our pool pals right. When Brian 'Oko' Daytz decided to marry his sweetheart of 7 years--Narcissa--his pals planned a skateboarding bachelor party immediately. 'Oko' --being half-Japanese--received his nickname from his mother...she called him a slightly- long Japanese nickname & his friends picked up on it.They shortened it to 'Oko' & the moniker stuck. He told me that he went to Japan in the 7th grade & received some money from his relatives. On his return to the 'Badlands', he bought two things. A Vision 'Gator' model...and a membership to the Upland 'Pipeline' skate park. He rode at the 'Pipeline' & with friends all around his hometown of 'Chino'. His pals Aaron & Mike would all travel together & skate mini & vert ramps as well. He counts Lance Mountain & Christian Hosoi as  skaters that he 'looked up to.' His friends planned a good one for today!. They started in San Diego & rode 'Washington St.' then 'Carmel Valley'  and a few stops in between. They ended the day at 'Ridiculous'. ' Ontario Eddie' came by with his delicious Tacos  & other pals supplied drinks & 'man-beverages' for the thirsty skaters. 'Oko' told me that he really "....couldn't believe the party." "It is amazing that from skateboarding we all have met & we can come together like this. I've made such great friends." Congratulations to 'Oko' & Narcissa on their upcoming wedding which occurs June 5th. Fortune & health to them both. Thanks to EVERYONE that made it happen. The 'Badlands' crew rules! Thank you to Kevin Burke for the images. Skate & love your friends. -Ozzie

item.title: 'Paradise Lost'
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5069" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="paradise lost? or found.....?"][/caption] It was growing dark outside. I had finished cleaning the truck out. I removed the pool pumps, hoses, cords, buckets, brooms, shovels & all the rest of it, into the garage. My knee pads stank so I threw them in the washer with some bleach. We had a long weekend. Samwise & I had hit the grid pretty hard on Saturday. We found some, drained several & helped host a party at 'Ridiculous'. Sunday was a backyard 'bonanza' of fun. The Powell guys came through & we rolled all day. I sat down in my dark armchair & started reading Milton's  'Paradise Lost'.  Slowdive 'Souvlaki' droned in the background & the noises outside my glass windows disappeared quickly. Milton wrote, "...his doom reserved for him, more wrath; for now the thought both of lost happiness and lasting pain, torments him..." I thought back over my sordid past & my self-wrought calamity...in wonder. To think that I held the keys to my own bondage. They were in my pocket the entire time! I had looked & pointed everywhere, trying to place blame for what occurred to me & how my cards were dealt. But, it was always me. I was my problem. It wasn't 'Paradise Lost' at all. What I've 'found' is far greater than anything I've ever lost. Happiness & a new way of living. Skateboarding saved me. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Juanisha's Pool.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5074" align="aligncenter" width="449" caption="Juanisha & the crew."]
[/caption]
KB,Kari Monea & Shane at Juanisha's
Badlands Chris- first to grind!
[caption id="attachment_5088" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Upland Dan- FS deathbox"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5089" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Kevin Burke- teflon"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5090" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Shane Borland- FS 5-0"][/caption]
Me- BS deathbox
The people at Powell have been good to me. They have supported my deal since I was 'Director' at Woodward, Mission Valley & lately with the 'Blue Tile Obsession'. Michael Furukawa, Jim Tesnar, Rob Washburn, & Deville Nunes have my back & I am glad. Deville, phoned me last week & said that he wanted to come out & ride backyards. He wanted to bring 10 year-old wunderkind-Shane  & new Powell Pro-Chad Bartie. They needed some backyard round wall & if Powell asks something of me, I will drop what I am doing & deliver! I thought it over & called in my sidekick, Samwise. We drove the grid Saturday & eventually located a few new holes to drain & ride. It was hot as only the 'Badlands' can become, but we toiled on. We stopped over at Juanisha's  & knocked. The story is, Salba found her pool from an airplane back in like 2004. He gained her permission, drained  & sessioned it. Juanisha's lasted a few sessions & then it was lost to us. Juanisha answered the door & remembered me. She is a really cool lady because--actually-- I wouldn't want me in MY backyard! . Who knows what I'll do! Anyway, she asked if I could hook her daughter up with some bearings & stuff for her skateboard. "No problem." I made arrangements with Juanisha & drove over at the designated time Sunday morning. She already had her little pool pump in there...working! Nice! I put her daughters board together, made her so happy, & cleaned out the rest of the muck. I did a final rinse with Juanisha helping, tidied up the yard & told her we'd be back after noon. I returned to 'Ridiculous', gathered my stuff & when Deville (without Chad Bartie ), Shane,  Jim, Brandon Wong & Kevin Burke arrived, we hit it hard. Michael Serna, Badlands Chris & Upland Dan joined us as well. We had a pool destruction team of epic proportions! We crushed a few local holes & a couple of things went down--including Michael--who took a pile driver onto his wrist! OUCH! He sat down & then Shane blasted a sick 'Lein air' over some side stairs....worthy! We ended up over at Juanisha's pool. We said our 'Hellos', introductions were dished out & the afternoon quickly became hotter. Badlander Chris stepped into the pool, grinded first & smiled at everyone... it was 'on'. Shane & 'the always' Teflon-smooth-- Kevin Burke threw down FS 5-0 grinds. Both pulled them effortlessly. Brandon Wong put the camera down in order to pull BS double-axle grinds that virtually inverted him. Upland Dan cut through the deathbox FS & Michael nursed an increasingly swollen wrist...with the assistance of 'man-beverages'. We shot a few pictures, laughed, cheered each other on & had a great time. Juanisha was stoked, as were we! Thank you to Juanisha, her children -Kari Monea, K'ne Morrison,  and friends-Quan Menifee & Raymond Holley and all the 'Badlands' crew. You made it unreal! Thanks to Jim Borland, Brandon Wong & Deville Nunes for the images. Skate-Ozzie
