item.title: Steve Alba-'Combi' comparison.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5110" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Steve Alba-OG Combi"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5111" align="aligncenter" width="327" caption="Salba-invert at 'Pipeline'"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5112" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Salba- Indy air"][/caption]
First of all,  let's get something straight.
Stan and Jean Hoffman rule! Without them none of this 'Combi pool' business would even get talked about, much less skated.Their original idea to build the 'Pipeline' skate park was monumental to the skateboard world. It was the first vertical skate park with a twenty foot full pipe, a fifteen foot bowl and the first  twelve foot bowl-- to be built --was attached to the pipe. However, there was no pool coping.
So the 'Combi' was born........out of the ashes and into the 'Badlands'.......where skating is just as strong today, as when it first started over thirty years ago in 1977.
So, Ozzie keeps bugging me about an Upland 'Combi' story......old versus the new 'Combi'........well it goes something like this....
Is the new rebuild worth the effort?
Will people be pleased with the new results?
Will I get paid for the consulting work that I did,  along with Lance and Grosso?  No.
But, it was 'hella- rad' to be there and involved on behalf of 'Vans' and 'California skateparks'. I love the process of ripping out the old and replacing it with the new. My only real bitch is the coping,  which has  no true 'reveal'. The coping sits 1.6 to 2 inches lower than most brands and does not grind like real pool coping. So, you blow out real easy because  it does not hold you in.
Lance said that the coping molds cost 700 bucks each and there is over 30 of them for all the different  radius'. I want to do the coping over and build new molds, but it is not cost -effective.  What do we do?
That opens another can of worms after we opened 'Pandora's box' by redoing the 'Combi'.
It needed something ...right?
I've always hated the slickness of the newer one compared to the old one which was mostly too 'grippy'. I always had scrapes from knee- sliding and stopping on the rough- textured bottom of the  Pipeline 'Combi'.
Ten years full of pain... sticking to the sheets ...I do not miss the pain from the old 'Combi'.
As for the current 'Combi' itself,  it does not feel like the pools of old. Meaning, the Pipeline 'Combi' or the 'Vans' remake at the Block in 1998.
The pool itself feels great now, even though I hated it at first...sort-of like Ben Shroeder does now.......
The deal is, you can not think of the old one. Get it out of your head and move on with the future.
'Duty now for the future'!
Lance was right when he told me to think outside of the box. Meaning, he did not ride the old 'Vans Combi' the last three weeks like we did. When I rode the new rebuild for the first time, it was exhilarating--- fast and scary-- because it was new. But, I kept 'blowing out' from too much speed and riding too heavy footed.
It really threw me for a loop.
I cursed it and went home, mad at myself for being a 'pussy'. Plus, I always hate riding new concrete, due to the 'break -in' factor......it is so sticky it hurts to bail. You get stuck when you knee-slide or rock your insides from hitting the concrete so hard.
Now, I really like it. I have figured out that I have to ride it 'light- footed' ala 'Gordon Lightfoot' to have any success at all.
I do like the coping now, but still feel it does not stick out enough.
'Bucky' thinks it sticks out too much.......?!
We all had to deal with the big coping before and it is ten times better than it was, yet people are crying about the coping sticking out too much?
It is  a POOL guys!
Pools are supposed to be gnarly right?
Well, the 'Combi' has definitely lost it's 'Gnar' factor.....with no lumps or bumps to overcome and slippery plaster pool surface........what little advantage I had from skating 'backyards' all the time is gone, over, 'finite'.
Every "Tom, Dick and Harry" can skate the 'Combi' now and rip, because there is no 'Gnar' factor. This is good and bad.
It's good because it brings skating back to the 'Block'...but bad because dudes who do not even ride 'backyards' can skate well & get their 'pool points'.
For me, it is weird because most of the time I ride 'backyards' which sometimes only allows you to do a FS grind. It might take twenty tries or a two hour 'nightmare drama' just to get a grind over the light! What I am getting at, is most of the competitors that will ride the 'Combi' this upcoming weekend do not dwell in shitty neighborhoods looking for the thrill of a lifetime. Most just skate the perfect pools with their perfect coping and perfect surface and all they do is practice ,practice ,practice at their craft.  I have to get myself in gear every year just to get to the level of all my friends who don't do what i do.........so i am always playing 'catch up' in the trick department.
I need to step it up to the next level. Get motivated and stoked.
It will be exciting.......and the newest version of the 'Combi' redux is still one of the biggest things to ride on the west coast (unless you are a 'buck -yeah' local!  [Buckys]). The 'Combi will still 'take you out' if you are not careful!
Did you see pictures of Grosso's butt cheek?
The 'Combi'  still deserves respect and lines that were not possible before are now a 'go' ...big time! I have only ridden the new one about 12- 13 times, but every time I go, I  figure something new out; a trick here or a carve -line there ...it is endless.
It is also really fun.
I feel like a kid going to a new skate park when I was a young.
My palms get all sweaty and I have a big smile on my face...'hootin and hollerin'.
Christian just laughs at me, but it is all good.
It feels more like the OG Upland 'Combi' because the cement color is gray like the old one and the new lines remind me of old times. I  have a couple of my '20 yr old' lines back. Backside airs feel good in the round again and carving over the hip into the round to the BS air line is really fun again! It's funny because  in the Upland 'Combi',  everybody rode the round more because it was easier and better than the square. But in the 'Vans Combi',  everybody rode the square more because the round kinda sucked. It was bumpier than the square; the round served more for a couple of speed hits and back to the square.
Now, it is reversed again.
The round is super sick and maybe better than the square. Though I still always prefer square pools, as long as they have corners to carve. Maybe it's because I learned to pump at the 'L-pool', a squarish- type plunge pool that housed the old Upland swim club.
As for me, I'm just an old guy trying to keep up with the younger guys.
I turned 47 in February. I have been entering contests since i was 15...
longer than anybody out there now , except Tony Alva.
'Hester series' bitches.
All you guys make fun of me with my push-ups and stretching.......but I am still going strong.
Will you even skate when you are 47?
I will have the last laugh.
Fullpads?
Who cares?
I've been training for months on my wifes bike, pedaling uphill from my house in Alta Loma to the Baldy pipe and beyond, into the hills, on fireroads and such. I am running and jogging ten miles a week just so I can skate with guys like Christian,Cab, Lance, Chris Miller, Grosso, Pat Ngoho and Lester...guys I never had to ride against in the old days,  and guys who were ten times better than me in talent.
They may have more tricks, but I have more lines and endurance. I can still grab 'tuck-knee',  unlike some of the other guys who can't because they are getting fat!
'Stinkbug' FS airs just suck!
Style is at a premium......if you do a FS air, do you emulate a TA tuck- knee or  a George Orton 'stinkbug'?  I know the right answer!
Do you?
So, for me,  just to be mentioned in the same breath as these guys is an honor and to get to skate with them  all is like a high school reunion.
After all these years of skating in the 'Combi' and seeing four different  versions (if you count 'Bowling Greens' 3/4 Combi -Wally Hollyday remake ), I still like the Upland 'Combi' the best. However,  the new version is 'hella- fun' and I keep thinking that if I only had another month or so to dial in a couple of more things... I gotta do  the math ........put up more stickers for markers and dream up more lines . This year is gonna be 'off the hook'........see you Saturday!
You better watch out!
I hope some of the Hoffmans show up.
I love you Stan.......
S.A.

item.title: Chuck Hults- 'Offerings'
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5122" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Chuck Hults- Combi 'Taperkick' carve"]
[/caption]
Kelly Bellmar with his 'offering' to the 'Skate Gods'
[caption id="attachment_5123" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Kelly Bellmar- rock-n-roll slide- Combi"][/caption] I find it interesting how highly regarded the new Combi Pool is these days. Because when the original Pool was destroyed not that many people came to say goodbye. After the Upland Pipeline Skatepark closed for business, it was a good 3 months before it was put to the blade. During this time a small group of us die hards took advantage of Stan Hoffman's generosity in letting us skate the park for free anytime we wanted right up till the last inch of it was rendered un-skateable. We invited many other skaters to come get their last grinds in, yet most wanted no part of the beast. The ones who did show up took a parade lap session and never came back. But our crew was different.... we skated ourselves into physical wrecks. Healing was not an option, there wasn't time for that, it was now or never. We skated right up to the very last second. There was no way that the greatest skatepark in history was going to be destroyed without every square inch of concrete getting the reverence it deserved. After all it was the ultimate proving ground.... it was Upland ...... it was more akin to Stonehenge than a skatepark in our eyes. After the park had been laid to waste, I had the machine operator smash my deck to bits with the bucket as a sacrifice to the skate gods. Kelly Bellmar followed suit and it was over, there was no more skateparks. We felt empty, like our time was over forever....... we were thankfully wrong, the Combi Pool is still the ultimate proving ground. I like to think the Kelly and myself's small sacrificial offering, and the passion of the last session crew helped keep the flame alive in the dark times. You better take advantage while you can, there's no telling when the next offerings will be necessary. --Truck Bolts Thank you to Chuck Hults, Mike Ballard & Ortiz for the images.

item.title: Contest day.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5132" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Bring it....!"]
[/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Lance - 'Terror at Tahoe' 1985"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5137" align="aligncenter" width="447" caption="Mike McGill signing autographs at VA Beach 1985"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5138" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="'Terror at Tahoe- contest sticker toss-1985"][/caption]
Gray, Blender & Ruff- Team Hotel Room
[caption id="attachment_5133" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Micke Alba- bed -bounce frontal...."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5134" align="aligncenter" width="449" caption="Jay Shuirman R.I.P. & Steve Olson- 'Heavies'"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5130" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Del Mar 'Stubbies' August 1985"][/caption] Contest day. Wow! The entire atmosphere of great expectation & fun is overwhelming on contest day. Where would we be without the following things during a contest weekend.  Crowds surrounding the pool. Pro riders going huge and staying on. Hotel room shenanigans with other team riders. Sitting around in the heat with company owners & riders. Autograph signings. The inevitable 'sticker toss' and of course, the contest itself. Stay posted & CD will be bringing you some great stuff on this years Protec/Vans Combi contest. Thank you to Jim Goodrich & MRZ for the images. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Protec Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5144" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Jake Phelps & Salba 9am"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5147" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Hosoi, Grosso & Lance- plotting victory"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5148" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Christy Van Doren & the 'fatty' payday "][/caption] Insanity. I need to take my brain out & run it under cold tap water! My mind hurts & my eyes ache. What I saw today, would've burned the blood of Kings. Masters- 1. Caballero 2. Miller 3. Lance Pros- 1. Bucky 2. Rune 3. Omar More on Blue Tile Obsession & CD later. I'm tired. I got to the pool at 715am & swept & mopped it. I am tired & brain dead. skate- Ozzie

item.title: christy van doren w Buckys money
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz

item.title: Working
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5151" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Steve Caballero- wanted it."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5152" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Chris Miller- not quite enough."][/caption] Yesterday was craziness. I am writing all day & am terribly vexed. Ask who won a contest & its all a matter of perception. I don't want to start any drama. Who am I?  Yet, where was Aaron Astorga? No invite? Hmmm. Pat Ngoho NOT making the cut yet Hosoi did? Where were the judges looking during the runs? Ben Rayourn destroyed the pool & himself, Duane crushed, Nash rode the Combi like he was 'on fire' trying to put himself out & there was more madness under that roof than I care to ponder over this early in the day. Miller rides better than most. He couldn't quite put it together. Caballero did. More on all that later. Perception. Thanks to MRZ for the images. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Bucky
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5169" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Bucky Lasek- at the defunct 'Spinning Wheels' park. Reading, PA 1990"][/caption] Bucky Lasek. He won the Protec/ Vans  'Combi' contest this year. I rode this pool at 'Spinning Wheels' when the park was open in 1979. The pool was the worst! We called it the 'kink sink'. It was. I never saw anyone do anything like what Bucky is doing in it. It was remarkable to be able to grind & that was it. Fini. I saw Bucky step up at 'Combi' this year. He was inconsistent during the start of the contest but threw it down when it was important. He is like that. I remember him at an Ocean City, Maryland contest --circa 1987--he was a grom and ruled there as well. He wasn't sticking all his tricks & then when the finals came, he stepped it up! That is Bucky. A ruler! I am happy that Bucky Lasek is a skateboarder & am glad that I've been able to witness him ride since 1986 when he was a young ripper at the Chesapeake 'Hell Ramp' . Thanks to Geoff Graham for the image. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Ousted
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5179" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Salba"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5180" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Josh Rodriquez"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5181" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Bucky in 'destructo mode'"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5182" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Stevie Caballero- putting it all together"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5183" align="aligncenter" width="449" caption="Duane...being Duane. He ripped so hard!"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5184" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Lance Mountain- destroyed!"][/caption] Sitting on the deck, the smells of concrete, plywood & ammonia from the 'port-o-johns' reaches me. It's all a part of the deal, I suppose. I prefer concrete & plywood but with pool skating comes beer & with beer comes urinals, so there we are. I sit on the lip of the Combi pool & look around me. There are few people here. Its 7:40am. I hear the distant echoes of people laughing, dragging chairs & the clank of metal. I hear a 'Skil' saw roar as it cuts something, then cease. Silence falls again over the Combi. Colorful sponsorship banners flutter softly in the cool morning air. Its cloudy, the sky like a lead blanket. A couple of guys walk around the black aluminum bleachers and saunter past. They nod, I nod, then they move on, pointing at the pool and muttering among themselves. I find it hard to believe that this 'tomb-like' atmosphere which hangs over the 'Combi' will soon be charged with the power of an electrical current. In a few hours, the greatest exponents of round- wall skating will come together in this place & take all they can from the 'Combi' & each other. It makes me happy to know that this building will be filled with people---friends & pool-aficionados--cheering their favorites. Chris Miller? Salba? Lance? Rune? Bucky? Nash? Cab? Hosoi? Then there are the new bloods- Munroe, Borden, Perelson & Barros? Who would it be?  A media crew of eight, walks over by the square pool and starts talking 'angles' & tech talk. I watch & smile. It's going to be rad! I am sitting on the coping of the round & the pool is cold under my legs. There are moisture lines around the bottom & a balled-up towel is left there to soak up some of it. I was told that they 'pressure washed' the pool last evening. A squeegee lies abandoned in the shallow end. I notice blue & purple paint smears on the well-ground coping. Was it from Grosso, Caballero or Shroeder? In my mind, I can almost hear the pool speak to me. "Come." Overhead, the 'Protec' winners banners sway slowly. Their red, white & black letters detailing the results of contests past. C. Miller, M. Knoop, R. Glifberg, C. Burnside. Masterful skating in times gone by. Salba & Jake Phelps show up. Salba sets up his amp & guitar. Jake & Salba start an echoing rock jam & the arriving staff are treated to a live show. Its 9:00am. After everything was ready, the practices started, Zach Miller, Salba , Steadham, Sergie, Matt Boyster, Ken Fillion, Lincoln & Chris Miller rode together. All were feeling out the pool and watching each others lines. Those 'battle lines' were drawn. Chris Miller watched all those riders & they were watching him. Eyes on the prize. Salba went everywhere & stayed on the gas, Steadham steadily stayed the 'Steadham' line, Miller drifted far & threw in a few new things. BS 50-50 through the corner to BS lip. Nice! Ngoho & Pennington showed up to add their flair to the practice. Pat Ngoho rips. I love to watch him ride. I reluctantly pulled myself from the deck of the 'practice' session & went to talk to Christie Van Doren & Mario Bonaventure. They run the entire affair. I asked about the changes to the format. Christie stated that,  "We got together & really wanted 'exclusivity' for this contest. New pool, new contest, new format. We wanted the 'best of the best'." I asked about the women riders. Mario answered, "There will be a three stop tour & a final this fall for the women. It will help elevate the female division & those involved." In my mind, they were doing a great job. It all seemed pretty organized to me. The womens contests will be worth watching! I noticed a few riders -conspicuously- by their absence.  Aaron Astorga? He won the 'Boarder Cross' & crushes the 'Combi' with a style & power that few others can deliver. I'll say it. Aaron should have been there. Tony Alva arrived. He was judging the event. We talked a bit. Even though we talk often & are friends, I didn't ask who --if anyone--he was thinking might take the top spots. He was judging with others. Let them judge. Bucky, Perelson & others were practicing & I watched Steve Caballero take some runs. He seemed 'out of sorts' & not the Cab of other times. Perelson boosted a FS tailgrab over my head & I heard someone say, "He's good when he wants to be." I must concur. As the contest got underway, I watched everyone closely & took notes. I wrote a 'blow-by-blow' of what occurred. Looking at those notes now, I find that it doesn't really give the contest or the riders justice. As in all contests, its a matter of 'perception.' Ben Raybourn killed it padless. Duane tore like only Duane can. He deserved his placing. Nash road like a vert god. Miller didn't put it all together. Caballero was not quite looking like the Caballero we know of. Miller sketched & bailed then Stevie went. He hit the switch & stayed glued to his board. It was awesome to see. Lance skated insanely & rode every inch of the Combi. When he was helping with the refurbishing...he paid attention. It showed! Pedro Barros was unbelievable. Power, style & technicality. He is a force to be reckoned with. Nolan Munroe left me speechless at times. This guy is a phenomenon & put together some power lines & trick combinations. Josh Borden --one of my favorites--tried to hold it together but consistency kept him from higher placement. What style though! Omar Hassan & Josh Rodriquez rode flawlessly at times. I saw Josh clip his wheels so hard, he almost took a 'cement nap' When he came back up the wall, he was laughing. Epic! One more thing of note--Lincoln Ueda was riding & I looked over and saw him pull a good 'ten foot' air . The crowd went bonkers but not nearly like they did for Jeff Grosso. Grosso pulled a BS 50-50 to fakie in the round  that made my heart stop. He had to be going Mach-5! He then rubbed his belly for luck & made a 540 attempt. People were tripping! Grosso rules. All-in-all, this contest left me drained & the skating that I saw is burned into my brain forever. Its hard to say that Chris Miller was 'ousted'. One of his completed runs in the 'Combi' was still better than most anything I saw all day. He's Chris Miller!  All that aside, Cab stepped up & skated insanely. Congratulations to everyone that rode. Thanks to MRZ for the photographs. The images can speak for themselves. Thanks to Ray Zimmerman & Christian Cooper for everything. I cannot wait to see what next years 'Protec Combi' contest will bring. Will Miller answer up? Will Bucky destroy again? Is Pedro, Borden, Munroe & Perelson the future of Combi destruction? Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Pressure
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5189" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Curt Lindgren- Cal Jam2 1978"][/caption] During the recent Vans/Protec contest, I saw Jeff Grosso walking by me on the deck. He looked a bit...preoccupied & anxious. I asked him , "Do you still get nervous before a contest Grosso?" He stopped dead in his tracks for a tiny second, then walked past. He answered, "Fuck yeah! Why do you think I'm pacing! I'm freaking bro..." I can't imagine exactly what was going through Curt Lindgrens dome when he was riding this plastic behemoth, looked over & saw approximately 600,000  eyes on him....! Even as Ted Nugent played 'Wang Dang Sweet Poontang', I think I would've been more than a little distracted to skate. What balls these guys had! I probably would've vomited on my Vans. Anyway, when Grosso said that to me the other day, I thought of this photograph. There we are. Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the image & Ted Nugent for the 'Wango Tango' & Curt Lindgrens dad, for giving him a big nut- sack. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: A Thursday in May.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5199" align="aligncenter" width="413" caption="Matt Moffett- Gonzales pool."][/caption] Back in 1999 & 2000, I lived in San Diego. There is a really amazing crew of pool skaters in the SD area, in case you didn't know.  Matt Moffett is one of them. In May, we would always drive up the I-15 together & skate Salbaland with Steve, Toby & Reuler. Often, Rhino & P-stone would venture along. Such great times! We would always try & ride often through the month of May because after that, it became really hot out in the Badlands. Anyway, I wanted to post up a photograph of my pool pal, Matt Moffett. He's a rad one! Thanks to Bryce Kanights for the image. If you look in the background, you will see Dogtown legend, 'Wes Humpston' &  San Fernando Valley legend, 'Dave Ferry'. Now, they were a couple of OG pool- riding badasses! Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Free Former Contest -1977
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5208" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Free Former World Championships"]
[/caption]
Skate event program with rider names
[caption id="attachment_5210" align="aligncenter" width="448" caption="Dennis Martinez -'Vert Wall'"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5211" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Ellen Berryman"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5212" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Long Beach Arena"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5213" align="aligncenter" width="432" caption="Stacy Peralta"][/caption] I am such a 'skate history' dork! Recently, I went to San Diego & was visiting Jim Goodrich. We were going through his old slides & photo-albums. I noticed a few slides from the California Free Former 1977 contest held in Long Beach that year. He also had a 'program' & the 'rider listing format' in his possession. Just look at the names on that list...amazing! Tony Alva, Bob Mohr, Ty Page, Bruce Logan, Paul Hoffman & Robin Logan, just to name a few. I quickly asked if I could photograph the priceless items & received the 'go ahead'. Jim told me that the 'vert wall' you see in the Dennis Martinez image was gnarly. The contest organizers were giving a hundred bucks to any rider that reached the topmost letters that say 'professional'. I think they kept their 100 $. People came close...I suppose contests & all have changed. That is a good thing. I love progression. Bruce Lee stated that "Change is the changeless state." I'm not quite sure what he meant by that, but it sounds rad...and Bruce Lee said it so it has to be meaningful. Anyway, I know these are not pool images, but they are a super- rad reminder of where we all came from. Thank you to Jim Goodrich for being so gracious with us all. You rule Jim! Skate-Ozzie

item.title: 'Black Powder'
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5223" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Salba, Nilton & myself"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5224" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Salba- always ready to get dirty."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5225" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="crew getting it done"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5226" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Nilton & Salba"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5227" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Bruno- FS lip"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5228" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Salba -FS 5-0"][/caption] Back in 2007, Salba & Bad Billy spotted this rad looking amoeba-shaped pool. They stalked & kept it under wraps...always they would lay in wait, hoping for the day. Viva emptiness. However, the house remained continually occupied. An African American family was there for awhile. One day, the crew stopped to ask permission to skate when they saw the family outside. The response Salba & the guys received was not hospitable...or printable. Gangsters. Thugs. The inevitable. However, we bide our time in Salbaland. Its how we roll. Eventually, the house turned up empty of people. They left their possessions & trash; disappearing into the inky night. Foreclosure. We went into the backyard. Nilton, Bruno, Bad Billy, Salba, Peter King & myself. There was muck & trash strewn about the dilapidated house & pool area. Painted on the wall in huge black graffiti letters was 'Black Powder'. Personally, I  venture that the author of said graffiti, might have been better served if he'd paid attention in English class. I think that he meant 'Black Power'. We laughed & the name stuck. 'Black Powder'. Here are a few images from that first session. The pool has subsequently passed into 'renter-occupied' oblivion, but the story & images remain. Thanks to Heverton Ribeiro for the photographs. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: You don't know how I feel.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5232" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="5:08 am today"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5233" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="about fifteen miles from 'ridiculous'"][/caption] I awoke at 4am just like normal. I gathered my stuff together, brushed my teeth & hit the road. I grabbed a Powerbar & coffee for the 80 mile journey over to Laguna Beach. We were working in town today. About fifteen miles into the journey, I noticed the truck becoming 'sluggish'. I turned the volume down on the Katatonia CD I was listening to & immediately heard the engine struggling & knocking. I quickly pulled off the next exit & thats when i noticed the thermostat gauge ...pegged past red. Damn! I am not quite sure what the deal is, but I sat there trying to stay focused & not trip out. After about an hour, I put some coolant into the radiator which was virtually empty....Gulp! Nothing. I phoned & left messages with  Samwise & Salba. Nothing. So, I started walking down the 210 freeway. Within 30 minutes CHP pulled over & gave me a 'riot act' for walking on the side of the freeway. He placed me into the back of the cruiser, searched my backpack & treated me like the scumbag he -obviously- thought I am. He dropped me off at the next exit and-- with a veiled warning-- told me to ' Stay off the freeway or I won't be as pleasant next time." I am sure that you know exactly what I thought of him & his pleasantries. Regardless, I started the long walk home to 'Ridiculous'. Sam & Salba phoned. Sam is an hour away & Salba told me he would be there soon. I walked about 8 miles or so before he picked me up.  I retrieved the 'shitbox' at home, turned around & drove to Laguna to work. We planted citrus trees & I must add that I haven't felt this demoralized in about two years. I borrowed the money for the truck, virtually paid it off, before I recently had it registered & insured. I have only been driving it one month.  When I had it checked out recently, the garage mechanic told me firmly, that it needs a new 600$ clutch as well. Now, I have this mornings debacle to suffer through as well. As I was walking, I could've wept with frustration. I have to say, I wanted to put a bullet in my brain in the worst way imaginable. I try so hard...I passed all sorts of litter & refuse in that walk, but all I was seeing were the liquor bottles & beer cans! I could think of nothing but ridding myself of myself.  I said the serenity prayer & stumbled on through Fontana.  Salba gave me a ride & later, I tried to find some sense in today. I guess I could piss & moan, blame fate & the world for conspiring against me..but I won't. I refuse to bend or break! I refuse!  I simply cannot afford the indulgence of self-pity. So, I am thankful that I have a job, a 'shitbox' & the pool pals that I have. We may not have much, but we have each other. Skate for me...I will be working on the truck. -Ozzie

item.title: 'Mans search for meaning.'
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5250" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Night"]
[/caption]
Skreech
In 1958, Elie Wiesel wrote his poignant memoir called-- appropriately-- 'Night'. In it, he writes about finding meaning in life. He writes about the war & making some sense in 'suffering'. Viktor Frankl posited the same line decades earlier in his life changing book, 'Mans search for meaning.' They both related that ANYTHING can give your life meaning. Its a matter of your individual perspective. As long as that 'thing' motivates you to move beyond the sheer mundane & barbarity around you; making you a better human being. Now, I know exactly what they both were alluding to. I also know that pool skating probably doesn't rate very high on societies list of acceptable & meaningful pastimes. However,  its of no consequence what society thinks of me. I must add that it  matters only what I think of society, its pressures & my response to it. I find our world frenetic, self-absorbed & destructive. I want nothing to do with societal norms. I found my 'meaning'. It may not be much, but I know there are others out there just like me. While the rest of the world is consumed by avarice, bloodshed, hate & pathos, I think that I will stay here in my muck-ridden, concrete  corner of the world. I am just fine, right here! Thank you to MRZ for the image. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: One year old.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5286" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption=" BS deathbox-Salbaland-May 16, 2010"]
[/caption]
My 'special of the day'
Today, the 'Blue Tile Obsession' is one year old. Last May, I was putting pool pictures on 'Spacebook', wishing I could write stories to go along with them. A girl that I 'sort-of' knew-- at the time--told me that I should write a blog. I didn't really know what a 'blog' was. I thought it had something to do with the financial markets. Anyway, she set it up, I chose a name & wrote a story. You know the rest. My best friend in the world is really rad! Over the years, he has kept me high, sane, troubled, sober, truthful & insane….and Jim Howell has talked me off –more than –a few ledges. He tells me the truth! He said, “Play it safe & be a mediocre ‘cool guy’, or be yourself- Ozzie." He asked me why I started the pool blog & my answer was simple. The ‘Blue Tile Obsession’ is about  ‘life’ & not just skateboarding. I wanted to connect﻿ with everyone using realism. I say what I ‘feel’ and  not what I think everyone wants to 'hear'.  I am  using these words for myself as well as you, sharing it because I know it is pure. I am sure that it  can be uncomfortable to read, just as its painful for me to live life sometimes & write about it. Its like sleeping with razor blades. Sometimes the cuts don’t wake me… but man, do I bleed! My life, troubles, disease, beliefs, skateboarding & how it saves me. Jim Howell helped me see all this clearly. I was intent on doing the 'Blue Tile Obsession' for a year. We made it. I will probably start only posting once in awhile, as its terribly difficult to continue writing quality content on a daily basis. I'd rather do it right or not at all. My big 'Thank You' section: Thank you for reading. Thanks to Brandon Wong & Zach Petschek  for the above images. Thank you to everyone at 'Bones' for their support. Thank you to all the stellar photographers & skaters that have helped & contributed this past year. Thank you Michelle Bossuot for setting up the 'Wordpress' blog. Thanks  MRZ, Christian Cooper & Jeff @ Concrete Disciples for the support.-Ozzie

item.title: endless quest
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5263" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="little cup"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5264" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="good trannies, big bite"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5265" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="perfect"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5266" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="all of the elements"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5267" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Samwise amid the splendor"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5269" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="260 gallons minute....."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5270" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="OG Anthony tag"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5271" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="yeah...happy fish."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5275" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Blue Haven muck pit"][/caption] Samwise & I, drove the grid pretty hard lately. We found some new holes, drained a few & continue the quest. I have this weird feeling that if I just continue looking, I'll find the next 'Dogbowl' or 'Gonzales' or 'Pepper' pool. Its strange, I know...but I'm obsessed.  It becomes an endless thing. I find something, drain it, dream of what can be done in it, then eventually see it through. We find & loose them with great rapidity. Its an endless quest. Samwise & I will keep at it because we know very few others that want what we do. Its time-consuming, difficult...and very dirty. I can speak for both of us & others like us, we wouldn't want it any other way. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Pams pool.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5291" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Pams 'Blue Haven' meatloaf amoeba"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5292" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Remy Stratton- 'Loveseat Ollie'"][/caption] In about 2005, Salba & Alex from Costa Rica, rented an airplane & started a pool search in the Badlands. I had gone up in a helicopter over Vista & San Marcos in 1998 and Salba has been doing so for decades. For years, it was the only way to really find pools. These two were flying low over a nearby rundown ghetto area & suddenly they couldn't believe what they were flying over. Here was this huge amoeba pool, just squatting there in the hot sun, absolutely bone dry! The yard was scorched earth & the surrounding properties appeared like a rumpled newspaper on a city street...just thrashed. Salba motioned for them to grab a video clip & plotted some landmarks. They soon were on the ground & with two cars, quickly found the property. The owners told them to "Go ahead...skate." Grinning at each other, Salba, Billy, Alex & Adam 12 hit the pool for the first of many permission sessions. The woman that lived there at the time was named 'Pam.' The property changed owners over the ensuing years & periodically we would get to cruise its 'Blue Haven' plaster. It was a gnarly pool. Steep, with 4 feet of true vert, the pool was gnarly for rock- n- rolls or lien to tail slides. Salba stated, "Chris Miller ripped it pretty good with FS airs over light and deathbox, but Rune Glifberg utterly destroyed 'Pams' more than anybody...although Remy did ollie off and over the loveseat,  which is one  of the raddest things I've ever witnessed in 30 some years of skating." 'Pams' was no joke though. The pool had a spacious deep end bowl, a side cup with a sick loveseat & thick, meatloaf coping that sent  many pool skaters rolling-- dismayed-- toward the drain,  without even a scrape of their trucks. Undergrind! Christian Hosoi, Remy Stratton & Chris Miller all rode its big walls. It stayed in the 'permission bag' for a few summers but --once again--its done. Thanks to Pam, Alex & Salba for getting it going. Thank you Brian Fick for the Remy Stratton image. Skate- Ozzie Bluetile

item.title: Brazilian bowl
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5299" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="brazilian mojo"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5301" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="cleaning"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5302" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="that's a bunch of water"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5303" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="fabio"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5304" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="kim"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5305" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="marco cruz"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5306" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Otavio Neto- Damn! Brazilians and their one-footed Smith grinds!Rad!"][/caption] 'We are joined and mixed' Oh yeah! This is the second time we've hit the 'magic pool'. We returned  there to film for an ESPN TV show, and talk about the history of this awesome discovery in 'Brazilian' skateboarding. This is the only known skated pool in Brazil, and it was located near  São Paulo city. This place was a country club which was open until the middle 1980s. Now, the facilities are in  ruins. When I saw pictures of the pool for the first time, I was in the office of the 'SKT' skateboard magazine, and we were working on  our first anniversary edition in 2005. That day, we met a skateboard crew named 'Class D', which is a  reference to their social scale conditions. We went out & shot some pictures and in the middle of session, the skaters talked about the pool. Renato is a good overall skater too and when he saw that place he was stoked! It was located in a very dirty place with water and a lot of things inside. The picture of Hevertons was shot with a fish eye lens and doesn't show the real dimensions of the pool. A few days after, Renato, his friend at the mag, and I  were  going there to see the pool! Well, I can't describe the sensation in my body! Immediately, we spoke with the man who was responsible to monitor the place for trespassers and asked  permission to clean the pool and skate. The cleaning session lasted a full day and we take off a lot of crap, fish, little frogs and everything, including a dog skull. After all the hard work, when the sun was dwindling, I got my skate and dropped in the middle of the wet pool to feel the transitions! I rode, listening to the sound of my wheels and thinking about this one perfect moment in my life! These images of Heverton's,  correspond with the second session to this magical place. The next trip, we found the pool to be very full of rain water, and we couldn't do the session in the same day. We had to drain it again. The next day we returned again and completed this incredible  session.-Walter Garrote Addendum-Thank you everyone for the emails, comments, insults, encouragement & stuff during this last week. I am working on new posts for Blue Tile & received this from some pool pals in Brazil. Thank you to Walter Garrote for writing the article & Heverton Ribeiro for the images. Skate-Ozzie.

item.title: otavio neto bs smith one foot

item.title: Flashback
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5334" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Bobby Piercy- Carlsbad 1977"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5335" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Piercy & 'prize'"][/caption] Back in the 1970s, it was slightly different. Clothing & music was questionable, cocaine ruled, and skateboarding could get you laid. I just think that these photographs perfectly depict the hubris & decadence of the age. Rumors abound regarding Bobby Piercy & his predilection for the 'high life', pretty girls & skating. I heard that he is gone now, but his memory & reputation linger on. Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the images. Skate- Ozzie Bluetile

item.title: role models
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5350" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Shogo Kubo & Paul Hoffman -2005"]
[/caption]
Paul Hoffman- La Costa 1977
[caption id="attachment_5341" align="aligncenter" width="432" caption="Shogo Kubo-Lakewood 1979"][/caption] I peered out my window & groaned inwardly. Ice coated the stark, leafless tree branches & frost the entire space of things. Winter hangs heavy in Pennsylvania & skateboarding is a costly endeavor. It costs. One must make places to skate. Jim Howell & I built ramps in barns, garages & basements. To those like us, the magazine was everything. Trapped indoors & weary of the sleeping seasons, we dreamt of blue tiled pools, California sunshine & palm trees. We dreamt of riding with those we saw in the magazines. We wanted anything but what we had. For the gun-toting hunters & sports jocks around central Pennsylvania, there were many role models to choose from. Jim & I had only our magazine heroes. That was the way it was. Fini. We had Tony Alva, Jerry Valdez, Paul Hoffman, Waldo Autry & Shogo Kubo. We had a few others like these that made us continue doing what we were doing. Through freezing cold winters & humid, insect-plagued summers, Jim & I hunted --fruitlessly --for a backyard  pool & were content with our occasional rough concrete ditch or asphalt bank. Perseverance. We saw these skaters & they helped shape us into what we are today. I can speak or both of us in saying "Thank you. We wouldn't change a thing." Thank you to Jim Goodrich for the images. Skate & remember your heroes. -Ozzie Bluetile

item.title: 'Ridiculous' redux
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5344" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="before..."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5345" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Ed, Chris & Billy- patching & repairs"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5346" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Thursday...Samwise & Salba gave her a primer coat. Friday...final paint!"][/caption] Peter Kings 'Ridiculous' is a heavily sessioned pool. We usually repair & repaint the entire pool twice a year. This past week, it was time. Riverside Ed, Samwise, Billy & Badlands Chris got together & started the process. All the bad areas were chiseled out, repaired & set right. Salba & Samwise primered the patch areas today. PK is in the house tonight & in the morning, we will tape it off & give her a fresh coat. Saturday is going to be so fun! I will keep you posted. Thanks to Samwise for the images. Skate- Ozzie Bluetile

item.title: messed up
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5359" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="great shape"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5360" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="who scraped the skin off!?"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5361" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="dang"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5362" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="would've been a close one."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5363" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="sadness"][/caption] The lawn was dead. Once it had grown thick & lush across the front of this  stucco & red brick 'San Bernardino' monstrosity. Trash, leaves, and old newspapers had collected on the porch & the black wrought- iron railings were thick with cobwebs. I ran an experienced eye over the adjacent properties. Everything in its place. This early in the morning, I could scout & perform my recon with little threat of interference by neighbors. I was dressed like anyone else out here. I looked like I belonged. That is the key. Look & act like you belong, remove suspicion, wave 'hello' at neighbors & people generally leave you alone. It has worked for me. The palm trees were thick & sagging with dried & dusty palm fronds. Stark red Bougainvillea grew across the brick wall surrounding the property. I checked the mailbox, front windows & assessed for human presence. The grass crunched underfoot & I immediately thought of the 2003 fires out here. With the heat & dessication occurring in 'San Bernardino', it only takes a cigarette & life changes drastically for people. The official estimate for homes lost in the 2003 fire was close to 1500. That's a bunch of suffering. I approached the side wall & peered through a broken wooden gate. I saw blue tiles. Pulling myself up & over, I checked for the presence of dogs & 'threats'. It appeared abandoned.  Trash bags of rotten garbage were stacked in a corner of the back patio. It seemed as though the owners just let things go. I saw indifference & abandon at every glance. Whoever lived here, didn't care. The pool was a great shape but the surface looked like some giant hand had come down and grated the surface off.  It seemed as though the owners had wanted to re-plaster the pool but never got around to it. The transitions looked stellar & my only thought was "...messed up." A large green lizard --startled by my intrusion--scurried across the deck, blinked & disappeared into the ivy growth. It was a fitting gesture, because whoever lived there had disappeared in a hurry. Cereal bowls were sitting on the counter with green mold growing out of them. Toys, clothing & a broken television were in the kitchen, strewn about. The propane gas grill was squatting darkly on the deck by the shallow end...its propane tank long gone. The lid was in a corner of the yard. Half burnt fire logs were stacked on top of the grills grating like some obscene makeshift fire pit. In the corner beside the grills lid were about a hundred empty wine & liquor bottles. That explained it all to me. Messed up. Letting things go & boozing will quickly lead to the loss of everything. Thus endeth the lesson. Skate-Ozzie Bluetile

item.title: 'truth is a pathless land'
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5375" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="a pathless land"]
[/caption]
aaron astorga- bs ollie over a punishing land
Jiddu Krishnamurti stated that "Truth is a pathless land. The moment you follow an organisation, church, ideology or person, you cease to follow 'Truth'. You can only discover the 'Truth'--for yourself-- within yourself." Does that sound complicated? Maybe to some. But I think that I know what he is getting at. If we sit around and view the world through the opinions of others, all we'll ever see in ourselves is the opinions of others. We become 'parrots'...repeating phrases and words that have little meaning for us. We say these things because its expected of us. All I know is what I've read, experienced & been taught by the hard realities of life.  Am I merely doing the same with Krishnamurti's words? Am I simply a by-product of 'conditioning?' Is there any other way to be? Its difficult for me to not be jaded & pessimistic. I work on this everyday. Have a rad Sunday and 'think on these things'. Thanks to MRZ for the image. Skate-Ozzie Bluetile Check out: Krishnamurti Foundation of America http://www.kfa.org/

item.title: 'Ridiculous' Summer session
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5387" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Peter King- at his house."]
[/caption]
Bryan- Crail
[caption id="attachment_5400" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Monster- BS side stairs"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5401" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="PaPa Serna- Bs grind"][/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Michael Serna Jr."][/caption]
Mike Perez- FS Air over side stairs
[caption id="attachment_5388" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Samwise"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5389" align="aligncenter" width="400" caption="Taylor Serna"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5391" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Eddie-FS Grind"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5386" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="pool side tacos with the crew"][/caption] This weekend turned out to be amazing, even though most of what was planned didn't occur or the plans were 'kicked sideways.' We made do. Last week, Peter King told me that he was doing a photo shoot/ filming session on Friday with some heavy pool players. We decided to repair & repaint the 'Ridiculous' pool for the session. During the week---as you know--Samwise, Billy, Ed and Badlands Chris made the repairs. We painted it on Friday. That morning, Peter King told me there was not going to be a photo shoot at the pool after all. They had decided to do it all at the 'Pink Motel' pool which Converse had refurbished for Rune Glifbergs shoe- release party. I shrugged & went back to painting. Bill & Tristan Rennie came over & with Samwise, helped me paint everything. The 'house crew' pruned the palms, cleaned  the property & hosed everything spotless. Saturday morning, we decided to have a BBQ session for our pool pals. Eddie from Ontario makes the best tacos & caters, so he was on the list immediately. We invited a bunch of people, bought some drinks, chips & hot dogs, then got things started. People flowed in and out all evening & into the night. Everyone was 'hooting' & 'hollaring', laughing & doing this thing we do. We have an amazing scene out here at 'Ridiculous' & Peter King rules for getting this one special place that we can call "our own!" Thank you to everyone that brought food, drinks & happiness. We love our friends. Thank you Peter King & Brandon Wong for the images. Skate-Ozzie Bluetile

item.title: Two in one.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5409" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Brandon Wong"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5410" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Kevin Burke"][/caption] I have two pool pals that are always down to clean & skate something. We've been out on --more than-- a few missions together & its been super fun! We got together a few weekends ago & rode an old favorite. It was a good day out. We ended up riding a few pools, taking a swim & having some food on the grill. Pool Pals. Two friends, a pool & one goal: fun. Thanks to Brandon Wong for the images. Skate-Ozzie Bluetile

item.title: it was raining in my house.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5413" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Doug Kinkade- pointing toward some light."][/caption] I found this journal entry a week ago. I find it hard to believe --and harder still-- to know that I was so lost. There are many out there, still plodding that path with all its danger & horror. I hope they work it out. We'll leave a light on... I loath myself. I hate what I've become...a monster if you will. Thinking back, I remember whenever she saw me, looked at me, talked with me, anything & everything we did, she had this look in her eyes. An amazing gleam. She actually looked into me & made me feel like I was a great person, special...those looks occur no longer. Those glances have been gone for some time now. I am--and have become--a virtual non-entity. She knows I am an addict & looks down at me; she looks at me as if I'm nothing. So, I am right back to square one & every time I look at her I see it reflected back at me. It's absolutely killing me. I can't go on being just a junkie. I am meant for more than this!  I'm at the end & there is no light in the tunnel. The only thing is darkness. A darkness that even has shadows. I feel it in my bones. Dripping water on cold stones. Drip. Drip. Drip. A sodden promise of more rain...more bad weather. I look for light. I feel only despair. I may have to leave because my enemy may be stronger than I.    12-29-06 Skateboarding saved my life. Thanks to Brian Fick for the image. Skate-Ozzie Bluetile

item.title: Doug Kinkade Shallow end front rock
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz

item.title: He is of my kind.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5450" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Darren Ho- Hawaii- 1978"][/caption] I have lived by the ocean, yet rarely find myself in its waters. I have a strange fascination & horror of the sea. It is all of the things I cannot understand. It lives & moves, pulls & crashes. In its inky darkness lurk things; hidden & furtive. I watch the sea in wonder. I marvel at those that have no fear of the sea. I don't think Darren Ho fears the sea...at all. He certainly doesn't fear concrete & this makes him one of my kind. One of my favorite authors wrote the following passage. "The sea-the great, grey, cold-eyed woman of the ages...Her tides spoke to me as they have spoken to me since birth-in the swish of the flat waves along the sand, in the wail of the ocean bird, in her throbbing silence. She is very old & very wise. She murmurs..."I have no part of man" -Robert E. Howard- 1926 Thank you to Jim Goodrich for the image. Skate- Ozzie Bluetile

item.title: Bruce Browns
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5454" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Josh Borden is my favorite!"]
[/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Bruce Brown?"][/caption]

Anthony Von Engelen
[caption id="attachment_5469" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Chuck Hults"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5470" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Fini"][/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Kevin Burke"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5464" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Rune Glifberg"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5465" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Peter King"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5466" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Me- Indy nose bonk"][/caption]
undercover
[caption id="attachment_5455" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Samwise -overcome by 'bruce brown' & coming up for air"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5457" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Samwise- working"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5458" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="GOSH!"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5459" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Me- bucket washdown. check out the trannies..."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5460" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="good grief!"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5461" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Bruce Browns"][/caption] It was a Friday night at 'Ridiculous'. I had just driven in from Laguna Beach & had bravely maintained my sanity through the three hour ordeal of weekend traffic. I must have had an 'idiot magnet' on the hood of my car because every ten minutes, some bonehead pulled in front of me & started texting or checking themselves out in their 'vanity' mirror. Ugh! I wanted a 'rocket launcher' in the worst way imaginable. Salba had emailed me earlier that day. He had been scouting & found a pretty neat looking kidney. It had a wooden & wire covering over it & was half- full of putrid water. No problem, I thought.  It was time to phone my side kick. Samwise agreed that it had to be checked out thoroughly & the next morning, he was sitting in the living room at 7:30am. We drove by & pulled a 'recon' of the place. The cover had plastic sheeting stapled to it and --with great effort--we pulled up a corner & propped it on bricks. I wriggled inside & Sam followed. We heard a humming & noticed it was like a sauna under there! The buzzing mosquitoes started hungrily munching on our exposed skin. It was gnarly. The transitions were so mellow that we laughed out loud in spite of ourselves. Insane! We agreed that now was the time. It wouldn't wait. With Herculean effort, we rolled about four feet of the cover back on each end, then threw the pump into the murkiness. I saw a neighbor & went out to talk. He was cool after I explained my presence. We drained & cleaned it, then left it sit. We needed more help getting the cover completely off.  I figured that it was a six- man job. The following Sunday, Brian Fick came out. He had previously arranged to come ride pools. He was bringing Rune Glifberg, Zach & Lucas Miller. Tom Remillard came as well. We rode a few holes & I decided to take everyone there & remove the cover. I hopped the fence & was shocked to find it rolled up beside the pool! About 2000 pounds of wood & wire...just sitting to one side! I was like WTF!? I walked the perimeter of the pool. To one side of the coping, right on the deck, was scratched 'Bruce Brown', in the concrete. 'Perfect' I thought. Bruce Brown made the surf film, 'Endless Summer'. I never did figure out who removed the cover, but there were no skate marks anywhere so I assumed the landscapers did it. We rode for awhile then Salba showed up with Tyco, Billy & Zask. Such radness! Fick shot some great images & everyone went home stoked! Over the next weeks, I took a few  people over there for short sessions. It was amazing. Last weekend, Guy Mariano, Chuck Hults, Anthony Van Engelen, Josh Borden & a few others, came out to ride. We went by & Ray Zimmerman shot some epic photographs. Anthony Acosta took some stellar images as well. As we were finishing the session, I looked over & saw a police uniform. "We have company." I informed everyone. Before we left the house, I had reviewed the rules. If someone comes, I talk & they keep quiet & still.  I approached the officers & gave them my ID & spoke to them about what we were doing. After a bit of verbal sparring, they let us all walk. We calmly departed & said, "Thank you." That was our last session. Salba told me that the next day, he & Toby went back & hit it for fifteen minutes. I guess the 'Master' got the last licks. The whole thing lasted 3 weeks...but what a pool! I drove over this morning at 5:15am. The workers have been putting a new roof on the house, the pool side stairs are replaced & its full to the top. We made it a reality. Our own short-lived 'Endless Summer'. Thanks Bruce Brown. Thank you to Brandon Wong, MRZ, Peter King,Brian Fick, Peanut &  Samwise for the images. Skate- Ozzie Bluetile

item.title: terminus of meus lacuna
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5486" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Blue Tile Obsession"][/caption] I am finishing the Lance Mountain story. Its over three-quarters completed & when Lance returns from Europe, we will post it up under 'articles'. Blue Tile Obsession is done.  'Thank you' for reading & 'Thank you' to those that contributed. I will be working on interviews for CD & be seeing you around. My respect goes out to everyone. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Pennsylvania -1979
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5490" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="My halfpipe -lower edge of image"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5491" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Me- rock-n-roll on 2X4 coping"][/caption] If you've been following my stories, you know that Jimbo & I had to build ramps in order to ride. One day my father gave me this photograph. He had taken it when he went flying in a small Cessna airplane one day. You can see my halfpipe...one of the versions of it anyway. Sometimes, I had only a wooden 2X4 as coping. There were no decks on it at times. We would climb out on the rickety edge & take the vert plunge. If I remember correctly, Devo, The Cars 'Candy-O'  & The Buzzcocks 'Singles Going Steady' played constantly on days when Jimbo & I rode. Pennsylvania. It was a world where I never 'fit in', where I was regularly ridiculed & anger festered within me. It was skateboarding-- on days like these-- that saved me. Thanks to my father for the images. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: 'OC Fishbowl' revisted.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5511" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Fishbowl 2010"]
[/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Josh Borden dropped by earlier for a 'Smith' over fish."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5521" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="both sides of the fence"][/caption]
Duane Peters
[caption id="attachment_5512" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Me- BS Air"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5513" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Fishbowl crew & owner-2010"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5514" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="fresh-baked cookies compliments of the host"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5515" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Ben Butler- shallow stairs with 'man- beverage'"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5500" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Fishbowl 1989-1990"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5501" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Chicken -1990"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5502" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Chicken -2010"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5503" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Chuck Hults"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5504" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Ricky Barnes"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5505" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Duane Peters-Indy"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5506" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Fish"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5507" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Ben Butler- FS deathbox"][/caption] In November of 2008, I went over to the 'Fishbowl' after a week of searching for it. Rumors abounded, regarding its place in the history of Orange County skateboarding. It was rumored to be an 'on again, off again' type of scene...much like the famed 'Gonzales' pool in Los Angeles. Supposedly, guys had ridden the 'Fishbowl' as early as 1975. All this was going through my head, as I stopped in the alley & pulled myself up on the wall for a peek. First of all, I was surprised at just how much stuff, can be crammed into one backyard. There were plants, cactus, succulents & flowers of every make & pain-inflicting kind, located in pots all around the deck of the pool. There was a partially dismantled truck, a camper, paint cans, sheds, tools & assorted items for household cleaning. In the pool was about three feet of rainwater...and a big aluminum boat! A boat! It took up the whole pool. I whistled under my breath. Phew! "That is a busy backyard". The trannies appeared really mellow, though the deep end was a bit steep. Multi-colored porcelain fish were attached to the pools surface. The whole scene looked like some macabre aquarium from hell. I took two quick photographs & rounded the front to give the owner my spiel. He had nothing to say to me except, "No!" Then he walked back inside. Fini. Recently, a pal of Ben Butlers bought the house next door, which also has a pool. His name is Jon Tucker.  He skates & makes skateboarding videos. After draining his pool & having some fair-sized but controlled sessions, he managed to befriend his neighbor who owns the famed 'Fishbowl' house. The man decided to let a few pool pals session the 'Fishbowl'. Very neighborly. Its permission ONLY. If you know someone, go with them & be respectful. If you don't know, don't go! That comes from the owners of both places. The grapevine sent out the good word, and the deal was struck. Jon & the 'Fishbowls' owner-  'Jeff' -gave us the 'go-ahead' on the story. I called Salba but he didn't make it. I phoned Duane as he had ridden the pool in the 1970s. He was ready & brought in two old 'Fishbowl' veterans, 'Arab' & 'Chicken'. We met up with everyone & Ray Zimmerman & Christian Cooper of CD, came along for a few turns & to help me 'get the story straight.' A great time was had & everyone threw down. The owners daughter came out at the end with fresh-baked cookies for us! How insane is that?! You have to love when those things occur. Arab shared some memories, as did Chicken & Duane. I figured I would let their words stand. Its their record of what transpired. So it goes.... "We first started skating the pool back around 1976-77.  In those early years, the old lady that lived there would charge us 50 cents to skate.  Duane reminded me that it was 50 cents per hour,  then I remembered she had an old cooking timer she would set for 1 hour and leave it in the kitchen window. When our time was up,  it was either pay another 50 cents or split.....   In the early days you would get free tap water in a little Dixie cup,  but then when she realized she could make money on the water she would charge us 10 cents for iced tap water in an 8 ounce Dixie cup." "The first time that I went to the 'Fishbowl', there was an old wooden fence surrounding the yard and I had jumped up to look over at the pool. As I pulled myself up, I pulled the fence right over onto myself!   It was fucking hilarious!!  We propped the fence back up and went around to the front and asked if we could skate..." "I don't know who originally found the pool. It could have been Arnie Hogue and his brothers, as they lived in the area.  Arnie and his family moved away to Utah or something, before the whole 'pool contest' thing started.  You ask anybody that knew him though...  Olson,  DP or the Carrasco brothers and they will  tell you,  Arnie was one of the best pool skaters --ever-- back in the day. Had he stuck around, he would have probably won the 'Hester series' the first couple years. He was like Gerry Lopez on a skateboard;  so much style and so much power,  he owned the 'Concrete Wave' pool and every other pool around OC in the 1970's." "Back to Fishbowl. The pool saw some great sessions back then & it was a tough little pool to skate, because it was so tight. Later on, in the mid  to late 1980's, there was another resurgance of the 'Fishbowl'.  By then, the brick wall that surrounds the pool was built and some of the little fish that protruded from the plaster walls had been chipped off." "In the early 1990s,  the house was sold and the guy that lives there now had moved in. He would not let anyone skate.  I tried about every 5 yrs, knocking on the door and asking if I could skate.  One of his daughters would always tell me that their dad would "kill them" if they would let anybody skate the pool..." "I stopped over-- about a year ago-- and there was a bunch of potted plants in the bowl & no answer at the door.  I didn't feel like barging by myself without a lookout, so I just chalked it up to another failed attempt. A couple months ago Ben Butler had told me about the guy that lived next door. He had a kinky square pool thing that they were skating and the owner of the 'Fishbowl' was letting them skate his pool now." "Then, the other night, DP texts me, "We are riding 'Fishbowl' with Ozzie Saturday" and that I need to meet at Chickens by 11 am if I want to go.  I've been plagued with injuries the last couple years and haven't been able to skate much.  I wasn't going to let this opportunity pass me up.  I had tried too hard & too long to skate that pool again,  even if it just meant 'taking one' run for nostalgia's sake....  I skated more on Saturday at the 'Fishbowl' than I have in the last couple years. I'm hurting today,  but it was worth it!" "OC has had some pretty legendary pools over the decades.  Most notably, Orange Hills L/H Kidneys 1 and 2, Fruitbowl (Garden Grove), Tahiti Inn (Costa Mesa), San Juan/Alva Bowl,  Ledges (Garden Grove),  Cool Mommas (Rossmoor),  Dan and Ruths/Sign In Bowl (Buena Park) and The Fish Bowl....." "How cool is it to be able to go skate a pool you --originally--skated almost 35 yrs earlier?! Thanx Man" --Arab "There was a really heavy local scene, back in the 1970s." Every pool crew had their own spots & you didn't just cruise up on someones pools. When we did try to go someplace else, we had to be careful. One guy would peek over the wall...uh-oh! Heavy session going. We could hear the skating. One of us would hop over & feel out the scene. If  you got the 'nod', you had to get in there and get some...try & go all out! We always had a few pools in our pockets, that way we could trade with the locals. At 'Fishbowl' there were a couple of Mexican guys that were rad. This one guy was doing 'rock walks' beside the deathbox...later at 'Concrete Wave', there was quite a bit of argument regarding the 'rock walk' or the 'cess slide'. It all went back to the 'Fishbowl.'  Some of the earliest 'tailblocks' were done there.The old lady living there, did have a kitchen timer...she also had a little hourglass timer, if I remember clearly. That was a heavy localized scene though. Arnie Hogue was a rad guy...really good. He did one of the first 'taildrops' ever done on vertical. The 'Fishbowl' was going before the 'Concrete Wave' opened, I know that. That pool has been going for a long time. It was great to go back there."-Duane Peters Thank you to 'Jeff' for letting us ride, his daughter for the cookies, Jon Tucker & Ben Butler for doing the impossible, Arab, Chicken & Duane for their memories & images. Thanks to Ray Zimmerman for shooting such great shots & Arab for allowing me the use of his great shots as well. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: The long hot summer.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5538" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption=" Ozzie: Tuck-knee handplant. 1980"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5539" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Jim Howell: BS air. 1980"][/caption] School was out & the long hot summer began. Central Pennsylvania grows really humid  in June. It can be unbearable when you are outside doing--virtually--anything. Jim Howell & I never really let the weather bother us. We didn't care...much.  We rode in freezing barns, dirty cobweb-festooned basements & drafty attics. We did anything to skate. Cherry Hill was an option, but we needed a ride & that didn't happen everyday. With a two hour commute, parents & friends were 'less than' enthusiastic, at driving us to the skate park & sitting there all day. I understood. One day in June, I called Jimbo & he came over to the house. We frequently changed the ramp, according to our whims & ideas. We saw the 'tombstone' at the 'High Roller' contest in the magazine & fashioned one for the ramp. It was a joke, but we dropped in, pulled rock-n-rolls & airs off of it. Once, we wanted to learn 'fakie ollies' but the one side of my ramp was small, so we built an 'over-vert' addition. We didn't have plywood, so I went down this winding country road behind my house. I went to an old deserted barn & pulled 'tongue-in-groove' planks off. We put them together & added about a foot of 'over-vert' on the ramp. Jimbo pulled 'fakie ollies' & 'fakie ollie to tail' that night. We hung a "Coleman' lantern on the corner of the ramp as it was growing dark & he was close to making it. As bugs flew in our mouths & dive-bombed us, Jimbo slapped one down. We were elated! These negatives sat in my fathers darkroom file cabinet until about three weeks ago. He wasn't sure if they were good or not. He just sent them. I asked Ray to scan them & just saw them for the first time ever. There was an image of Jimbo as well! So Stoked.  We didn't have very many images from my ramp so this was a find! I wanted to share them with everyone. Thank you to my father- 'David' -for these images. Skate. - Ozzie

item.title: Alone with everybody.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I could be faceless here with you. A vacuum. A cipher. Sometimes I am okay, other times, I feel as though there is something terribly wrong going on inside of me. I feel torn and buffeted by everyone & everything. My head throbs & pain marches down my neck. I lay in my bed & squirm like a beetle under a hiking boot. Gods! If I could find a hole deep enough, I would climb inside & barricade myself...escaping my fellow man forever. Ego, Ego, Ego...please go the hell away!

item.title: Warren Bolster
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5550" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="The Legacy of Warren Bolster."]
[/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Warren Bolster signature"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5553" align="aligncenter" width="432" caption="Warren Bolster - La Costa 1978"][/caption]

Warren Bolster shot of Bob Biniak. Two greats are gone.
The photographic images of Warren Bolster covered the walls of my bedroom back in Pennsylvania. His images fueled my young mind & gave me hope. His skateboard photography gave me something to continually aspire to. We lost Warren Bolster on 06 September 2006. We then lost Bob Biniak on 25 February 2010. I will never forget the influence they have had on me. Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the images & memories. Skate & respect to these great pioneers of our sport. -Ozzie
