item.title: Scorcher!
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Riverside & its surrounding areas can burn your brain in its shell during the summer months. It --regularly--reaches 100 + degrees & it'll sap the life right out of you during a skate session. Anthony Van Engelen (AVE) & Greg Hunt had wanted to come out & ride a few 'permission' pools. AVE had a few things he wanted to film. I checked around & tried to figure out something that would be 'aesthetically' pleasing & rad to ride. I wanted a pool with mellow transitions & a cupped shallow end.
I phoned Riverside Ed. He was always sitting on a few good pools. Over the past few years, he has found some of the best pools out there & always has a few on 'lock'. He told me that he could 'accommodate' us & had a few 'permissions' going. He phoned me back a few days later. "I have three ready." I passed the word that it was a 'go' for Sunday morning. My cohorts, MRZ & Christian Cooper, met me at the appointed place & Christian bought us some breakfast.
The sky was overcast slightly, but we knew that it wouldn't last.The sun & heat were coming. The rest of the crew appeared. Anthony Acosta, Cody, Hunt & AVE, along with Riverside Ed & his pool pal 'Kevin' all were ready. It was good that we were going to 'permission pools', with a crew this large. We hit the first pool. Its an epic old 'Comma' shaped pool from a better time in the 1950s. A huge wooden porch roof, towers over the deep end providing shade & a respite from the heat. We would need it. On the hip, an enormous 'California King Palm' stood like a sentinel over the plaster pool below.
AVE & Christian jumped right into the mess. Sweeping & bucketing the small amount of filth. I liked seeing that! "Stepping up." We immediately started carving lines & picking out the speed flow of the pool. It is more of a 'goofy foot' pool but everyone got in there. We pushed ourselves hard for almost two hours. AVE threw down 'light box' , I struggled with the 'pretzel line' bs box & everyone else carved & floated throughout this 'gem' from the past.
After thoroughly draining ourselves from the heat & exertion, we headed to the next pool. We stopped to pick up some beverages at a small market/ liquor store. We all had a laugh at the pictures posted on the windows by the checkout cashier. They were fuzzy security camera images of guys running out of the store with cases of 'Tecate' & 'Bud Light'. The Korean folks behind the counter didn't seem to share in our enthusiasm or hubris. They were the unfortunate victims of the 'beer bandits'.
We all followed each other to our next pool. It was a 'caravan'. We pulled up & parked. In the yard, there seemed to be an unending supply of small dogs. At quick glance, they were yapping & making a fuss. Once Jose--the owner-- let us inside, they calmed down. Jose has lived there for almost a decade. He has the pool as a 'swimmer' periodically. The story that Ed & Kevin told us, is that in the 1970s & 1980s, people skated this pool. Ed & Kevin both remember this pool as being the one where they each did the deathbox for the first time. That's quite the milestone for pool riders. I remember my first deathbox.
We all met the family, & swept the pool out. By now it was feeling like a million degrees. The heat was baking us! The pool was an older right hand kidney. It had a loveseat on the left wall close to the light. The deathbox was on the right side. Ed pushed in & quickly sealed the deal with a BS light loveseat carve that left everyone yelling! Damn! AVE felt out the pool a bit, then he threw down FS 5-0 grinds over the light loveseat. Kevin FS grinded the box & I fooled around a little as well. Christian , Acosta , Cody & Ray, all got in the pool & cruised around...happy to be rolling in a backyard pool.
AVE & his crew headed back to LA & Acosta joined us for one more little 'Blue Haven'. We swept out this 'Blue Haven' arrow shaped pool while crickets overran our position like the Russian soldiers engulfing Berlin in WWII. The crickets were 'tripping'...and they came out of the leaves & drain in waves. We attempted to 'shoo' them out but--finally--gave up. Everyone carved this pool & a few grinds were put down but --by this time-- we were all sapped. We ended the day at an 'air conditioned' taco shop. We re-hydrated & while Christian & I discussed tricks & video parts, Ray & Anthony Acosta talked photography & 'tech' talk. After saying our 'goodbyes', we then headed out into our different directions & back to our lives. It was an epic day of pool riding and --rest assured--that I will be doing the same thing next weekend. Thank you to Riverside Ed for making it happen. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Lance Mountain
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Within skateboarding, amid the ranks of the 'greats', the 'self-proclaimed', the 'talkers', the 'doers' & the 'followers', are several individuals that stand out. Lance Mountain is one of these 'standouts' & an enigma to most people; an unfinished puzzle. If he has a common motivating thread that runs through his life, it is his will to be obedient to the Lord & the word of God.
Lance is a man of strong conviction & belief. In a sport overflowing with 'cool-guy' mediocrity & clones, Lance --virtually--stands alone. He really doesn't mind. Through the highs & lows of skateboardings --sometimes--volatile industry, he has been following his path in the same manner for many years.
I found that Lance is not one to speak first, but if asked, he will tell you the truth. However, his opinion will--sometimes--fall on deaf ears. As soon as Lance broaches the subject of his 'belief in God', some ears grow shut. Lance Mountain definitely has an opinion about how things should be within skateboarding & the world at large.
Sometimes it seems as though Lance Mountain was handed the 'Oscar' unexpectedly & now has to come up with an acceptance speech. He is reserved & cautious in his talk. It's as if he doesn't really believe that he warrants his position in the panoply of skateboarding legendry. I think that at certain times in his career, Lance has felt 'undeserving', and seems to feel that all the places at the table have been taken for the banquet feast.
Periodically, Lance has been relegated to the role of 'light entertainment'...the 'court jester'. This is furthest from the truth. One of the primary reasons for Lance Mountains continued popularity & high regard among skateboarders is that, not only does he continue to rip & progress, but he seems to be having the most fun. Isn't that the reason we all started skating in the first place?
Lance, like many others, started skating in the time of Tony Alva & the Dogtown crew. He saw what the Zboys were doing & emulated it. He wore a hat like TA & Jayboy, knew FS tuck-knee airs were proper & wore argyle socks. He made his own boards with a Wes Humpston 'Dogtown' cross on the bottom. In a side note, I asked TA about the hats they would wear & he looked at me sort-of absently & responded, "It wasn't a hat, Ozzie. It was a 'brim'." I guess when you wear a hat with 'style' it becomes a 'brim'. Lance --upon hearing TA's comment --quipped, "I guess I was wearing a hat."
Regardless, Lance --like so many others--copied the style of the Zboys. He said to himself, "This is what skateboarding is." Lance & I were at 'Ridiculous' on the day we were recording this part of the interview. We were sitting at the breakfast bar looking out over the pool. A photograph of Jay Adams grinding a backyard hole, hangs just behind us. Lance peered out of the window & stated flatly, "At that time, Tony Alva was skateboarding. That is just the way it was." I nodded & kept quiet.
Lance continued. "Then, when Steve Alba won the first pool contest-- ever-- at Spring Valley, I immediately said, "Oh, this is what skateboarding is now. I made a 'Badlands' cross logo for my board to replace the 'Dogtown' cross & went from there." Lance continued to skate anything he could. "We bought & sent away for our 'Skatepark Montebello' cards in 1976. The park opened in 1977." I rode 'Lakewood Center' & 'Skate City Whittier' but was never really a local as I could only go on weekends."
Lance entered some park contests at Montebello. The first contest he entered was--actually--a 'high jump' contest. He also recalls going to the famous Freeformer contest in Long Beach, but remembers little of what went on. The Lakewood contest in 1979, was where he first saw all the pro riders together. Up until then, Lance told me that he had seen a fair number of pro riders at Montebello. The Lakewood contest of 1979 was different. It made a huge impact for Lance. "Salba won that contest. I saw Bobby Valdez win the 'high air' contest with an 'invert', which was weird. I watched Darrell Miller, Shogo Kubo, Jimmy Plummer, Stacy Peralta, Micke Alba, Pineapple Saladino & a bunch of others."
Lance said that the Lakewood contest changed his mind about skating & the direction he was going. "I had seen Bobby Valdez do inverts before the Lakewood contest & knew that I had to learn them... which I did." Shortly after, Lance & his dad went to England. His father is from England & they definitely made plans to stop at the British skate parks while there.
Lance pulled inverts at Harrow. The local skaters were like, "Who are you? Who do you ride for?" Lance looked at me & grinned. "I was just....me. Nobody. I had a homemade board that I made in the bathtub with new green 'Cubics'. The British skaters had never seen them. They were like, "Inverts? Cubics? You must ride for someone!" I just shook my head & said "No." Lance laughs at the memory. When he returned from England, he entered a Lakewood amateur contest & began riding ASPO contests for 'Skate City Whittier' as well. The ASPO contests pitted Lance against Billy Ruff, Tony Hawk, Neil Blender & Gator, to name a few.
In 1980, Stacy, Steve Caballero & Scott Foss visited Whittier en route to the Escondido contest. The 'Bones Brigade' had just been formed & Stacy was touring around with his young team of amazing talent. An 'unknown' Lance Mountain was told by his park manager 'Jerry' to come to the park & show Stacy what he could do.
Lance did as he was told and --subsequently--was not one of the lucky ones chosen to usher in the new age of skateboarding in the 'Bones Brigade' upper echelon. At the time, he was crestfallen and he told me flatly, "I just wasn't good enough." He laughed softly, looking away at the floor.
Years later, after being on the 'Bones Brigade' & touring with Steve Caballero, the two became close friends. Steve told him , "I remember you! You were the 'annoying' local rider following us around everywhere." Lance smiled and in a low voice rumbles, "It wasn't really like that. I was just trying to show Stacy what I could do. Everyone wanted to be on Powell/ Peralta at the time. I sure did!"
"When Powell/Peralta came together, I wanted that. I was always that way. Since the urethane wheel & the Bennett truck, I always wanted what I thought really 'represented' skateboarding. With Powell/Peralta, it was the whole package. The image, the product, the team. It was Stacy, Jay Smith, Scott Foss, Ray Bones, then Steve Caballero. In my mind, they were the best."
Lance and I finished for the day & went skating pools. We got together a few weeks later. We met at his house with a crew of 'round- wall aficionados' & watched Mimi Knoop make a FS ollie over the side stairs ladder. Lance was yelling just as loudly as the rest of us, while Mimi simply looked relieved. We sat to one side while a low-key session ensued. I asked him about getting on 'Variflex'.
"Well, my skateboard was stolen at the 'Upland' contest & Steve Hirsch gave me his board. I entered the contest riding it.The next contest was 'Colton'. At the 'Colton' contest, Gil Losi asked me to ride for 'Variflex' & go on a US tour with them." Since I knew that no amateurs went on US tours, I said yes!"
Lance took a sip of water & pointed toward the pool, after Carabeth Burnside pulled a sick 'feeble' grind on the facewall. "Rad!" He clapped & then continued. "In 1981, all the skate parks were closing. We were to go to Cherry Hill & Apple but they were done. We hit Kona, Michigan & others, but park after park closed. We arrived in Boulder to get one of the last sessions there. Everything was done. I had finally made it & BAM!... it was over. The whole thing was sad."
Lance padded up & went to ride with the others. I recalled the close of Cherry Hill skate park with bitterness. It was such a great place...a Mecca. In some small way, I knew how he felt. Ray Zimmerman was at Lances that day & then shot a few images of him pulling FS Inverts on the side stairs ladder. It was pretty inspiring to watch. Afterwards, Lance asked me to refresh him on where we were at. I pointedly asked him about his actions after the 'fall' of skating in 1981.
"I was working at Variflex. I screened boards there. Skateboarding had--basically--died. They came up to me one day & said, "Congratulations. You are the new Variflex 'Pro' rider." I was like, " Rad! Out of default, I get to turn 'Pro' because the world of skateboarding is gone. What a weird world. This is 'Pro' skateboarding?! Screening boards at Variflex?!"
Well, Caballero & Stacy came by to pick me up for the 'Palmdale' Desert Ramp Battle & I ended the trip on Powell/ Peralta, making two-hundred dollars a month. I was married by then, working extra jobs, so the extra money came in handy. At that time, CR Stecyk was a huge part of Powell /Peralta & I-- immediately-- was made to feel a part of it too. They were the best. I was 19 years old at the time and Stacy had never put someone like me on the team. He had always chosen 13 year old prodigies. I heard someone said, "Why is 'Riff-Raff' on the team?" Lance laughed but I could sense a pang of angst underneath his mirth. I sat back & stretched, growing quiet. I peered over at him. "Someone called you 'Riff-Raff'?" Lance nodded in the affirmative. "Damn...."
Lance kept at it. " I told myself, "OK. I have to beat these guys at the next contest!" My last contest was Kona & I placed 11th out of ten pro riders. So, I needed to really do something. The next contest was St. Pete & I got 3rd. Upland was next, which I won." Lance sat back & crossed his arms. 'Riff-Raff' indeed! I wanted to stop there & digest what he had told me. We met again at 'Ridiculous' the next weekend. It had rained & Lance decided we should grab some lunch. We holed up in an Italian eatery & ordered homemade pizza.
"In 1984, Stacy & Stecyk made the 'Bones Brigade Video Show'. They had crafted me a part in the video. I was to be the 'thread' that wove it all together. I was over in Sweden at skate camp & Stacy phoned. He said that the video was hugely successful & there was a high demand for a 'Lance Mountain' model. Would I consider having a signature deck?" I was like, "Of course! I had always wanted my own model. You see, I rode in contests against guys like Lamar & Bowman. Yet, I wasn't them." Lance stabbed at the air with his fingers to make a point. "Brad Bowman had his name on the bottom of his board. I, did not. He and others like him, were still my heroes."
The food arrived & we ate for a while. We talked about the things that skaters discuss. Tricks. Styles. Contests. We avoided 'gossiping' like old ladies at a church function. Lance isn't like that anyway. Wiping my mouth with the back of my hand, I asked him which was better. Turning 'Pro' or getting a 'signature model'? "The 'signature model' was different from turning 'Pro'. I had entered a contest as an 'amateur' & finished the contest being turned a 'Pro'. Having a deck with my name & graphic on it was just rad!"
I went from making two-hundred dollars a month to over two-thousand dollars a month. Virtually overnight. I had a wife & a newborn son by that time so it became what it became really quickly. All of the sudden one day I was like, "Oh, you are one of the dudes after all!" It had dawned on me. I had a different perspective. Some skaters focused on winning, some focused on going the highest, some on the most money, some inventing the most tricks, some became the biggest 'stars'...I just wanted to be good at the whole thing. I'm not great at any one thing. I'm just lucky enough to be good at a bunch of little things. Yet, there is a difference between inventing & following."
I flagged down our pretty waitress & asked for more coffee. She sauntered off & I reluctantly took my eyes off her, returning to the task at hand. Lance was watching me in some amusement but said nothing. I asked him what he meant by his 'inventing & following' comment. He shrugged and answered in a matter-of-fact manner.
"In every generation there are only a few special skaters. As I said before, at one time Alva was skateboarding. Look, Steve Caballero invented a way to skate that had never been done. He moved his feet around. He invented it at 13 years old, matured it & worked hard to keep it. Before him, guys skated with their feet solid. They didn't really move their feet. Cab moved his feet all over, which allowed him to develop a new way of riding." Tony Hawk came along and at 13 years old, 'ollied' into everything, because he didn't have the power & speed of a more mature rider. He invented a modern way to do airs, opening the door for many tricks to be developed. Mark Gonzales saw the park skaters, saw what Rodney Mullin was doing--which most skaters didn't take notice of--and combined them, to become the most influential skater ever. He invented modern street skating"
"You see, I wanted it all. When you want it all, you only ever get bits & pieces. I shot photographs, wrote articles, ran a skate company, did advertisement layouts, tried to learn tricks & win contests, built ramps & parks too. Having 'bits & pieces' of it has ended up being my strength. I wouldn't trade it for the world. I was a 3rd generation skater. By the time the 'Bones Brigade Video Show' came out, we felt that we had created a 'following'. When 'Animal Chin' came out, we knew we had created something special. It was really booming."
I stuffed my notebook & digital recorder into my backpack. Lance--graciously--paid the lunch tab & we headed out into the rain. I recalled the time Lance was referring to. The Bones Brigade, Gator, Vision Street Wear, Christian Hosoi, Swatch watches, Jimmy Z clothing; the mid 1980s were a crazy time. Skateboarding seemed to be everywhere. Lance, Ray Zimmerman & I met up a few weeks later at a backyard pool. The rains had finally gone & we swept the pool out & rode for awhile. Later-- back at 'Ridiculous'-- I asked him about the mid 1980s & the Bones Brigade.
Lance took a drink of water before he answered. "The movie 'Back to the Future' had come out at the same time as 'Animal Chin'. It was a huge 'boom' for skateboarding. We were selling ten to fifteen thousand decks a month. This lasted for a year or a year and a half. You must understand, there were about twenty pro riders all sharing the industry at that time. There weren't hundreds of pro models at the time. We made a good deal of money in those days."
I pushed the recorder closer to Lance & gestured toward him--absently-- with my finger. "You must have some odd stories from touring with Powell Peralta, don't you?" Lance laughed & I could tell that it was so. These guys had seen it all! Lance said that he had a million stories but this one was so unreal, he had to tell it. Ray & I waited as Lance began. " Back then, there was so much going on. This is right when people started paying us for non-skate related things, so we took the opportunity presented. Tony & I were sent to Italy for a live TV show. We spent a week there. They sent Tony & I, two arrogant 'hacky-sackers', four roller skating dance people & a chainsaw juggler." Ray & I exploded with laughter. "Arrogant 'hacky-sackers' & a 'chainsaw juggler'...you can stop right there. That's funny in itself!" I said.
Lance was cracking up as well. "It gets better...listen." "They put us all in this hotel in a real seedy area of town. There were prostitutes & stuff all around. Around eight at night, they locked us in. We were bored silly. One evening, Tony & I were skating down the street & saw a policeman busting a prostitute in a car. I grabbed Tonys camera & took a picture. The automatic flash went 'poof' & the cop started chasing me! He threw his car in reverse & chased me down a hill. He ran up over the curb! I popped my board up & 'BOOM'...there was a machine gun pointed at me. Pssssss...! That was the first time I pissed myself since I was four years old. I've never been so scared in my life. I thought I was dead."
Lance raised an eyebrow & stated dryly, "I let the cop have the film." He laughed loudly at the memory but Ray & I were 'tripping.' That must have been pretty gnarly. Machine guns are no joke. I poured us some more cold drinks while Lance continued. " The Italian crew finally finished the ramp for us. It was built on a platform & was completely surrounded by mirrors. Mirrors everywhere! They wanted us to test the ramp. It was one layer of 1/8 inch thick 'paneling' over a metal frame, with a 2x4 for coping. No good! We told them what was needed to make it ready because this --obviously--wouldn't do."
"The next day, we arrived & were whisked off to wardrobe. We were like..."Wardrobe?!" We get in there & I immediately see two outfits & figure out what's going on. I was quicker than Tony & I raced over & grabbed the blue-colored shorts." Tony was like, "Fantastic! I get the yellow ones." We laughed. Lance then told us that they were 'see-through' plastic shorts. We were making quite a raucous. We were all laughing, picturing Tony Hawk in yellow see-through shorts.
Lance returned to the story. "Tony has no underwear. He's bumming. He finally obtains some & gets ready. We go out to the ramp. I dropped in & did a BS air. I bailed & my knee goes right through the ramp...just caved it in! Tony dropped in, did a few airs, bailed his board & broke a mirror. Done! End of show. That was it. They were over it." Ray & I looked at each other & shook our heads, chuckling. Arrogant hacky-sackers, chainsaw jugglers, cheap ramps, plastic dork shorts, machine guns.....awesome!
A few weeks later, Lance, Ray & I met up at the Pink Motel. Workers were surfacing the pool. We talked a bit & recorded some of the interview sitting on the deck. The location was not lost on me & I recalled images of Kent Senatore, Dave Ferry, Jerry Valdez & other 'Vals' riding the Pink Motel- AKA -'Fishbowl', back in the mid to late 1970s. I asked Lance about his exit from Powell/ Peralta. He sat quietly for a long minute, rubbing his eyes. It was like he was trying to collect his thoughts. I sat, watching a hummingbird nearby & said nothing.
"Stacy left Powell." He said under his breath. I picked up the recorder & placed it on the arm of his chair. He didn't seem to notice. Sitting there with his fingers laced together behind his head, Lance told me the rest of the story. "When Stacy decided it was time to move on, we left as well. We all rode for Stacy. It was like "What's next?" I didn't really leave Powell. They made decisions that made it difficult for us to skate for Powell. Stacy came to us & said, "I'm leaving. What are you going to do?" Lance looked at me rather matter-of-factly & said, "I wanted to stay in skating, be a skater, influence younger riders & continue. At Powell, I couldn't."
"In 1990 & 1991, World had the best riders. Powell didn't. Powell wanted me to start a company with them. I prayed & said, "No.". I ran it by the Lord & that was that. I then started 'The Firm' in 1991. I wanted to have Colin McKay, Ray Barbee, Eric Koston & Matt Hensley on the team. World ended up with many of them. I started 'The Firm' with Ray Barbee, Keith & Joe Gruber, Weston Correa & myself."
"When I started the company, people would ask me how "...Christian marketing was going?" I just shrugged that away. I made the right decision. I stayed committed to the Lord & his will. The entire time I ran 'The Firm', was 'character building.' It made me stronger in my faith as well."
Speaking for myself, I thought it was fairly typical of the skateboard community. I have seen & experienced it long enough. Many skaters claim to be 'individuals', yet remain terrible clones of each other. We eat our own & it eats us up. Skateboarders are not alone with such thinking. Human beings seem to fear the individual that goes to the 'beat of their own drum.'
I watched as Ray Zimmerman photographed workers finishing the Pink Motels pool surface with trowels. Somewhere, a generator growled in the distance & the mid-day sun was painfully bright. I looked back over at Lance & asked him something that I was interested to know. I knew that in all his years of riding & traveling, he has seen & participated in some insane skating moments. I wanted to know exactly what.
He thought for a few moments then responded. "I think that the day I saw Mike McGill learn 540s in Sweden, Bob Burnquist trying the Baldy pipe loop, & Alan Gelfand doing FS Ollies at Lakewood, were pretty amazing moments for me to see." I shook my head in disbelief as he reminded me of the story when Bob tried the Baldy loop. He grabbed his 'I-phone' & pulled up a photograph of Bob at 12 o'clock in the Baldy pipe...upside down. Its pretty unreal. I have been to Baldy since. You can still see his wheel marks in the dust on the ceiling of the pipe. Another level.
I asked Lance if there is anything he hasn't done on a skateboard, that he would still like to do. " Not really" he smirked. "I wanted to try the loop but got hurt. I then realized that I had wanted to 'try the loop'... not 'make the loop.' That was the difference." He told me the amazing story of David Hackett & Jeff Grosso pulling the loop on the same day! Old Dogs...?
We spoke about skateboarding & the influx of new parks. Lance remarked that the new cement parks are helping to create a new type of skateboarder. I agreed. We were seeing young riders that now had tech ability & round wall technique, combining the two. Added, is the propensity for most riders to skate padless. The new guys coming up....were destroying!
I was questioning Lance about his past & current involvement with the building of skate parks & pools. " Well, I was never in the right place at the right time. We had a 'sub-scene'. My friend 'Enrique' was older & he helped build ramps to ride. This was in 1977, in the 'Rad Ramp' days. One of the early pools that we skated, had flat bottom. When we built our wooden ramps, we put flat bottom on it. We moved it up to 'Mountain Manor', even while the skate parks were still going. I've had articles in the magazines regarding the stuff we built to skate." I scribbled side notes in my journal. Lance peered over at me, squinting in the suns glare. He continued.
"I was involved with the 'Animal Chin' ramp, Kevin Harris ramp, & numerous other projects since. California started building city parks but most of them weren't good. I am opinionated. I said, "Lets build stuff better!" Eventually, I was asked by Mike Hirsch to help with a local park. I told them that if they build a pool, I will help. I've been doing this ever since, with a great deal of learning all the 'ins & outs' & red tape."
Lance then told me about various projects. I asked him about his recent assistance with Vans 'Combi' pool. He smirked at me & I laughed in spite of myself. I already knew the scoop. Between Ray Zimmerman & I, we had covered every angle on the refurbishing before this years 'Protec' contest. I shrugged & Lance shifted in his seat. "Well, the skate park surfaces have been getting better. We didn't want any structural changes in the pool. Same pool, better surface. One day, Steve Van Doren asked about re-doing the pool. Everyone knows the story now." I nodded in assent. Indeed, the 'Combi' pool refurbishing has been lauded as a massive success story. Lance spent many long hours at the 'Combi', making sure it all went smoothly.
We gathered our things together. The sun was falling behind the huge palm trees that perch over the Pink Motel. Dogs barked in the distance & a car alarm shrieked shrilly. Lance waited for the alarm to cease & asked Ray & I if we wanted to eat, then check out a pool near his house. "Of course!" was our immediate response. Lance had driven his old 1940s British war-era motorcycle that day. We 'putt-putted' back through the San Fernando valley & took the long way to Lances house. After a quick lunch, we stopped by an overgrown estate on the other side of Pasadena. The pool was lost to us. A large yellow bulldozer hungrily tore huge gobbets out of the yard as we unhappily looked on. I turned to Ray. "Oh well, they keep destroying & we'll keep creating". I believe that whenever we drain an old pool & clean the area , we are creating. We create a positive place in a world of chaos. We set things 'right' by example. Lance has followed just such a path his entire career. He keeps things 'right' by example. He follows his beliefs & the will of the Lord. His conviction stands strong & he wavers not one iota. I am glad that Lance is the way he is. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Tom Groholski
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Even though we both skated Cherry Hill Skate Park during its heyday, Tom & I didn't really ride together until one cold winter day in 1984. I was home in Pennsylvania --on leave--from the military. Jim Howell & I were drinking beers at a pool hall late one Friday night. He looked out at the snow & windblown streets & tossed back his fourth Heineken. Placing the bottle on the table, Jim lit a cigarette & blew a bluish cloud of smoke toward the ceiling. He glanced over at me and stated, "We are going to drive to the 'Kanes' barn ramp in Basking Ridge." I shrugged, finished my brew & we grabbed our coats. That is how Jim & I did things back then. We stopped at his house, grabbed a few blankets, our skate gear & some sweaters, then drove the three hours to Basking Ridge, NJ. We arrived at about 2am. We crept inside the barn & with a flashlight, found a piece of plastic tarp. We duct taped the blankets & plastic to the flat bottom of the ramp & crawled inside.One side of the half pipe had steel coping & the other... pool coping. There were 'Zorlac- Shut Up & Skate'  & 'Vision  Street Wear' stickers everywhere. Spray paint was on the walls. Fortified by man-beverages, we fell asleep, completely stoked! When we awoke, snow had fallen & drifted through the roof shingles covering us in a thin layer. We climbed out & went to a 7-11 for coffee & a 'whores bath' in the public restroom. Later, back at the barn, 'Backwards' Bernie O'Dowd & Tom Groholski showed up. We all rode together.Tom pulled some of the raddest grinds & crail slides the entire lip of the ramp at warp speed. I was dumbfounded at his lip tricks & board control.  We made contact recently & I asked him to write a bit about his history. What Tom wrote,  stands alone as a perfect description of how things were & where he came from. Thanks- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_5602" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Tom Groholski"][/caption] "Like most kids I started skateboarding in my single digit years for fun and transportation. Skateboarding felt better than riding a bike, I think what captured me was the the glide. The act of standing and leaning and turning with the wind in my face really resonated with me. When I’m on my board, it really takes me away. It’s as if I’m in my own world. Once I discovered the heavier side (vertical bowlriding) I really got sucked in. I was fascinated by what I saw in the early 'Skateboarder' magazine. How did he get there? What did he look like in motion? Thankfully, there were a couple of sequences that helped me to understand what was going on. Coming from suburban New Jersey,  it wasn’t like there were a whole lot of skateboarders around. [caption id="attachment_5608" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Grom Tom"][/caption] A friends brother did have a Fibreflex with Bennetts and Roadrider fours. I thought that board was the coolest thing. He was the one who had the 'Skateboarder' magazine. I toyed around with various Roller Derby’s and Grentec’s trying to keep a board together. It was on a cold December day that I went with my mom to 'Grog’s Surf Palace' to pick out an early Christmas gift. Grog himself set me up with a Sims Taperkick with Tracker mids and some Parkrider fours. Grog also gave us directions to the first skateboard park that I’ve ever seen in person. The park was called “Monster Bowl” and with good reason. Seeing the park from the road was sort-of scary; it was steep, deep and covered in snow. Since the park was at the beach, mom said that we’d return when it thawed in the spring. Up until this point, a couple of neighborhood kids and I, only had a quarter pipe and some hills to get radical on. The first skatepark that I actually got to ride was called 'Fybre Ryder'. 'Fybre Ryder' consisted of blue modular transitions of varying heights and configurations. The sections were set up to make different runs. Mostly halfpipes, a fullpipe and a couple of dishes. The park was indoor/outdoor and was a whole lot better than our quarter pipe! New Jersey did have a few concrete parks that were commonly found near the shore. The first concrete park that I rode was “Off the Wall” which was probably named after the infamous shoe, since it’s design did not lend itself to any type of surf-style skating. Off the Wall (we called it “Often Fall”) was a series of lumps bumps and humps with a few pockets that bowled it all together. The park was fun since I didn’t know any better. It was where I made my  first attempts at catching some air. I would roll down a bank toward a mogul and bunny-hop my way-- to freedom-- over a block of foam from an old couch. The sky was the limit! My parents have always been more than cool about me skateboarding. [caption id="attachment_5616" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Sweeper- Groholski family ramp NJ- photo- R. Groholski"][/caption] One day my dad showed up at home with a bunch of wooden arches on top of his work van. He was driving past an old restaurant that was getting demolished when he spotted the arches. [caption id="attachment_5609" align="aligncenter" width="441" caption="Tom w sis & half pipe in his yard"][/caption] Apparently the arches were an overhang that he envisioned turning into a skateboard ramp. Little did he know that he’d be turning our backyard into a skatepark for the next fifteen years. While away at a friends house, dad and mom, (yes I said mom!) assembled the restaurant overhang into a perfect halfpipe. The ramp was eight feet wide and eight feet high right to vert. It was the first version of four ramps to take over the yard. Once I had that ramp, I spent every waking hour --when not in school-- trying to learn how to deal with the art of riding a skateboard. Back to the steep and deep inclines of Monster Bowl. I would love to go back and ride that park now. Monster Bowl was a maze of steep runs that backed up to each other and had green and red mesh fencing separating them. The novice area had two small bowls connected by a rollover. The bowl was four feet at it’s deepest and tipped out at vert. This was a bowl where a little kid could catch their first grind. Older surfers probably in their mid to late teens ruled the rest of the place. They would show us the way and kept us young ‘uns in line. Picture seventies style rippage—edgers, carve grinds, lipslides, airs, tailblocks, and a favorite of mine to see and later do was an early version of a frontside disaster. We called this version a “slap air”, and when done properly was audible across the park. There was a strong buzz going around Monster Bowl of a new “mega-park” being built in south Jersey across the river from Philadelphia. Vague details and rumors were circulating about the new 'Cherry Hill Skatepark'. The year was nineteen seventy nine and Cherry Hill was a dream come true. Four pools and a halfpipe with an over vert three quarter pipe into a bowl and a couple of bank runs. It was all indoors. This was the east coast version of what was already out west. [caption id="attachment_5611" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Cherry Hill-egg bowl- photo- R. Groholski"][/caption] For opening day at Cherry Hill, pros came from all over to celebrate and to break in the park properly. For all who witnessed the skating that day, and had partaken in what the park had to offer...for the next three short years, could not have been more profoundly affected. It was a chapter in skateboarding’s history that bridged the coasts of America. Cherry Hill changed countless lives-- including my own-- and continues to remain a high point in many skaters memories. Through the seventies to the present, I feel extremely grateful to have seen something that I love so much evolve and grow, I have to thank my family and my friends for all of their sacrifice, love, and support. It truly has been a priceless experience. --Tom Groholski [caption id="attachment_5610" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="FS 5-0 Ralphs pool, MD-- photo- D. Kane"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5612" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="'Combi' tail block on the finger. photo- Geoff Graham"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5613" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="'lien air' while Jeff Phillips watches. Arlington Tx. photo- Allen Guimond"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5617" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="BS Air Pier 62 -photo-Squindo"][/caption]

item.title: Jayboy Adams
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5629" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Omar Hassan & Jayboy Adams at 'Cholos'"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5630" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Jayboy Adams at 'Skatopia' July 1977"][/caption] Jay Adams has followed a tumultuous road in his life. Always on edge, pushing the boundaries & going before everyone else...he has led the way in 'discovery'. He has created a way of skateboarding by showing what is 'possible'. He has taken dark paths & twisted alleyways. He has delved deep into himself. He has seen his dragons... Sometimes the dragons have won & other times, Jay has overcome. The world needs Jay Adams. I am glad that he is with us. Thanks to Peter King & Jim Goodrich for the images. Skate & appreciate those like Jay Adams. Respect! -Skate-Ozzie

item.title: masks
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5635" align="aligncenter" width="400" caption="Robert Englund & his alter ego ...'Freddy Krueger'"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5636" align="aligncenter" width="436" caption="Neil Blender"][/caption] I was trimming & pruning some purple-flowered bouganvilla recently. I heard footsteps & looking up, I saw  the actor Robert Englund- AKA Freddy Krueger-walking past. I hid my surprise & said "Good Morning." He chatted briefly & then moved on with his walk. He lives in Laguna. He was quite pleasant actually. However, it did make me think. We wear masks. In our interactions with each other & the world. I once heard someone say that every human being is--actually-- three people. We are who we think we are. We are who we want people to think we are & we are who we really are 'inside'. Interesting.  Whoever stated that might have been right. I walked around for years hanging my life on a tragedy. I became  human wreckage. I let my monster win. No longer. Since I became sober, I deal with myself--and all of my fears & insecurities--so I don't have to live that way any longer. I can look people in the eye, I gain self-esteem by doing good things, being honest & keeping my 'mask' locked away. I'm finally content in my own skin. Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the Neil Blender image. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: robenglund111

item.title: Life's incomplete
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5642" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="sadness"][/caption] I was people watching again yesterday.  There was a decrepit park bench & I sat for a few moments. There was a Baptist church service going on nearby. I could hear 'clapping' & singing going on. Outside of this, I saw few smiles.A liquor store did a brisk business even at this early hour. Escape.  Oblivion. Deadened. I felt their pain, as I have been that way. People seemed downtrodden, empty. They appeared like windblown husks....devoid of life. I tried speaking & saying "Hello" to some of them. They looked at me with lifeless eyes. I had a sinking feeling of disillusionment in my fellow man.  Peoples superficiality & lack of feeling was so disgusting that I felt like crawling into a hole & neither seeing nor hearing another human being again. I thought of Nietzsche. He wrote, "He who has a 'why' to live for, can bear with almost any 'how'. Maybe people need a reason to live. Yet, some seem to get beyond that point. I remember my complete self-absorption & misery. Not a good thing. I went to my car & drove to the grocery store. A homeless man shuffled across the parking lot. He looked like a 'smudge' against the asphalt lot. Plastic bags spilled over the edge of the baby stroller he pushed which carried all his worldly possessions. Seeing him made me wince. He was truly lost & I knew that there were probably hundreds like him in this area. He looked at me & mumbled. I could smell him. He reeked like a public toilet. His teeth were missing & his eyes had yellowed with jaundice. Broken. Did he make poor choices or did life merely pass him by? Did he ever have a chance? Was he ever loved? Did God send him out into the streets like he did with 'Job'? Was God testing his faith? I hate to say it, but this man exuded little faith to me...he exuded nothing more than despair. I found myself handing him money. It was automatic...a reflex action. His eyes never met mine. He mumbled "Bless you." I turned and watched him shamble away. His baby stroller threadbare, clothing rumpled. I wondered about life. I wondered why things go the way they do. I wondered why it hurts me so much to see others suffer so. I wonder....Skate-Ozzie

item.title: return
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Tough luck. I haven't forgotten it. It is nailed into my skin daily--it seems--and some days I find it hard to go on. Golgotha. Storm clouds. I am so uncertain. Life is crippling. I gave up everything & am left with little... some books, threadbare clothing & a few faded photographs I cannot part with. My heart is sold. I seemingly wait for nothing. I neither smoke, drink nor do drugs. I haven't been out with a woman in an entire year. My last relationship was a debacle. At times, there is an ocean under my eyes. My soul is like old, cracked leather. The older I become, the less I understand. Though, there is a certain odd freedom in giving up all responsibility & expectation. My toughest daily decision is deciding what I am eating for dinner. Rice & beans or rice & beans. I am becoming quieter; my mouth is out of words. Cold... is my endless road. My life--stuck in the 'waiting room'. I am sitting at a glass & chrome table. Its surface is dull...like my senses. The sun is bleeding itself out into the ocean. I can see it growing red & darkness falls across me. I haven't been writing on 'Blue Tile' lately. It has been a tough few weeks. I looked at a few photographs recently. They were of a session in Palm Springs with Riverside Shawn, Kevin Burke, Brandon Wong, Lance Mountain, Samwise & myself. I was reminded --all too clearly--what is important. I must remember what I was & where I came from. I must stay grateful for what I have. So it is.

item.title: Motivation
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Tony Alva was an inspiration to me when I was a young 'outcast' in central Pennsylvania. I would obtain a copy of Skateboard World' and read EVERY single letter ... cover- to- cover. The magazine was my 'bible' & skateboarding my 'religion'. I would be forced to go to church every Sunday morning & night. The bible of the church had interesting stories. I liked that people lived to be 900 years old, had tons of wives, water was turned into wine, prostitutes & lepers flourished & people fought during massive bloody wars. There were even sacrifices & fires... I love fire! All-in-all, the bible was killer reading when you are forced to be there on a Sunday.
I would sit there on the mahogany wooden pews, thumbing the cabbage-colored pages of the bible. I would stare at the stained glass windows & think of skating. At Woodward, I heard a kid say, "I would rather be riding bike in the woods, looking at the beauty of nature that God created, than sitting in church thinking about my bicycle." It was that way for me. We shared the same sentiment. I liked church. I loved the pageantry & hated its punishment. Sitting there, watching the candles cast wavering shadows on the walls, I wondered--even then--if God actually hated us. Like it dawned on him--one day--what a colossal mistake he made in creating us. Rage, war, inadequacies, pure destructiveness. Maybe he would have enough & send in the Calvary. Then angels would come, carrying savage weapons. Angels- One, Humanity- Zero. God hates us? I thought he must have.
I mean, Jesus sounded pretty rad to me. You have to like a guy that teaches & feeds people. You have to love a guy that goes into a room full of 'money-lenders' & starts breaking things up with a stick or a whip.... I have often thought of going into 'Bank of America' myself & laying into a few people with a stick! I understand. Human beings are greedy, cruel & self-absorbed. I try not to be those things, but I am sure I have hit the mark from time to time.
Regardless, I would pull out my well-thumbed copy of 'Skateboard World' & stare at images of Tony Alva & others. I would place the magazine inside an opened copy of the bible & peer --urgently --at the world I wanted to be a part of.... a world so foreign to my surroundings. Pennsylvania. California. The math doesn't even add up! I taped photographs of Tony Alva, Wally Inouye & Jerry Valdez on my wall. I constantly reminded myself what I loved. Skateboarding. It was just it & me. There was no bullying. My skateboard never struck me in anger. My skateboard never 'mocked or ridiculed'. It was ALWAYS there. It provided an endless escape from the dusty country life that ran away in every direction I looked. The roads were buckled & cracked asphalt. The streets & people were old & they followed-- even-- older ideals. I could cruise my ramp & pretend. In my mind, I was with Tony Alva & Wally Inouye, skating some awesome pool. I was hanging with Tony Alva at the Long Beach arena when he kicked ass! These thoughts pulled me through the rough times. In a strange twist, I have met Tony Alva & most of my childhood heroes. I hang out with Tony Alva pretty frequently now. We are friends. He just celebrated another year of sobriety & once again....he is an inspiration & motivation for me. I love skateboarding. Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the image. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: grid
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Once the authorities caught up with gunslinger Jesse James, they asked him a few questions. One of them was as follows. "Jesse, Why do you rob banks?"  He peered at the authorities as if they were insects and answered, "Because that's where the money is." Well, why do I live in the heat of the San Bernardino area? Because, that's where the pools are.
After World War II,  Kaiser Steel flourished in this area along with many other industries. Kaiser Steel had done really well by building the 'Liberty' ships, which the Allies utilized to storm Europe & finally end Adolf Hitlers failed bid for global conquest. The San Bernardino area was filled up with neighborhoods & housing for the many families that flocked to the 'Golden Dream'. The area scorches in the summertime, with temperatures regularly spiking over 100 degrees. Unlike the coastal communities, this area has room to spread out. The area is vast. People don't live on top of one another.
In the 1950s & 1960s, the contractors built homes on area lots which were larger. The more spacious yards allowed for larger pools. Sprawling four bedroom houses, with great green palm trees hanging overhead, spread out into the distant foothills. The snow-covered mountain town of Big Bear, towers over all in the distance. It was idyllic for the families looking for a start.
The oil crunch of the 1970s, job losses, foreclosures, mass-exodus, poverty, ignorance & all that goes with it, fell across the San Bernardino area like a wool blanket. The neighborhoods dried up after the jobs & it all got 'kicked sideways'. There are areas out here that still remain pretty nice. One can drive around & still see lush lawns, purple bouganvilla & sidewalks drowning in flowers.
Yet, four blocks away, spattered unintelligible graffiti covers old liquor stores. There are wrought iron bars on --virtually--every window. Drug dealers do a brisk business selling misery to all comers. Alleyways reek of urine, booze, and needles & condoms are scattered about. Trash & rubble are the norm. Pathological people & disease. The ugliness of humanity pervades. In this hothouse of broken life, we wander. The grid is there for us. We hunt systematically. We drive alleys, looking through splintered fences & over crumbling concrete walls. We find 'abandoned dreams' & turn them around. We create a 'positive' from such negativity. Skate-Ozzie
Reply
Forward

item.title: disorder
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5691" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Buddy Nichols"][/caption] It is getting to be 'fire season' here in Southern California. In 2003, the area --where I live-- lost over 1500 homes to wildfires, that ravaged down from the Angeles National Forest. At the time, I drove out & met up with Salba. We couldn't even get to the neighborhoods. The police had shut the area down. When we could drive the grid, I was appalled. I saw people wandering bewildered through their properties. I saw melted cars.....melted! I swear. I saw dead animals, charred roof timbers sticking up out of swimming pools. I saw blistered rubble & the chemical stench of cooked possessions, lingered for long months afterward. At some places, the pools were lost under rubble or filled with peoples things. It seemed like they threw these items into the pool in a sad effort to prevent their destruction. As much as I knew we would reap the benefit from peoples loss & misery...I felt a sense of terrible loss. In retrospect, some of these folks never came back or rebuilt. A lifetime of work & dreams...gone in one 'fire season'. Lets hope that the fires stay away & people are careful this year. I have enough pools to ride. Thanks to Geoff Graham for the image. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Buckys BargeBQ
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Stark trees & brooding skies. Cold. Bone cold. I think it was in November of 1990. I knew Bucky from the 'Hell Ramp' in Chesapeake, but I only saw him --irregularly-- around the various vert ramps that dotted the Eastern seaboard. It had been raining in Pennsylvania for three days. The roads were frozen, glassy & treacherous. I didn't care. I loaded up the Datsun & drove out into the night. I made my way to 'Cheapskates' indoor skate park about two hours away.
When I arrived, I crept slowly into the rutted dirt lot. There were a number of cars there. I was stoked to get inside & ride vert. I hoped Sean Miller, Tom Boyle or Darren Menditto would be there. As I walked toward the front door, I heard heavy 'bass' thudding from an approaching car. I turned. It was low- slung and glimmering. The stereo was so loud that the panels of the car vibrated. It was a Honda of some sort, but tricked out with ground effects & unique painting. It looked like a brand new penny. I thought, "Christ! That car is clean, considering the weather..."
When it pulled up, Bucky got out & went quickly inside. Always friendly, he smiled & asked if I was going to skate. I was stoked. "Hell yeah!" It was going to be a great session now. Later, on the deck of the vert ramp, Bucky told me that he was working on cars, detailing and such. Such was the state of skateboarding then. I remember being dumbfounded that such an amazing talent as Bucky Lasek, had to go to such lengths to make ends meet.
The reason I relate this anecdote, is to show how far he has come. Make no mistake, Bucky has done well for himself. Through hard work, discipline & sacrifice, he has remained an innovative force & an example to all skaters around the world. Having had 'California Skateparks' build his backyard bowl, he has--once again--raised the bar on what is 'possible' in vertical skateboarding. Once you witness Bucky ride his pool, it is clearly evident his abilities are a stretch above those around him.
This year Bucky-- again--decided to host the Bucky Bowl BBQ. Anticipation was high. He put the word out & his sponsors responded positively. Long time sponsor-- Billabong--threw down & really came through for him. Other sponsors: Vans, Rockstar, Element, Mophie, Longboard Ice Cream, Kona Brewery, Wave House, Fred Water, Fydelity, Wasserman, K1 Speed, and Bioserie.com, didn't disappoint. Bucky is grateful for their full support & encouragement. He thanks them here.
I had come down to Buckys that morning early. There were trucks unloading gear, people milling about & the general air of a carnival prevailed. Banners fluttered around the place & tents were set up. I signed the standard 'release' forms & wandered up to the bowl. Its quite large. I have ridden it before. When I pulled an air in it, I felt like I had just consumed three 'Rockstar' energy drinks. It was exhilarating!
I saw Bucky. He was wearing a lime green Billabong shirt & appeared cool as usual. I've never seen him stressed. He is always chill & friendly. I was quickly put to work helping Paul Wisniewski, & Josh Nelson put sponsor stickers around the top surface of the pool. It takes a bit of finesse & the sun hammered down on us. We eventually finished with help from Steve Caballero who showed up & jumped in to lend a hand. The Vans crew set up their tent to cook burgers & Steve Van Doren & Christy were smiling & happy as usual.
People started pouring into the place around noon. The deck grew crowded as riders started throwing down. Bucky had worked out a few 'games' for the event. He had slalom cones to tape up around the bowl for a 'timed' carving slalom race.I helped him string a 'cowbell' up into a palm tree hanging a few feet above the hip. The object being that when a skater hit the bell & rang it, that rider would get some cash & the bell would be raised higher. We barely had it tied up there when 'Cookiehead' nailed it. Bucky looked over at me with a raised eyebrow & said dryly, "Guess we gotta raise that thing already."
We hustled about, filling drink coolers with ice & drinks as people 'hooted' & yelled for the skaters ripping the bowl. There isn't enough room to list all of the skateboarders that were there. Let it suffice to say that it was a 'Who's Who' of skateboarding legends & current heroes. It became so crowded with riders, families, kids & spectators, that it seemed like everyone in San Diego 'barged' Buckys that day. It really was something. Bucky started the 'Slalom' contest. Astorga flew, Christian Hosoi was close on his heels & Zach Miller was keeping up as well. In the end, it was 1-Hosoi,2- Astorga, & 3-Z.Miller .
Paul Schmitt had made a customized BBQ board for Bucky & the event. It was an actual 'working' grill with trucks, wheels & all. Bucky singed his leg hairs as he smoked a blistering grind on his custom designed BBQ board. The skateboard is amazing & Paul Schmitt is indeed a 'mad professor'.
After this, Bucky decided to have a 'longest grind' contest on the 'Golden State' coping. Judges were placed & everyone hit the switch. Bucky had one rule. No 50-50s. Brad McClain had flat-spotted wheels & went further & longer than most. He ended up 2nd. Pedro Barros crushed it & ended a FS 5-0 into 3rd. Steve Caballero was on fire. He ended the contest with a 'No Joke', 13 block long 5-0 grind & he smiled as Bucky 'showed him the money'.
I saw smiling faces everywhere. I saw Jay Adams & Dennis Martinez. I saw a 'bleary-eyed' Darren Navarette sitting on the deck. He smirked at me & said, "It was a long night after the 'Rumble in Ramona'. But, Bucky showed at the 'Rumble'. I am here supporting his deal." 'Navs' rules. During the 'slalom' contest, I saw 'Papa Miller' giving Zach a few hurried bits of advice. I saw happiness, old friends, stoke & skateboarding. I saw the definition of all things that are 'rad'. Once again, Bucky pulled off a 'one-of-a-kind' event. People skated until it was too dark to see. Not one person wanted the day to end! Everyone that came together, witnessed great skateboarding, camaraderie & fun. This is the reason we all started skateboarding in the first place. Bucky asked everyone to bring some canned goods for a 'food drive. He later told me, "We collected 1,059 pounds of food, which converts to the equivalent of 827 meals." Well done people. Well done!
Thanks to all the great sponsors that helped support the event. Thanks to Bucky & Jen for putting us all in the 'loop' for the day. Thanks to MRZ for the images, and thanks to everyone that came out. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: The counter 'culture'
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5714" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Hermann Goering. "Lick my arse""][/caption]   As most people know, the Nazi party leaders stole massive amounts of art during World War II. At the Nuremberg trials, the strutting, corpulent leader of the Nazi Luftwaffe--Hermann Goering--stated, "The confiscation of art had nothing to do with 'culture'. When I hear the word 'culture'...I reach for my revolver." Thus, one of the grand villains of art 'plundering' throughout Europe, defended himself to the world. This is also the same man who stated categorically that he wanted his 'defense' restricted to three words. "Lick my arse." I guess I can never understand such a monster. I suppose that its easier to believe that the best part of Hermann Goering, ran down his  moms' leg at the point of conception. He never received the 'good things' that make a human whole. Empathy. Emotion. The whole debacle is a sad chapter in history. Back in 1975, when Wes Humpston began --what he called--'doodling' on the hand -cut wooden skateboard decks of the Zboys, he started something. With those 'Sharpies', he created an idea that we-- as skateboarders--could have our own 'thing'. We could have our own 'art'. Its a skaters 'interpretation' of things. Our art. This thing he created 'identified' us as skaters. Other skaters took hold of that banner & carried it forward. They developed it further. Some branched off. Others paved a completely different pathway. Skateboarders wouldn't allow themselves to follow the established 'norms' of society & art. It is simply not in our nature to do so. Another monster from World War II--Adolf Hitler-- made the following public statement at a gallery opening in 1937. "I have observed among the pictures submitted here, quite a few paintings which make one actually come to the conclusion that the eye shows things differently to certain human beings than the way they really are, that is, that there really are men who see the present population of our nation only as rotten cretins; who, on principle, see meadows blue, skies green, clouds sulphur yellow, and so on—or, as they say, experience them as such. I do not want to enter into an argument here about the question of whether the persons concerned really do or do not see or feel in such a way, but in the name of the German people, I want to forbid these pitiful misfortunates who quite obviously suffer from an eye disease, to try vehemently to foist these products of their misinterpretation upon the age we live in, or even to wish to present them as “Art.” History seems to have judged both Adolf & Hermann to be quite wrong in their beliefs. I am thankful for that. I suppose that 'art' is truly representative of the artists perception. What the 'observer' makes of it is what makes it a beautiful thing. I happen to like green skies & blue grass.  I love a differing point of view. I stand on my head sometimes just to see what the world looks like from down there! Skateboarding has a fair number of great artists. Skateboarders are creative people as a whole. Many of us are isolative, driven & introspective. The 'Love & Guts' art show was to come to Redlands. Ben Bridgers contacted me a few weeks back & asked if a few people could come by 'Ridiculous' the day of the show for a skate session. We set it up & worked out the details. I was stoked. I think that anytime we can get skaters 'together' & in the same pool session...its a good thing. The day before, Ray & I had driven the grid on a pool search. We came back to the house, patched a few problem spots in the pool & cleaned up the grill. BBQ time. Everyone from the local crew came by on Saturday & skated. The 'Love & Guts' artists & pals stopped by. A  loud, boisterous session ensued. Josh Borden & Dave Reul tore it up.Upland Dan, Michael Serna & Billy blazed. Mike Perez floated over the side stairs. Tristan & Papa Rennie cruised effortlessly. Lance killed it, Pat Ngoho pulled rock-n-roll boardslides forever. Kevin Burke was on fire, Scott Cooper pulled a 15 wall line, Brandon Wong couldn't be stopped, Michael Burnett, MRZ & BLKPRJKT all rode side-by-side. Once, I looked over & nudged Lance. I pointed toward the shallow stairs. All the major photographers were there...riding. Skin Phillips was perched up on the roof. He was a constant blur of activity all day, poolside. In the end, hotdogs & burgers were cooked, grinds & tricks were done, vibes were perfect & ego stayed away. We all drove to the "Love & Guts' show at dusk. A caravan. Sweating & tired. Pleased. Beyond stoked. The buildings at the University were massive. Sprawling lawns. Cyclopean stones. Fluted marble columns holding up the ceilings. The doors to the gallery were open. I saw 'Independent' shirts. I saw SSC in the house. I saw 'our people'. Inside, the walls were lined with images, paintings & drawings. Mixed media & sculpture were represented as well. Color. Passion. Freedom. It was all there for everyone to admire. There was a 'question & answer' panel. The artists discussed the 'commercialization' & packaging of skateboarding to the mainstream. They spoke with regard to the direction of the sport & its meaning for each of them. It was an awesome display & I am inept at describing the art that I saw. I have my feelings & favorites. These thoughts will remain mine alone. This is the art experience for me. Thanks to MRZ for the images & everyone involved. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Weaver's Needle Hike
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I took it after hiking to Weavers Needle near Apache Jinction. We were on the way back to the car as the sun was going down. As you can see we were cutting it pretty close on time. Sun goes down early in late November. Kathy really likes this one.
