item.title: Arizona
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: In the mid 1980s, I was in the military & had a friend that lived in Paradise Valley. We flew over to Phoenix periodically & stayed at his parents house. They had this really sweet little right-hand kidney in the backyard. It was really hot there and--unfortunately--the pool stayed full, but I always noticed that --virtually--every house seemed to have a pool. I met Chris Livingston in San Diego, when I lived down there with Andy Mac, Rhino & Preston. I was director at the Mission Valley YMCA skate park & 'Livi' would come over & ride the vert ramp. We had more than a few good sessions there. We lost track of each other but the other weekend, I saw him at the 'Rumble in Ramona'. He had been living in Arizona & riding pools. He told me that pools were all he wanted to ride. I was stoked. It turns out that 'Livi' had been reading 'Blue Tile' & I asked him if he wanted to write up a 'guest post' on the Arizona pool scene. He agreed & this is the end product. I will be going soon, to visit 'Livi' in Arizona & am hoping to ride with the various backyard crews that reside there. Respect to my pool pals- Ozzie AZ REPRESENT [caption id="attachment_5754" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Chris Livingston- crail "][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5756" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Wrex Cook "][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5767" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Chris Kelley"][/caption] Arizona, the Wild West and the home of the burning sun.  The state where in nature only snakes, scorpions, desert tortoises and other creatures with the  spirit of a  loner exist.  The scorching heat forces animals underground where the temps are cooler than the searing 115+ degree temperatures outside.  People retreat to their air conditioned nightmare of an existence or their swimming pools filled with chlorinated relief.  Except for us.  Skateboarders search endlessly through the foreclosed dreams of others to create our own dreams in these empty pits where animals fall in to be cooked to an early demise.  Fueled by a desire to express and confront our own fear and limits, skaters risk heat stroke, melanomas and complete physical discomfort to ride the seemingly endless pits that abound. [caption id="attachment_5762" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Josh Heath"][/caption] AZ pools are known by outsiders as shitty, tight and kinky holes that are unfit for skating, but we do not know any better.  We have learned to appreciate the challenge of these smaller pools available to not only the well-off, but the majority.  This is why they are so challenging to ride, because even a small house on a small lot will squeeze one in the yard to help convince the inhabitants that living in the middle of the desert is not really so bad.  Like the snakes who have adapted with scales and cold blood, we have learned to love these tight trannies and meatloaf lips as a means of LIVING, not merely surviving.  Not to say that we do not find our desert gems.  They are rare, but when they do pop up they are as cherished as a flawless diamond.  Cared for and protected as our own. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Hoss Rogers- 1976"][/caption] There have been numerous gems throughout the years.  Back in the early '80's when I started skating, there was the notorious “Deadcat” pool which is now AZ skatelore.  It was sessioned by AZ legends such as Brian Brannon, Sam Esmoer, Hoss Rogers and many more.  These are some of our founding fathers, to which we all owe our appreciation for paving the way for later generations.  Every town and city has had its share of classic pits, such as the Chandler bowl, the Airport pool, the Amoeba,  the Veggie and on and on...  One epic pool that stands out in my mind from the late '80's was the Eightball.  In the beginning of Phoenix's urban sprawl, State Route 51 was connecting central phoenix to what is now North Phoenix.  The city bought whole neighborhoods in order to make way for the new highway.  There were at least 25 skateable pools in this area, but the one gem was the eightball.  It was shredded by many locals and traveling skaters including Salba (of course), Bill Danforth, Allen Midgett, Shag, Wrex, Colby, Colvin, Jimmy Moore and many more.  The saga continues now as the economic downturn and the over speculation of this city's growth has left over 200,000 homes foreclosed.  This means our work is cut out for us to sift through all of the cancered, jacked pits to find the gems that are out there.  Pools that would have sufficed at one time are sessioned once then its time to keep searching for Chin.  They are out there and the AZ crews are working day and night to uncover these desert oases. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="'Scabs'"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5763" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Jesse Galvan"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5764" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Rob Locker"][/caption] As with any city with a thriving skate scene and warm summers, AZ has its own crews of OG hardcore pool skaters who would rather search out possibilities on google earth or by scouring alleys and older neighborhoods than give in to the caged skateparks which are mere representations of the REAL thing oftentimes available across the street in the run down, stripped down dreams of yesteryear.  These “private parks” allow sessions with just the homies without all of the kids at the local park.  We can drink adult beverages and  have the intimacy of an old school “private sesh”, where the energy culminates and hypes everyone up to push their limits.  Mostly over 30 with full time jobs and families to take care of, these crews do not look for notoriety or any type of approval for what they do other than the intrinsic reward that is found with a light box, box light, shallow stair or any other of the endless potential possibilities available to them through their creative transformation of these previously mosquito infested wastelands.  That is the spirit of skateboarders everywhere and this is Arizona's manifestation.  From the Pool Dust crew to the Scabs to the West Side Oilers and all the “Swiss” who remain neutral, there are many die hard rippers that make up the underground AZ pool scene and truly Skate to Live and Live to Skate.  My respect goes out to you all.  As skate legend Eddie Elguera once put it,”Carve, grind, slash – very good, have a drink.”  Cheers!   - Livi [caption id="attachment_5769" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Wez- taking Eddie Elgueras advice"][/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Luis"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5761" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Hoss Rogers"][/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Wez Lundry"][/caption] ."Find your own and do your own thing.  You show me yours and I'll show you mine."  - Wez Lundry [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Colby- BS D"][/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Court"][/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Jason Schooley"][/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Chris Gobber"][/caption] "I've been skateboarding 27 years and have never seen a place where you can pick and choose from so many pools. Stoked to live in AZ!"- Chris Gobber [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Baker"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5734" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Hoss, Wez & Colby- Halloween 2009"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5737" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Livi- FS 5-0 wedding cake"][/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Ben Dixon"][/caption] [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="412" caption="'Dagger Shane' passes the torch to his son 'Rayce'"][/caption]  [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Rayce"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5768" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="J. Baiz"][/caption] Photographs courtesy of the following: Colby and Hoss (new) by Wez Wez, Livi & Luis by Hammeke Jesse, Dixon, Wolfie and Court by J. Baiz Rob Locker by MRZ Chris Kelley by Tom Conley Wrex by Kelly Baker " There are many other AZ pool rulers who I was unable to get photos of, but deserve a mention, as they have helped to create and make the AZ scene what it is - pure, raw skateboarding with no goals or agendas other than pushing themselves and each other to seek and destroy.  Namely, Jimmy Moore, Shag, Colvin, Sam Esmoer, Gavin Troy, Cody Boat, Ben Wixon, Shawn Dutton(RIP), Punker Matt and all the others out there bailing sludge and grinding pits daily... "- Chris Livingston

item.title: Blue
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: A few months ago, Salba dropped this beauty on us. We will call it 'Blue'. He had found it early in the summer and kept a sharp eye on the property. The pool had been empty but the house lived in. As soon as the people fled into the night, we pounced. Foreclosure. The pool was slippery & it needed a CLR wash down. Once we cleaned it up, the pool turned out to be amazing. We first followed our time-tested rule of 15 minutes. We had three sessions there in as many weekends without a problem. On the fourth session, a guy showed up & caught us unawares. He was with three friends & just asked us to leave. He said that he had bought the house & was moving in the next weekend. We explained that we were just skating, because he acted like he thought we were vandals. He was eyeballing us pretty suspiciously. We took a run or two & they all relaxed & seemed to chill. They even were stoking a bit that we could skate like we did. We left & made it back once more before it was filled with water. Peter King took some of these images & the rest were taken by me on my original recon with Samwise. I hope you like the stoke. Thanks to Peter King for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Green Issue
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5784" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Paul- '8-Ball pool' Phoenix AZ 1990"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5789" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption=" 'Green Issue' showing Haiti some love."][/caption]
“If you don't stand for something you will fall for anything.”- Malcolm X .
Paul Wisniewski started 'Green Issue' in 2007. The impetus to start doing something different came from seeing the way skateboarding was being served & represented.  Paul developed a dislike for corporate skateboarding. He wanted to 'stand up' for something. He wanted to care & give back. "It's about what the individual is into. I wanted to kick people in the ass!  I wanted to say, "Do your own thing." It takes courage to stand up for something, especially if its against the 'norms' of skating. I designed a graphic for a 'Haiti relief' T-shirt.  It was the very first product we sold and we gave all of the proceeds to them.  We ended up donating 500 dollars with the Haiti shirt. It went to the Red Cross--every single dime. Another thing. Almost every magazine posted photographs of that shirt or its graphic. The ASR  trade show was right after & this guy comes in to clean after the one day.  It turns out that he was from Haiti. He lost 90% of his family....I gave him one of the shirts & he was jazzed... It felt good to know that I helped. It felt good to know that I was on the right path." Paul has been pursuing just such a path with 'Green Issue'.  Its mandate is for the individual to forge their own way & 'stand for something'. We can make the world better only if we care. Skate- Ozzie
Check out Green Issue here: http://www.greenissue.com/GI/

item.title: 'Jakes'
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Sometimes the rumor mill grinds along on a 'time-factor' all its own. "Time set for rewind." A few months back, the rumor- mill sent me a message that there was a new pool in Los Angeles. New. Virgin. Untamed & untrammeled. It was a big fat 'Blue Haven' Rossmore kidney. You see, I share sometimes. I network. I have needs & these needs have nothing to do with females & sex. Its a deeper need. Concrete & coping. Lifeblood. These are things women won't understand. It went like this. One of my old pool pals sent me a text with an address. It stated simply. "You will want to go here." I trust this mans judgment. Back in the mid 1990s, we hit a few pools in Compton with this gentleman. He kept things 'legit'. We shouldn't have been there & a few of the locals looked unhappy with our presence that day. He spoke with them & we rolled away...unscathed. When he sent me the text, I knew it would be good. I visited the pool on a Saturday evening at dusk. I didn't even bring my skateboard. I do this periodically. Recon-mode. The pool looked unreal & I shot two views with my camera, scoped the neighbors yards & rolled out. I came back with Ray Zimmerman & Lance Mountain the next day. A friend from Australia came as well: Tony Jones. He wanted to shoot some pics & video as he was flying back to his native land the next day. We all swept the pool & hit it hard. Lance & I were the only ones riding. The trannies were great & the shallow cup gave us massive torque for the face wall. We raced for the deathbox. There were no grind marks over it & we knew that one of us would get it. Lance sailed across it pretty quickly but stepped off coming in. I think he was being gracious. When I bailed my next attempt, Lance made his. He grinned & told me that I might want to go a bit wider on the left wall before I cut up towards the box. I nodded, took a deep breath & hit it clean. I was stoked! We pulled airs & grinds. Lance did fastplants, inverts & everything else he wanted....he's Lance Mountain! Lance had to leave & once he was gone, we drank water & talked about the way he dissected the pool. Amazing. My pal John Zask came by. I had asked him if he wanted to ride. John & I rode for another 30 minutes. It was so fun. The next week, Brandon told me that he hit the pool with the guy who originally bucketed it. His name is Jake. When Jake heard that I was there with Lance, Ray, Tony & John, he became anxious. He didn't want the pool 'blown out'. It was kind- of funny. I thought, "My god! This is ME! I don't 'blow out' pools...." It all turned out cool. I spoke with him & he knew the deal. I never went back actually. I invited Jake out to 'Ridiculous' & we will ride soon. I love my pool pals. Thanks to MRZ & Brandon Wong for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: monster revisited
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5821" align="aligncenter" width="400" caption="monster"][/caption] She kept on screaming & it came to him then.  The feeling. That was when he started hitting her...hard! "Shhhhhh..." he murmured. There was little noise coming from the girl now. She was finally quiet; her eyes like wet marbles- staring at nothing. All life gone. No more tomorrow. Nothing left to scream about. He smirked & wiped his forehead with the back of his scarred hand. "Where have all the good ones gone to?" he asked himself. He remembered 'good girls'....friends from the past. He recalled friends in a vague sort-of fashion. They were there in his mind, like smudges of dirt on his jeans. Bending over the sprawling girl, he kissed her mouth. Her lips tasted like rotten bananas. Her hair spilled over the rumpled sheets and onto the carpet. He felt an odd sense of unreality as he grabbed the dead girl by her foot, pulling her to slip onto the floor in a heap. Showering, he rinsed her shame & sweat off of him. He was brighter. The avenger. His skin glowed as her pain & misery swirled down the drain like soap scum. He smiled & whistled through the scalding water. It mattered little to him that she had fought his advances. She begged & tried to please. He remembered her then as a vivid image in his minds eye. Hopeless, wrists zip-tied, snot-faced & eyes red-rimmed. A shining destiny was not to be hers. He knew that was just the way 'they' worked. Women. Love. The great lie. He flexed & stretched his muscles as he toweled & got dressed. Feeling like metal, he ran an experienced eye over the girls corpse. Her hair almost covered her face & blood was clotted in it. Her nose was barely recognizable for what it once had been. Poor thing. He had told her to be quiet. He parted the dusty blinds & peered out into the evening. He was sated. He knew that the power he felt surging through his blood would soon diminish. He felt like there was some insane new nitrous fuel burning up his spinal cord. He was lethal & the world better watch itself! He also knew that the immense satisfaction he was now experiencing would soon give way to an emptiness that only one of his 'kind' can feel. No drug on earth could help fill that void. In time, he would need another. The feeling would come again. "Madness" ...some say. He absently kicked at the girls arm with his shoe. Inside, he felt nothing.  She was certainly beyond any feeling. He glanced outside again. A siren screamed & he knew that someone had bled somewhere else as well. He mumbled to himself. "Look at the world & tell me the pleasures of sanity." His voice was a broken sump pump, spewing silt & muddy water.  He was hungry. After a last look back, he closed the door behind him. He prowled the streets like a stalking panther. The night & neon parted before him. He was a part of the inky blackness & fear that followed. His stride was deliberate & the sound of his footsteps sounded hollow & hellish. He glanced to the left & saw a chain link fence. It reminded him of his previous hunger. Metal. Rust. Separation.The dividing line. His brain bubbled like a cauldron. His thoughts ran in every direction like ants. He squirmed inside his clothing.  He found a diner on the next corner. The gnawing inside of him had to be squelched. Was it his head or his gut? Sometimes, he wasn't sure the cause. He would eat & see if it subsided. Clenching his fingers, he peered inside. A few people were hunched over plates of half-eaten food or steaming mugs of coffee. A waitress looked through the window at him expectantly. Dark hair spilled over her shoulders & her mouth was a wet, crimson gash of unexplored mystery. He pulled the door open & smiled at her. Epilogue- I know that this is horrible. I was told the details of this story by a mentally ill man when I worked on a 'Crisis Unit' of a Psychiatric facility. He was a diagnosed 'Sociopath' & his reported behaviors & subsequent incarceration allow me little comfort. If it's true, then there are- indeed- monsters among us. I reported his story 'word-for-word' to the physicians & authorities at the facility. It leaves me in wonder... How do people become this way? It defies logic. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Saint Raphael Pool- Montreal
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5848" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Saint Raphael Motel- Montreal"][/caption]
Back in the 1950's,  they built this motel on the main highway just as you entered Montreal. As kids skating in the 80's, we always kept a keen eye on it , wondering if it would ever be empty.  "It would be so cool if...." As time went on, the motel  started going downhill. The clientele was becoming worse and worse. I remember going there in the early 90's. I was at the bar & it was pretty scummy. At that point, I was not even skating and the pool was out of my mind. I was too busy running with the wrong crowd, getting high & selling drugs. By the year 2000, the place had been sold a few times. They eventually sold it over  to the Knights Inn motel chain. At that point, the place was a real dump.  Quote from 'trip advisor': "The warped floors in this Motel are covered by the UGLIEST carpet you will EVER see. Bring your own towels, because if you take the "weekly special" this means they DON'T clean your room and you don't get a change of towels. But you save 10 bucks." Unquote. The whole back section was actually rented out to hookers.  People would drive up and go inside to bang a prostitute. Cars would come and go. The bankruptcy guy was telling me that before it went 'tits -up',  he was working with the owner, to make sure he was not doing cash deals and all the income was going to the bank. He told me that he saw these big Mercedes pull up. A businessman would rent a room for lunch, bang his secretary and then leave. Its days were numbered. So, one day we drove by & it was boarded up . I phoned my friends Marc and Eric and we went to check it out.
  [caption id="attachment_5850" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="done in the slum"][/caption]  
[caption id="attachment_5852" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="when does Montreal thaw?"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5853" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="reminds me of Pennsylvania...minus the kidney pool."][/caption]
This pool is huge... 51 feet from end to end. It was filled 3/4 with water.The next week, I went and pumped it out for 6 hours alone. Later, my friend Marc joined me and we rode it for the first time. We were so damn stoked! At this point, only 3 people knew about it & we were scared to get busted, as it was so close to the busy street. I went on the internet to see who owned the property. Then,  I could 'bullshit' my way if the cops showed up. As time went on, I became braver. I went during one afternoon. This guy pulled up and said in French, "qu'est que tu fait la?" I replied in French, "I am skating the pool. I know the owner 'Jay Raaz'. He said it's alright if I skate." The guy replied,  "Well Jay Raaz does not own it anymore. I am working for the bankruptcy firm & you're not allowed to be here." I stood my ground.  "Look, I am 40 years old ( to his surprise ). I am not going to sue anyone if I get hurt. I have insurance etc. etc. etc. I own a garage down the street. If you're cool with me skating, I will fix your car for cheap."  I gave him my business card and he was cool . He told me that he wouldn't call the police. The next Saturday, we (8 of us) were there & the cops showed up. They were not happy. I told them that "I am allowed to be here, the owner is my friend & gave me permission." Once they checked my story & found it true, they were cool.
[caption id="attachment_5855" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="'To protect & serve'"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5856" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Kevin....working."][/caption]
[caption id="attachment_5858" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="the crew...holding it down."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5859" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Marc Tison"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5861" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Marc Tison"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5862" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Kevin Cann"][/caption]
The pool is still here a year later. It has cracks that we patched. We've pumped it  out many times. It is a cool place, but the work involved is killer. There is so much water to be pumped out constantly.So, that is the story of the 'St-Raphael'. It was a sign of the times , built in the hey-day of Montreal, when this town was booming. Now, its a decaying building; an era gone by. It must have been fun in its day... heated pool and all. The perfect family vacation stop in the big city. Now, it's just a distant memory. For me, I feel sad. It's in my old neighborhood. The scene has changed & the people and faces I remember growing up ...where are they now?  I look back when we were kids skating. Now, there are only a handful left. I am sitting here,  just wondering & thinking. Nothing brings people together like skateboarding... so unique & so special.
I cherish every moment I ride .
Kevin
.

item.title: Squalor
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Summer had faded into Fall & this in turn led us directly to rain. It rained & rained. Le deluge. I ran a pool pump into the grave that winter... along with innumerable feet of fire hose. It was an unending mud puddle. Salba & I were driving back to the house after a draining mission & he quickly pulled the truck over to the side of the road. He was peering towards his left & I couldn't see what had-- evidently --caught his interest. I was in 'scan mode' & my eyes raked the adjoining houses & cars...I was on point. He mumbled something (as he oftentimes does) about squatters, meth & condemned buildings. "Go check over that wall, Ozzie." Salba said out of the side of his mouth. He was pointing to a completely boarded up 'mess' off in the distance. I made my way over a small concrete wall that was buckled & broken. Tires & rubbish littered the area. I was hyper-alert...every nerve alive as I approached the house. Looters & squatters had tore the Hell out of the place...what was left of it. I peered around for signs of dogs. I listened intently. The roof was open in spots & rain dripped from the ceiling tiles. I smelled piss & sweat. I saw slimy condoms & syringes. I saw horror & decay. Human degradation. Prostitution. Addiction. A future denied. I scouted the house for 'threats' & went back outside. I pulled myself up over a block wall. The pool was a big capsule. Salba had known about it for ten years, he later told me. He said that he had found it on a helicopter ride one time. It was full of black water & refuse. It stank. There were broken liquor & beer bottles & a wave of multi-colored glass was thick against the walls. It looked like the floor of a glass factory. Damn! Eventually, Samwise & I would go there & drain it three times. We rode it once then sat on it. Each time we wanted to ride it again, squatters & their ilk would vibe us hard & we'd get 'shut'. The neighborhood was bad & we always 'posted' someone upon the wall to keep an eye open. Sometimes we gotta stay 'frosty'. Samwise & I drained it & we hit it this summer. Summer never looks the same where we live. Things come & go. The crew changes & always....we hunt for the coveted backyard 'plaster'. THAT is the only 'constant' in a mad, mad world. Thanks to PK, Brandon Wong & Samwise for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: 'Against The Grain'
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5874" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Against The Grain"][/caption] 'Against The Grain'  art show was held last night at "Gasoline' in El Segundo. The Vans 'womens' Combi contest was barely over & we quickly found ourselves hurtling through traffic to get up to the art show on time. Arriving, we saw Steve Caballero standing by the front door & people milling about on the sidewalks. It was 'packed' inside. There was a full house & a good vibe abounded. The owner of the gallery had approached Steve Caballero about 'co-curating' an exhibition as Steve knew many skateboard artists & other artists as well. Steve accepted & the resulting show was an awesome display of varying themes. The idea of the art show, was to showcase a few artists & their work; artists that utilized the skateboard deck as their 'canvas'. Steve explained to me, " Low brow artists & others rarely use a skateboard deck as a 'canvas'.  Using a deck is much easier sometimes because its flat & there are size limitations. This show gave them an opportunity to use a different 'canvas' & express themselves. Art is art. It was actually good for them to utilize this different medium." The walls were covered floor-to-ceiling with skateboard decks but what really struck me, was the fact that the art represented there, over-shadowed the thing that they were expressed upon. I didn't really 'see' that this was art on a skateboard deck...it transcended it. It was simply ... beauty. The artwork was done so uniquely, that the skateboard decks themselves became a 'non-issue'. It was really something to see. I am not an artist, nor would I offer myself up as a critic of any sort. I look at things & try to see what the artist was attempting to express. I wonder at the 'motivation'...the human behavior & what is behind it. If one wants to know an artist, one has to examine their work. Steve Caballero told me that, "An artist has to stay psyched & focused when working on a piece. It comes from the heart & it takes time & energy to produce it. It always comes from inside." We visited some amazing artists & their 'vision' last evening. I feel that we are the better for it. Steve Caballero wishes to thank Mark Waldman & all of the artists who contributed to the show.Thanks to MRZ for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: 'You've come a long way, baby!'
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5907" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="This one is for the ladies."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5885" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Leilani Kiyabu- Newark 1978"][/caption] Vans really knows how to 'put their money where their mouth is'.  These days, most people have that age-old problem of their mouth getting the 'talking' part done. However, there rarely seems to be much 'follow through'. Vans doesn't have that problem at all. When the Vans Protec contest was in need of a 'refurbishing', they stepped it up. Organizational & structural changes occurred & the ladies found themselves on the short end of the stick. It didn't last long. As a matter of fact, Steve Van Doren reassured everyone that things would be made right & quickly put a plan in place to facilitate it. In the summer, Steve Van Doren took a whole posse of the ladies on a skate tour of California & the northwest. This tour culminated in the Vans womens contest this past weekend. The night before the contest, I was watching the practice heats & thinking. I overheard a few guys talking. We were sitting along the fence & one of the guys stated that he wanted to see "manly skating" during the contest. We laughed. Someone else chimed in to say "I want these girls to 'man-up'. Joking aside, I think that was exactly what was in store for us 'fellows'. Watching the practice,  I recalled women riders in 'Skateboarder' magazine back in the 1970s. I saw images of Leilani Kiyabu, Vicky Vickers, Judi Oyama & others. Judi Oyama was a Santa Cruz sponsored skater & early rider for Independent trucks. I saw Judi Oyama & spoke with her regarding the past & current vert scene & women riders.  She was happy to be seeing a new level of vert skating & acceptance among women riders. "I am super proud of all the women skaters and the caliber of skating. The changing of the guard so to speak. These young women are skating hard and doing gnarly moves. I am glad I watched the event first hand." [caption id="attachment_5882" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Judi Oyama- Winchester 1979 -with a young Steve Caballero"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_5884" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Vicki Vickers - Marina 1979"][/caption] Mimi Knoop told me that Cara Beth Burnside was of incredible importance in getting the tour & contest organized. Cara Beth has been a 'mainstay' & an icon for women riders the world over. If Tony Alva is regarded as the 'Godfather' of skateboarding, then Cara Beth must be looked upon as sort-of the 'Godmother' of  skateboarding. Not to put too fine of a point on it, but many women riders have looked upon & continue to view her as an inspiration. The Vans tour that she helped facilitate had various riders. This summer, they all loaded up into the Vans RV and headed north. Mimi, CB, LynZ, Letitia, Evelien, Olivia, Kristin & others went all over California & the northwest. The contest --this weekend-- was a culmination of all these events and planning. [caption id="attachment_5905" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="tour"][/caption] The future was now. To the  misogynists & 'naysayers' that don't believe women can skate vertical, I say, "Wrong!" As events unfolded this weekend, men were to be 'force-fed' a heavy dose of vertical destruction. At Vans, I saw many a guy 'knock back' that bitter pill. I could list a 'who's who' of the contest participants, but it should suffice to say that there was a great deal of energy, camaraderie & ripping going on. Something decisive was occurring. The past met with the present. Collision. It may have been raining &  storming outside, but under the roof of Vans skate park, a new era dawned. No longer would the vertical torch be carried by the 'few'.  Cara Beth, Mimi, LynZ & others had set the wheels in motion as had those that came before them. Judi, Vicky, Leilani & others, had shown the world that women can & will skate vertical. Sometimes, much better than the men who watch from the sidelines & mumble amongst themselves. This day, women ruled & ruled well. I saw fastplants. I saw BS Disasters, FS lipslides, inverts, big airs, speed, style & fluidity. I saw happy faces & applause all the way down the line. Beginner to advanced...all received the respect of those that were riding with them. There was a great deal of respect earned from the men watching as well. During the contest, I saw the guys who --earlier-- had stated that they wanted to see 'manly skating'. They were screaming & shouting just like everyone else by the level of ripping that these ladies were exhibiting. On this day, it wasn't just about the contest. I think it was more of a statement. The ladies are here & they are here to stay. Men...you've been put on 'notice'. Respect. - Ozzie

item.title: licking my wounds
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5915" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="courthouse dawn"][/caption] It's another incomprehensible day in what passes for my life. I'm under the porch & licking my wounds.I'm sorry to whine & gripe but do so for your edification & enjoyment. It must be amusing to witness my folly. A few months ago, I went to San Diego to see some friends. While there, I was pulled over by two different police cars in the same hour. I swear! One, saw my registration sticker expired. After checking that I had paid & was only waiting for the stickers...they let me go.  57 minutes later, another police officer pulled me over. She immediately got in my grill. She asked me what my "business was in her fair city". I told her that I was visiting but my business was my own. She bristled & started giving my paperwork the proper Gestapo scrutiny. Unlucky me. My insurance had lapsed 3 days earlier. I could almost hear her heart thumping in joy as she reached for her little notepad of pain. Taking my citation, I bit back my viciousness & left. I had let my mouth, overrun my ass. I went to court in San Diego & paid 200$ of the fine: roughly half. I told the judge that I could pay the rest later. He agreed. Later, I had a whole new set of problems & the San Diego court systems money was one of them. I didn't have it. I didn't pay it. I didn't call. I received a polite letter recently, telling me that my drivers license was being suspended on November 27th. I left the house Monday at 4:00 am, Stood in line from 6:00-8:00am & finally saw the judge at 10:30am. He was not very forgiving. I understood. 'Batman' (the judge in his black robes), sent me packing with a curt,  "Next time, pay the fines." I mumbled & cursed under my breath. Yes, your honor. That thought had --finally--occurred to me!" I was the 'goon'. I didn't take proper action.  A loving friend came through & now I owe somebody else 514$. Damn! Life on lifes terms. I learned a valuable lesson. You know, I learn through really painful experiences. This one hurt. Purification through pain. Skate...and pay those fines. - Ozzie

item.title: Burly
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
San Bernardino, Anaheim, Rialto, Upland & Colton. These names and others, beckoned from road maps and advertisements for the California dream. These cities would be drawing the hundreds of thousands of families that thronged to the southern California area in the 1950s and 1960s. After World War 2, many people found work and affordable housing in the east Los Angeles region.
Kaiser Steel was located there & had made a fortune during the war by providing steel for the sprawling shipyards in Norfolk, Virginia. There, the massive 'Liberty' ships were constructed, with which, the Allies pounded back Hitlers SS on the Normandy beaches of D-Day. Subsequently, these 'Liberty' ships, carried supplies & troops into Europe and Hitler-cowering in his bunker-shot himself as his Third Reich crumbled & burned.
It was a time of hubris. America was not the 'star-spangled-lie' it would become. It was a place filled with the hard working & hopeful. Kaiser Steel hired thousands of people & homes had to be built to keep up with the massive influx of families. Construction companies worked overtime to complete the arid neighborhood housing tracts in the subsequent press to provide for those that wanted the California dream. Walled backyards with fluted brickwork, palm tree fronds whispering over blue-tiled kidney pools, quiet cul-de-sacs; this image was sold in concrete, chrome and glass.
Blue Haven, Anthony, Sunset & Master pool companies vied for contracts in the ensuing push to place swimming pools in -virtually- every other backyard of the homes being built. These pool companies couldn't know that what they built, would later be the foundation of a minor religion. Skateboarding. Sometime in the mid 1970s, skateboarders discovered pools. There was a drought in California at that time and swimming pools quickly became a luxury that few could afford. Pools were emptied & remained thus. Skateboarders found these round, cement wonders and nothing has ever been the same.
Salba recalled of a time when they would ride pool after pool, working their way across town & back again...all day long! One day, Tony Alva & I were riding Bronson Canyon ditch. TA told me that around 1977, pool skaters from the San Fernando valley, San Diego & the 'Badlands', began to actually 'network', so they could ride more pools. Kent Senatore, Jerry Valdez, Jeff Tatum, Gunnar Hugo, Salba, TA, Wes & others, would call around and drive out to other areas to ride new stuff.
This period was instrumental in developing the vertical sport seen on TV today, in the buffoonery also known as the 'Xgames'. Moves & tricks were developed. Speed lines were learned. A lifestyle was born. For those of us living a million miles away in the rest of the US, the magazine photographs were all we had. I remember a particular 'Skateboard World' photograph of Shogo Kubo.
It was fall in Pennsylvania. The air was cold. In the dawn, frost covered the entire space of things. Dying leaves of red, purple and orange blanketed the streets. I received the magazine in the mail. Opening what became my 'bible', I saw Shogo Kubo. He was carving deep to shallow in a square pool. The secret 'Watchtower' pool. Shogo was so stylish. He oozed style. In the photograph, he was padless, eyes looking forward, wheels balanced precariously on the tiles...speed & flow. I stared at that photograph for hours. Pool skating was all I wanted to do. It seemed the essence of all things cool & soulful. I know that I am not alone in thinking these things. We owe everything to those that came before us. I thank them all.- Skate Long-Ozzie

item.title: things are great on the way up...
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5923" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Salba- 'keeping me down'"][/caption] It feels like it only rains on me. Now, a pale sun burns & stings. Parched throats choke on dust & decay. Faceless people clutter the dirty sidewalks, checking their reflections; concerned only with the 'outside'. They'll give nothing of themselves & nothing is offered in return. I feel so cold & I can't be sure why I feel anything at all. I guess I'm swimming in the same dark ocean as everyone else. Sometimes, trusting that life will get better, is a terribly overwhelming thing. I guess I'm going to have to go make a 'gratitude list'... I was talking to TA on the phone yesterday. He told me that he & Katy were listening to a Yogi speak last weekend. The Yogi was  saying that he believes most people are celebrating 'Thanks-having' & not 'Thanks-giving' He said that many people really miss the point. I'm not sure that I know what 'the point' of Thanksgiving is. I'm not sure of anything at all. Few things are certain. That is one thing that I know. I am going home to 'Ridiculous' tonight & try my best to be thankful. People & life can only 'keep us down', if we let them. Thanks to MRZ for the image of Salba 'keeping a brother down'. It's a funny one . Happy Thanksgiving to all my friends out there. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: literat
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
'Poet, Author, Man of letters. Person who finds joy in words.'
I read a great deal. I can't help it. There is an old saying that I am fond of. It goes like this. "I buy books & if there is any money left over, I pay my rent & buy food." I like that. I would go to swap meets & yard sales to buy up books on history & psychology, chemistry, behavioral science....anything I could learn from. My search for myself. I came to find that I didn't really need all those books & ideas. In the end, my greatest teacher was others. Learning about ourselves is really possible when we look at our relationships with other people. I came to everyone wearing a mask. After awhile, I didn't even know who I really was. In the end, I was only sick as my secrets. I dealt the death blow to those ghosts & I now know exactly who I am. It is a fact that relationships with other humans, shows our true nature to ourselves. I choose about six books a month to read through. I carry them in my car & in my backpack. I read several at a time because I am interested in a differing number of things. These are from my current pile. Go read something....its good for you. Ozzie

item.title: Thanksgiving
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Dream sequence: Cool-guy club. Ego & drama. I stand at a podium screaming..." Time worries away the foundation of--even--the most solid lies. In the end, you send yourselves away, in tears, decay, clinging to the sun that shines. Only to be returned again, to thistles & vines. We will pop your inflated ego & you will fart and fall to the earth. None of what you do really matters.".
Incessant chirping....alarm clock. Thanksgiving day dawn. Coffee & Advil. Shower steam. I could feel the static on my leg hairs as I slid into my warm clothing straight from the dryer. It was a good start. The sky fell last night & everyone knew it. It was pale blue this morning as it came back to life once again. I loaded up the truck. Generator. Pump. Hoses. Buckets. Bolt cutter. Broom. Towels.
The wind was slamming the truck around & the gusts were probably 40mph. Trees were stark against the dark dawn sky & bent at the waist, spilling leaves everywhere. I drove the freeway south. I saw an industrial area. The grimness of the brick buildings was overtaken by the yawning overgrown lots. Rusting cranes & discarded iron parts sprouted out of the ground & it seemed as though these were but remnants of some giant robot war. It looked like a lost battlefield littered with steel, cables & old cracked leather. I drove on.
I met up with my companions Shawn & Ed from Riverside. We were happy to be together on Thanksgiving morning. We were grateful. Shawn pulled his beanie tighter across his head & peered up at the trees. The palm fronds were whipping with the wind & giant husks were spread out in the streets where they fell. "The winds will hide the sound of the generator & our skating." He smiled. Let's go. We drove out into the back country & scouted a few holes enroute. Once we arrived at our destination. I received the 'lowdown'. This was the infamous pool- 'El Pollo Loco'.
It was 'going on' years ago...but no more. Total bust. Being as it was Thanksgiving, we decided to give her a try. We gathered our gear & ran across the road. Darting under an overhanging pepper tree, I spotted the hole in a rusting fence. Soon, we were through & safely ensconced inside the block-walled perimeter of the yard. The house was 'tore up from the floor up'. The pool was strange. It had a deep end in the middle of the pool & odd ledges & weird transitions. We were pleased. We cleaned & drained, then rode. Things were accomplished & all was right with the world.
Then-- over the sound of the wind--I heard it. Helicopter! Police. He did a 'fly- by' & banked sharply. We had ducked for cover & as soon as he was out of sight, headed out. The Sheriffs Department pulled up as we were standing by the cars. He asked us what we were doing. "Hiking" was my mono-syllabic response. He smirked & drove away in a cloud of dust. Happy Thanksgiving. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Palm Springs
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I like Palm Springs. Its like going to Mars. Everything is concrete, chrome, glass, lava rocks & rough stone. The sun beats down unmercifully & very little lives in that hothouse climate. Perhaps nowhere else is the sun regarded such the 'life-giver' & the 'life-taker'. I usually drive out there a half-dozen times a year. I call upon my pal Doug Kinkade & we drive the grid. I must admit quite frankly that Palm Springs has an over abundance of square pools. As a matter of fact, my first six finds today, were all square pools! It's kind-of the way things go sometimes. I scouted for pools in the 'Badlands' for over a decade & never saw a tarantula spider...not once. Then, about a year ago, I saw one or two a week for something like two months! It was absurd. I don't know about anyone else, but when I see a tarantula, I get the 'heebie-jeebies'. I found a skimming net & got them out of the pool. Palm Springs is strange. Its windy & has a curious abandoned look to it. As I drove the yawning side streets & neighborhoods, I noticed people sitting idly on porches. It was like they were waiting to die. They sat there in the dirty sunlight & watched the leaves blow by, surrounded by lava rock, cactus & stones. Like I said; Mars. The houses have an odd 'unoccupied' look that is peculiar to this area. Maybe, because they are vacation homes...? I am unsure. It certainly makes pool hunting more difficult. Today, I saw this one home. It had 1950s architecture, blistered paint & a red lava rock yard in front. Overgrown palms & cactus were all around the perimeter...it looked like it had sat empty for years. The wooden fence was half broken & it sagged on rusting hinges. I moved quickly into the yard. I saw the pool. It looked great & was virtually empty. I went to take a photograph & then I saw a mans bald head through the patio window. I exited quietly. One can never tell. Today was a grid search that ended up being a 'Square Pool Sunday'. One can't win everyday. Besides, at least I was out hunting the grid & not sitting on the couch, drinking cheap beer & talking about how rad it was 'back in the day'. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: East
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5949" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Andy Neals pool"][/caption] I love skateboarding. Put simply, skateboarding is a part of who I am. I have the most fun skating in backyards because when I started riding in the 80’s you had to build your own “fun.” My friends and I built ramps in our backyards and created our own paradise, DIY style. At one point in my hometown there were three backyard ramps going all at the same time…that was Rad. During this time in my life I loved opening Thrasher magazine and seeing images of pool skating. I would dream about skating pools. Ironically, I grew up in a town called Poolesville, yet we had no skate-able pools. Trust me, I searched. The search has continued into my adult life and I love finding, draining, and skating real pools. One of the highlights of my life was a weekend spent with Ozzie in the Inland Empire…5 pools, 2 days…enough said. Nothing is better than the real “find.” I am a bit envious of those that live in the land of sky blue pools. Some dislike made to skate backyard pools because they represent the opposite of what we “search” for, a masterpiece not built for skating. I understand this argument. However, I also like made to skate pools because on the east coast we don’t have the luxury of a lot of pools. In order to ride what I like, it had to be built. I had ideas in my head and friends at Artisan Skateparks that made my dream a reality. Everyone at Artisan skates. All of Artisan’s work is skater designed and built. They did a great job. She has tight hips, two death boxes, and stairs. Enjoy the images. This session was a good one.- Andy Neal

item.title: Brandon Wong
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_6012" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="the endless road"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_6000" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Country Club hubbub"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_6001" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="purrrrfect"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_6004" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="pretty"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_6005" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Swimquip"][/caption] My pool pal Brandon Wong has been rolling out with our crew for well over a year now. He just keeps charging & getting better & better. Brandon is a stellar photographer, great person  & I am happy to call him a friend. We drove the grid for a few hours Saturday. We really had no plan & aimlessly ended up weaving our way from one seedy neighborhood to another. We spoke about life & the futility of some things. Life hurts when you lose a thing you will never be able to replace. The weight of the world. Dispossession. We laughed at me having only 23$ to my name. We spoke about relationships with women. Women faired well. The sun glittered & the road wound away into the distance. I felt broken when I awoke that day, but hanging with Brandon was cool. I was temporarily glued back together. We drove closer to a nice area of town & ended up around some 'Country Club' estates. Things became a bit more exciting for us. Overall, we found eight pretty good holes. The best was a '7', the worst a '3' & the others fit somewhere in between. I just asked Brandon to shoot whatever struck his fancy & at the end of the day, he sent me these. I must admit...he has a 'great eye'. The photographs represent all that we saw & experienced. Enjoy. Thanks to Brandon Wong for being a cool guy, buying me food, & showing us his images. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_6007" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="scoping"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_6008" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Williams"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_6009" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Blue Haven maven"][/caption]

item.title: Alba /Alva
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_6021" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="alba at winchester"][/caption] According to Steve Alba, he began riding for Alva Skates at 'Big O' in the summer of 1978. "I rode for Alva at least a year. The prototype model came out & I rode it in a few contests. The signature model never came out though. In 1979, I was winning contests & receiving a great deal of coverage. Kryptonics offered me a signature model, and royalties as well. I decided to take their deal." Tony Alva stated that it wasn't really a decision on his part. "The guys running Alva Skates at the time only wanted me to have a signature model, but if anyone else would get one, it would've been Steve." Whatever the case may be, The Steve Alba prototype/model is now reproduced for posterity. Thank you to TA & Salba for their memories.

item.title: pondering
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_6033" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Alex Perelson"][/caption] I've been reading a book by Dietrich Bonhoeffer. He was writing about cheap grace. He wrote that many people live in such a state. "Instead of following Christ, the Christian enjoys the consolation of his grace. This is what I mean by cheap grace. It's a grace which amounts to the justification of sin without departing from the sinful ways." In other words- a person can commit & live in sin, because they know that God has forgiven them. Lame.  Cheap grace is the grace we bestow upon ourselves. I love reading & pondering these things. My friend Shawn told me, "The very essence of every faith is the same. Time, place & circumstance of the teaching was different."  I understand. Back in the dark ages, people were killing each other exponentially. It was mayhem. I'm sure that the church needed to throw down some rules from on high, to make folks toe the line. It does make sense. I just love to look for the truth in all things. Most of what we see, isn't really what's going on....   is it?  The Japanese Zen master - Bankei stated, "The farther you enter into the truth, the deeper it is."  I think I'll quit on that note. This is the time of year to ponder such things. Thanks to Brian Fick for the image. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: sallie

item.title: la fin du monde
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_6047" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="wreckage of her past"][/caption] Perhaps the end of the world happens for different people in differing ways. For some, it may be the death of a family member. All the shared memories & dreams become a terrible reminder of the loss. Tragedy. Woe. Perhaps it is catastrophe. Apres moi le deluge. The flood. Plague & pestilence. On September 11, 2001, all the world seemed to burn & everything was strangely chaotic...lopsided. It seemed as though everything we knew had fallen down & landed on its head. Sometimes, the world breaks for  good reason. We find life in shambles frequently. We saw a family home today. An old woman had lived there. Church bulletins were scattered about. Denture cream & Depends boxes lay in heaps of trash. She must have been handicapped. I could see evidence of her long occupation of the home. From the floor, I picked up a curled, yellowing black & white photograph. A tired-looking woman of about 40 years old, stared back at me. Her eyes could not hide the weight of her existence. I placed the photograph up on a window ledge so she could see the trees outside. Faded knick-knacks & memorabilia sat in dusty niches reflecting the dirty sun that filtered through the broken windows. It seemed cold in there. I felt lost... saddened. It was like part of her still remained in the detritus of her broken life. The pool lay out back in the rubble. It had --obviously--been unused for decades. It must have been an obscene daily reminder of a happier time. Cookouts, swimming, family. Tires & garbage were strewn about. I saw syringes & broken glass. Others had come this way after she left. They always do. They scurry in the night & pass on their virus & disease. The night teems with a thousand horrors. We walked through, saying very little. Her story was there. On the floor & in the rubble. The end of her world. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: my back against a wall...
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Tired. Fed up. Over it. I want to get out of this whole deal. Life. I feel most alone with everybody. I feel everything. Its like the whole fucking weight of the world is beating me down into a hole. I see no light. I see shadows. Clouds knife the gray skies. I look for a colorless God who won't listen or hear. There is nothing more. I miss Q. He was such a rad little spark in my life. Where is he now? My back is against a wall & I can't lift my arms to fight any longer. I see a really big wall of water coming & I don't seem to care very much. The deep sleep. Oblivion. I won't be departing the way I came. No  more pain & self-abuse. My engine of self-destruction is hammering in my head. It feels like someone is stepping on me in big black boots. Help me, help me, call the helicopters! My words. My life.

item.title: VallelyStacyGleamingTheCube

item.title: Stacy Peralta
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Stacy Peralta with Mike V. on Gleaming the Cube set."][/caption] In the fall of 1999, Tony Alva phoned me & asked me to meet with him, as he had something that he wanted to talk to me about. It was important. I drove to Oceanside that night & we went out to get some Sushi. TA told me that Stacy was going to make a Dogtown documentary. They had started working on it already. It was pretty hush-hush at that point. TA knew that I was always out searching for pools. He had been riding them with me for awhile. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Stacy -at Skatercoss"][/caption] A few days later, TA & I drove up to Los Angeles & met up with Stacy Peralta & Craig Stecyk. I must admit that I was tripping when I met Stecyk. Here was this man who had helped forge my identity in so many ways. His Dogtown articles were of paramount importance & made me want to be a writer. The man was an influence. Stacy told me that they wanted to get  few pools going for the documentary.  They wanted pools for some current footage of TA riding & as an interview location. TA told him that I was their man. I nodded in agreement. In the following months, the time I spent with them was epic. It seemed as if my life had come full circle. My own contributions were minimal--I think--but to be a part of that process & subsequent success will always remain as a highlight in my life. Full circle. I was just a poor, broken kid from PA, who had looked up to the Z-boys. Amid the shadowed woodlands & unending cornfields of Pennsylvania, I skated alone-- frequently-- & emulated them. Now, thirty years later, I helped tell their story to the world. I considered it an honor. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Stacy- with lapper for lipslides. 1977"][/caption] Stacy was such a nice man & a wealth of skateboard knowledge. Whenever we were driving somewhere or eating, I would sit quietly (rare) off to one side, listening. I love skateboard history. He had more than a few stories & I was delighted. I admire Stacy for his contribution, style & talent. He was always a great skater and Salba told me that Stacy was one of the first riders to pull FS lipslides. He did it back in the 1970s! Stacy Peralta will always be regarded as an iconic figure among our people. He has created a body of work that will stand the test of time. His career, company, videos, & subsequent films continue to inspire generations everywhere. Thanks Stacy. Thank you to Glen E. Friedman, J.Grant Brittain & Jim Goodrich for the images. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Stacy- at his home- 1978"][/caption]

item.title: Heroes & Zeroes
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
3:03pm -Dark Matter Gallery-Promenade- Long Beach, Ca.
I drove in on the endless concrete ribbon that leads from Ridiculous to the beach cities & beyond. The sky was overcast until I approached the exit at Broadway in downtown Long Beach. All of the sudden, sunlight came streaming through the clouds. An omen? I spoke with Ray on the phone. He was out running errands & would be there shortly. I parked & wandered into the gallery. At first glance it seemed empty. Echoing. Vast. Industrial. Then, as my eyes adjusted, I saw the walls. Pale blue tiles. Coping, skateboards, familiar faces, unknowns, concrete, my people. Everything I felt inside--every moment of everyday --was on display.The images from Ray Zimmerman's lifeblood poured over the walls & ran into the darkened interior. I immediately felt at home. I meandered through in stunned silence.
Duane Peters had a place of prominence inside the front door on a wall. The image of him was familiar. I hadn't seen this one before, but I was there the day it was taken. DP is jauntily sprawled across the shallow stairs of 'Fishbowl' with a smirk on his face. He peered down at me as if to say, "You wish you were me!" Somehow, I actually did wish I was DP. Decades of ruling & road-weariness were all over him. His creased face and heavily inked body betrayed his many years of abuse, denial & skateboarding punk sacrifice. Duane rules! Another image next to it, was of DP at 'Bricktop'. I was there when it was taken as well. The image is insane. What you cannot see, is that Duane bled all over the bottom of the pool. I believe that the wounds he received that day, were the catalyst for his later leg infection & subsequent misery this past fall. I'm glad he's better now.
As I looked around, I saw many guys that will never be in a skateboard magazine & probably couldn't care less. They would probably feel exactly the same if they knew they were on a gallery art wall as well. On the wall, next to the start of the exhibit, Ray had his artist statement. In it, he describes his view of things. He wrote, "Skateboarders see the world differently. They see obstacles as challenges and restrictions as invitations. This is the nature & evolution of the species. Un-natural selection." BLKPRJKT arrived sporting a punk mohawk. He spoke of CR Stecyk, the unreliability of government, financial foreclosure woes, therapuetic approaches in modern psychotherapy & the banality of most human beings. You got to love a guy like BLKPRJKT. He's really upbeat & positive!
There were some other artists setting up a gallery behind ours. They had sculpture & things that resembled toaster ovens with eyes and the like. It was strange. Hmmm. I saw two guys carrying in one of these things. One buddy chided the other saying, "Careful dude. This is priceless. It's my life." I peered over at the tin foil & pop- riveted thing they were carrying. It looked like a 4th grade science project gone awry. But whatever. If that does it for them. Who am I to say? We all set up the keg & drinks as people started gathering outside. It was time. Skateboarding. BLKPRJKT took a knowing look around & turned to me. He asked, "Do you know why you don't see these images in print magazine?" I let the question hang there & shrugged. I thought I knew why, but waited for him to tell me what he thought. "Because its just too good! It's the finest in non-commercial work." I have found BLKPRJKT to be absolutely right in many things. I love his cynicism & adroitness. We completely agreed on this one as well.
I had to admit, this was skateboarding to me. This work represented all that I loved & lived. People wandered in. It filled up quickly. The murmur of voices rose as more people filled the space to overflowing. Old friends were greeted & admirers spoke among themselves, totally stoked on the hardcore, soulful exhibition Ray put together. I overheard people talking. They spoke in admiration. Someone said that Ray manages to capture--not only--the skate image itself but the vibe & mood behind it. I noticed-- long ago-- that Ray captures the environmental decay surrounding everything; the fleeting moment of the entire experience. He portrays the lifeblood of all we do. It pulses & hammers within skateboarders, and Ray seems to get that better than most anyone. He should. He's been on his skateboard his whole life. It's wired into his biology. His use of shadow is incredible. He is a master at showing deception within the truth.
I saw Grant Brittain, Josh Borden, Lance, Dressen, Tom Knox and a host of others. Riverside, SD, LA & the valley were all heavily represented. It was a blast. Ray Barbee sat in the corner, smiled, plugged in his guitar & totally laid out the coolest vibe & soundtrack for the evening. Everyone milled about & listened as his fingers nimbly moved across his guitar like the legs of a large spider. It was perfection. The mood was grand & everyone was stoked. Thank you Ray, for all you do. You are truly one of the 'greats'. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: it felt very real
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_6099" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Tuling, Amy, Ji, PK, Cheryl, Marlo, Sonja & Chris"][/caption] My friend Patricia (PK),  asked about skating Ridiculous a few months back. She had a small group of girlfriends that always would try to ride together & they regularly rode, Venice, The Cove, Culver City & other park pools. I readily agreed & a scheduled day was planned. I had helped set up Split Clothing Girls Skate Day at San Diego Mission Valley Skate Park back in 2000, but I didn't ride that day. This would be my first experience riding with an all-female crew. I didn't know what to expect and--to be quite honest--thought that the ladies might be getting themselves into some hoopla. I mean, backyard pools are difficult to ride. That being said, I voiced my opinion to Patricia & she shrugged it away. "Don't worry. We're all pretty tough cookies." I let the matter rest. On Christmas Eve, I skated Venice with Patricia & she spoke about wanting to try Lance Mountains pool sometime. She didn't think any of the other girls had ridden there either. I phoned Lance & set up a session. Since the ladies were coming --mostly-- from Los Angeles, we could all meet there, skate, then ride Ridiculous after. I still had my misgivings but wisely kept them to myself. It must be said,  I mean no disrespect. I skate with some pretty heavy crews & am accustomed to insane things going down, ego, longevity & hardcore skateboarding at its best. I was wondering how the ladies would do. We gathered at Lances house & met everyone.  No man's land. There were a bunch of us & the vibe was total happiness. There were the following in attendance: Tuling, Amy, Ji, PK, Cheryl, Marlo, Sonja, Lance, photographers  Chris & Brandon & myself. We all scrambled into the pool & swept...cleaning out the leaves & tree debris. The ladies--to my surprise--quickly padded up, dropped in & got busy. I sat back with Lance & we watched. He had brought out a stereo & the music pulsed in the background. I was reminded--immediately-- of skating as a kid. Everywhere that we looked, we saw perfect, peaceful faces. It was like small children had landed from some strange planet inhabited by happy, egoless people. One of the ladies grinded & Lance looked over at me grinning. He nodded. It was unspoken. Rad! We watched & everyone seemed giddy. All the ladies pushed themselves & each other. There was no heckling or name calling. It was is if the language of skateboarding had changed for the day. All were hooting & hollering for each other and individual barriers were crossed as the ladies drew lines & figured out Lances pool. After quite awhile, the sun began to wane & we had to head out to Ridiculous. Lance stood with the ladies for a few photographs & graciously brought out a box of Lance Mountain shirts. He gave each girl one on their way out! We loaded up & were soon in our cars streaking across the freeway in the dirty receding sunlight. At Ridiculous, my roomies Michael & Badlander Chris, hooked up the lights & got the propane & grill going. With music throbbing through the backyard & burgers smoking on the grill, the ladies arrived & hit the switch for the Ridiculous session. I must admit, I was surprised. I was intrigued by the tenacity & punishment that these ladies took. They all--without exception--crushed themselves all day, and returned for more. After eating burgers, I looked around in the gloom. Some of the ladies were limping & more than a few had ice packs on various parts of their anatomy. I was pleased. Beer was consumed & fun was had by all. The ladies proved to be equal to men in their desire to push themselves. They improved by their willingness to take a concrete beat-down,  in the effort to better themselves & have fun. Fun was what it was all about. All day. This is where I must admit an observation. The ladies actually seemed to be having more fun than I sometimes see in their male counterparts. Skateboarding is a male-dominated minor religion. Sometimes, the fun gets lost. Periodically, a sense of unreality descends on a session. It was refreshing to see complete stoke on peoples faces and the reason for that is simple. The ladies were stoked by the very act of skateboarding & rolling... all by itself. Maybe the guys should take a lesson. In closing, all I have to say is that today--for me--skateboarding felt very real. Thank you Lance, Chris & Brandon. Thanks to the ladies for opening our eyes. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: ozziesAngels

item.title: I don't like being what I am...
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Frustration. My back against a wall. Sometimes-- because of what I am & my disease-- I must make decisions that would not normally be forced upon someone. I have recently come to a decision...its one of the painful kind. Anything that causes me undue stress or anxiety must be eliminated from my life. When I read  these words pouring from my computer screen, it sounds  so weak. It's like the bones in my spine have become Styrofoam. WTF!? I must admit, I don't particularly like being what I am. Only another alcoholic would understand though. Most regular people, think it's just a weakness of the willpower or something. Maybe. But, whatever it is... I got it! It makes me want to crawl into a hole sometimes. I am constantly hyper-vigilant. I must always anticipate things that might bring me to my knees. I go down the drain fast. I lost eight years of my life, last time out. I am hoping I learned from that. Hence, the difficult decision. I must show no fear at all. It becomes a very selfish & lonely existence. Selfishness rooted in self-preservation. Sometimes, I don't like being what I am. My thoughts turn dark....  swirling like black pool water. I'm going to go running. Reflective today. Sober. Sad. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: nothing ever changes.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_6131" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="tyler mumma"][/caption] Most of what I've ever read or written--in some strange way-- seems rehearsed. In that, it's already been penned by another's hand. Somewhere, somehow, the same calloused palm that thrums and mutters the taut-skinned drums, echoing ancient customs into fire-sparked night, has spelled out similar words. These palms & gnarled fingers, have held a quill and scratched out litanies and lines in languages long-forgotten. In the dim light of the worlds dawn, it's all been done. By firelight, gas lamp & tallow-- the light casting wavering shadows into the dim corners of antiquated dens--its all been written.Appropriately, the shadows lend an aura of unreality to the written words. Someday, a story may come & a nameless face on some foyer wall will echo out its lilting laughter, as plagiarism yellows the time-eaten pages. Nothing ever changes... unless there's some pain. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Style
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I ran this morning, did crunches until I thought I'd puke up my spleen, then took a long hot shower. It didn't help the gnawing in my guts one bit. My mind was swirling like a cauldron & I couldn't think straight. Gods! I started writing. Pleasantries. Happy Talk. I ran a line through all that & scribbled darksome & unholy things to myself. It didn't work. My dragon is awake & I don't know why. I began looking through some images that J.Grant Brittain sent to me. I see Chris Miller. His is the first image as I open the file. Style. Flow. Power. Majestic. I sit & peer at the images. I notice my head calm. I notice the clock as well. Soon, I must leave to be 'Forklift' boy for the next 8 hours....Ugh! My dragon shifts inside. I look back at Mr. Miller & he calms down.

item.title: Glen E. Friedman & C.R. Stecyk III
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_6140" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="The iconic images"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_6141" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Glen E. Friedman, Jeff Ho, C.R. Stecyk III"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_6142" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Craig Stecyk - 1981"][/caption] Respect. I pay homage here & now. Call me what you will. I won't be listening. Glen E. Friedman & Craig Stecyk made my life better, with the images & stories they put out into the world. They threw a stone & watched the ripples spread... I lived in a place far away from the concrete sprawl & decadence that made up their world. Every month, I would open the slippery, colorful pages of  Skateboarder magazine. I would see into a world unknown & alien to me. I was sucked in like a magnet. Space & time fell away. The frost & ice of Pennsylvania, was replaced with palm trees, sun, blue tiles, kidney pools, estates & rolling wheels. I smelled weed smoke. I could hear the wheels as they click-clacked across the tiles at the pool. I heard Ted Nugent's gruff voice growling from a radio, "Stakes are high & so am I .... " Paul, TA, Wes, Hackett & others were perched on the shallow stairs at Dogbowl. Jay was flowing across the waterfall, turning hard on the bottom & throwing himself at the lip. He wore a black fedora on his sun-bleached head. He had a yellow Powerflex shirt &  OP shorts. His Vans shoes were threadbare & his toes were almost sticking out of the tattered canvas. He carved hard & his momentum took him past the tiles. He was momentarily suspended on one wheel. The sun hung behind him & it was like the world had stopped. The image burned into my brain. Every molecule that makes up my body was hardwired at that moment. I came from my reverie. The magazine was hanging-- limply--in my hands... as I stared into space. I heard the heater switch on & its metallic sound filled the house. Outside, a snowplow truck shifted gears and moaned down the road, as sleet hissed off my windows. Thanks to Glen E. Friedman & Jim Goodrich for the images. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_6145" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Jay Adams- Dogbowl"][/caption]

item.title: gef ho stecyk 2
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.excerpt:encoded: Glen E. Friedman, Jeff Ho, C.R. Stecyk III

item.title: change
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_6166" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="a shadow of myself"][/caption] “Everytime I find the meaning of life, they change it.” I think I'm getting smaller. I know, I know. It sounds weird. Uhmm, give me a minute to explain. You see, when I started this, I decided to always be honest on the Blue Tile Obsession. Two rules were laid out for myself. I must present honesty & hardcore soulful pool skating. I had to keep my vision real... always. It has been gnarly to be so self-disclosing sometimes, but I know that it helps other people that suffer from some of the same crap that I do. They know that they are not alone in their thinking. The human condition. We all suffer from some sort of something. That being said, I think I'm getting smaller. I was driving an hour and a half--one way-- to work over the last year. It finally started sucking pretty hard... and not in a good way. I decided that I wasn't quite ready to get back into the RN thing, so I got a job ten minutes from Ridiculous. I run a forklift & work freight. Its cool & all but the pay is unbearable. Here is the honesty part. I received my paycheck the other day. It was $502.27.  Cricket....cricket....cricket. I paid my rent the next day. That left me with about 5$ to my name. It was almost past a joke. The morning after, I got up from my dark armchair to get ready & go jogging, because I work out a bunch. When I stood, my pants fell down to the floor. Now, I always wanted my pants to hit the floor for other reasons but this time, it's because I'm getting smaller. I've lost weight. I've been eating rice, ramen  & not much else. It's been pretty tough. Purification through pain. Here is the point. I was bummed out last week & at my very end. I had made a decision regarding someone & given up. I was contemplating a rough weekend ahead. Friday-- at work-- I decided to change. I couldn't give in & be a shadow of my former self. I called this person & apologized. I hope I fixed it because she is special. Saturday, my pool pals came out & skated. They surprised me, bought me lunch & gave me a few sets of Vans, as mine were full of holes. Yes! Sunday, some other great friends, brought me a huge pile of groceries & we skated. The session was unreal! . It started as a bad weekend & ended as one of the best I've had in a loooong time. I might be smaller, but life was larger & more positive this weekend. I changed my outlook & the world changed for the better. Thank you to those involved. You know who you are. My love to you. Ozzie

item.title: the promise
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Her hair was piled up silky & dark. It spilled over her shoulders. Her red lips curled like flame & her mouth hinted at the promise of more than words. Her walk was a mockery itself.... passion, silk, legs, and the inevitable lies. I looked away lest I succumb to her charms. I pushed hard & my skateboard moved me past her on the sidewalk & rapidly away from my weaknesses. Further down the street, a boarded -up house greeted my roving eyes.  The top curling edge of a pool slide jutted above the concrete edge of the property. It was a beacon. Salvation found within. I hopped the wall. It was perfection. It glittered like a thieves dream. It was a Blue Haven. It offered up endless possibilities & promise. The Blue Haven lady would take only what I could give & never concerned herself with trivialities & nonsense Decision. I hesitated not one moment. I plunged right in. A perfect marriage. Thanks to Brandon Wong for everything. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: a morning at the skatepark
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_6178" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Fontana II Roman"][/caption] I've been working the 7:00 pm-4:00 am shift as 'Forkboy' the last several nights. One of the forklift operators was sneezing & stuff last Tuesday. I awoke Thursday feeling like dog shit on a stick. I guess I picked up his cooties. I rested, hydrated & suffered. Today, some pool pals were going to meet up at Fontana II skate park. I thought I could ride but my energy is still pretty negligible. I decided to take a bunch of photographs of some of the crew & post up the results. These people are for real... they skate --not for glory--but because it's fun. I admire that in them. Thanks to the crew for making the long drive from Los Angeles. It was a pretty day...

item.title: Marry this mess & a happy you near.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Uhmm...  Merry Christmas & a Happy New Year. Well, that all sounded pretty hollow to me this past season. I had 13$ and three days off. If you ask me, that's a great deal of Internet porn to get through & not much else. It's a good thing my girlfriend --Jergens --was there for me. Anyway--jokes aside--I drove the grid Christmas morning. I was draining pools & it is actually the only thing that brings me peace sometimes. My pool pal Kevin was flying in from snow-covered Montreal & I wanted a new pool to take him to. I had a thought. Back in the fall, Salba & I had found a Master Pools amoeba in the area.
