It had a blue netting attached over it to prevent kids & pets from falling in. We stick tested it & it seemed pretty amazing. I went back around Halloween to drain it of its black water, but the backyard sat on a downhill angle. The pool area sat lower than the front of the house. I didn't have enough hoses to get it to the gutters out front. The sloping angle of the yard meant that all the water would run back & settle,  flooding the yard & the neighbors property. Not good. That's a quick way to lose a pool before you even ride it. Never flood the neighbors yard. Bad juju. Christmas day, I drove over. I found some 10 foot sections of rain spouting behind a house & formed them into a culvert, connecting them all together. I ran the hoses & started  draining. It worked well & the added length of rain gutters directed the flow of water to the street. I swept the gutter clean of leaves & debris. I waved cheerfully at the neighbors. As I had in the past, I told them I was Mr. Hugh Jorgan of the local Vector Control. I laughed inside, thinking of them telling their families that the pool next door was pumped dry by a huge organ!  The day was quiet & left to my own devices, I emptied the hole & took a few photographs. We went back the next day & hit it hard. Salba got the box first & took the Master Pools plate. Score! The pool was good but lasted only a short time. We found it, sat on it, drained it, rode it & lost it. It matters not. We love what we do. Thanks to Brandon Wong for the use of his camera & for making the giff image. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Snowbirds
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: My pool pal Terrell is from Colorado & there is ice & snow right now. Him & his buddies became snowbirds. Terrell is similar to many of the pool pals that we have. We only see each other once in awhile. Its always like greeting a long-lost brother. Skateboarding is a pretty small minor religion. Pool skating-- the bastard child of skateboarding-- is even smaller. We know each other. Its like the vert guys. During one of the Xgames, one of the people running the shenanigans wanted people like Tony Hawk & Andy Macdonald to vibe each other and create drama. They call that 'Good TV'. We call that nonsense. There are so few guys doing what they do--at that level--that they all skate, hang, help & know each other. Best pals! They aren't going to do any such thing as vibe each other! Pool riding is the same. Whenever we see each other, its a great thing. Cam called & told me that Terrell was in town with some pals & that they wanted to ride Ridiculous. A session was set up. I hadn't seen Terrell in 6 or 7 years. When they showed up at the house, I was surprised to see his beard. I guess we are all getting older. He looked like Kenny Rogers & his buddies called him the 'Gambler'. Funny. We met up with Salba, threw the pumps into a pool & he took them out to hit a nearby hole. I stayed & drained. The guys had to fly out of Las Vegas that afternoon & I wanted them to get some runs in as many pools as they could. That's how pool pals do it! We rode a few, everyone grinded, deathboxes were traversed & disaster averted. The Sheriff's Department stopped by to see how we were doing. I thought that it was quite pleasant of them to check in like that. Actually, he was pretty unhappy & cautioned us. I --the subtle tongued-- used sophism & guile to extricate us from potential citations. Whew! Lucky again. The day ended with the best of feelings. Old friends were seen, new ones made & pools were ridden. There is a brotherhood that exists in skateboarding. It transcends all. As Matt Neely (R.I.P.) wrote... 'Pool Pals'. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: even the best fall down sometimes
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: A man may fall many times, but he won't be a failure until he says that someone pushed him.  ~Elmer G. Letterman ‘All or nothing’, has to be worth something. Sometimes, its almost too hard. You go out to ride your skateboard, and your board ends up riding you… I learn best when I hurt. I think that this is pretty common for most of mankind.  I've said it before & repeat it here- "Nothing ever changes, unless there's some pain." If I want to get better, I need to fall down. Just remember that old Chinese proverb- "People who say it cannot be done, should not interrupt those that are doing it." While I work and prepare for some new pool adventures, here’s a few images to entertain you all. Thanks to Jim Goodrich, MRZ,  Motrin, Ben Gay & Emergency Rooms everywhere. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: hiding from tomorrow
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I've been sick lately. I can't skate, run or workout. Melancholy. I get that way. My apologies. I'd blame my family, but when I blame someone, I give up my power to change. I have my fathers awesome work ethic, intense drive to learn & stoicism. I have my mothers wit, empathy & depression. I share the same blood; the same weakness. Sometimes, I don't want tomorrow to come. Send my condolences to the heart. Mine is cold as of late. At least my signs are still vital. Oh well... I think that I found a way to better my situation. I've been thinking. Maybe it's time to get back into medicine. However, I need to be smart about it. I interviewed yesterday about a Case Management position. I would be helping people who are recently discharged from the hospital. I would set up therapy & ascertain their needs, then initiate the aftercare for them. It seems like a good move. I have done this before. I would be able to help people yet I wouldn't be directly involved with the desperately ill & dying. I guess I better keep my therapists phone number handy just in case I need him! I'm currently working on a Blue Tile Obsession T-shirt. I will post it up when it's ready. Hopefully, you will all support this thing that I do. You have a good weekend. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: his shadow on every wall
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_6213" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Jeff Phillips Arlington "][/caption] Sadly, Jeff Phillips is gone. People only really ever die, once the living stop remembering & thinking about them. I think of Jeff Phillips often. I write about him. He was power & grace. I skated with him at Virginia Beach in the 80s. He was super cool. A part of Jeff lives on in all skateboarders & that's why I see his shadow on every wall. Remember those that went before us...  keep them alive. Thanks to Tom Groholski for the image. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: just another tight little hole
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Alimony: the hosing you get, for the hosing you got. I don't know why I put that in there, but I've always thought it funny... and there we are. I liken it to this tight little hole that we've ridden recently. She looked promising, felt good & gave a little when we pushed. But, when she decided to push back... punishment. This was one of those 'off & on' pools. I think that it has been empty for decades. I believe that I rode it in the late 90s & Salba may have originally drained it back in 1930 or something.... kidding. All I know, is that we have hit it & missed it over the years & now its gone again. It's not one to fawn over, but it was pretty fun once you figured out the kinks & jolts. Thanks to MRZ & Brandon Wong for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: highway run
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I worked last night until abut 3:00 am. Tired & coughing, I drove home. I think I have Bronchitis... it sure feels like it. I awoke early & drove the desert roads up & over the mountain pass to Palmdale. There was an AA meeting I wanted to go to. I have some pals up that way. I feel like hell, am down & wore out, but that is probably the best time for me to be in a meeting. The meeting was cool. I was in a room of misfit toys just like me. Driving back, I saw Joshua trees bristling by the roadside & into the distance. There was virtually nothing out there & the highway ran away until it became a blur on the horizon. Telephone poles sprouted out of the ground & their electric wires contrasted grotesquely with the barren naked desert landscape. I cruised through a dead end town & slowed. A tumbleweed crossed my path & I laughed out loud. It was weird. I saw an old motel & peered between a broken fence. I found one. It was much the same as the surrounding town & countryside. Short on fun & long on pain. It was a huge square from a more prosperous time. I climbed back in the truck & made the long highway run south. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: rewind
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: After my morning drive up to Palmdale, I came home & crawled under the covers. I felt like a dog laying under a porch & licking my wounds. My head & chest hurt & I can barely stop coughing. I wish I could sleep for a week. I think that I drank about a gallon of water and ate rice & beans all day. I had oranges & hot tea. A shower felt orgasmic. My lungs were loving the hot steam & humidity. It's almost midnight & I am awake again. My internal clock is so skewed. My time is set on rewind. I was going through some old flash drives & found some images I had forgotten about. They are all from 2008. Most of the images are from my grid searches & I pulled off a few to show you. I hope that I feel better tomorrow. I need a hug... Skate- Ozzie

item.title: line city
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
A few years ago, I was driving the grid. It was first light. I had been living in Signal Hill for a few months & would drive out early in the morning to the Badlands. Driving the side streets, I would be in the neighborhoods long before most people were even out of bed. I was cruising slowly through a pretty nice area of town & saw dead grass off to my left. It was August & the lawns died pretty quickly in the scorching summer heat. Once a house was in foreclosure, you could bet on there being no water or electric. It was just the way things went. Pools turned into pea soup in a week or two & mosquitoes thrived.
I looped about & pulled over by the house. The lawn crunched underfoot. The air was already warm & I could tell that it was going to be a typical brain burner that day. There was a slatted sunroof-like structure over the back of the house & yard. It was screened in & it appeared to have a pool inside. Not one to be deterred by such trivialities as locks & things, I opened the trunk & removed my bolt cutters. In no time, I was inside. Hummingbirds fluttered & swooshed at my intrusion. I remember thinking that I must be near a nest. I saw the pool. The water was just darkening with algae & the pool looked incredible. I looked around for a power source & found one over the wall in the neighbors yard. I looked for a path to run the hoses. I made note of it & left.
After a full day of scouting, I returned at dusk. I entered the property & ran an extension cord & set up the pump & hoses as unobtrusively as was possible. I hid the cords & hoses behind the shrubs & landscaping. At dark, I brazenly walked onto the neighbors property, opened the gate & plugged in the power. I returned next door & was pleased that the pump was running quietly. I closed up & drove to Signal Hill. By 4:00 am the next morning, I was back. The pump was still running & the pool was virtually empty. It was amazing. I finished & cleaned up as dawn brightened the sky. We went back & rode. The overhead sunroof had a metal frame & the shadows made lines all over the pool. Because the pool had crazy carve lines & because of the shadows, Salba named it 'Line City'. It made sense. We rode it much to the chagrin of the neighbors & the pool was quickly lost to us. We knew it wouldn't last. That's the story & I'm sticking to it. Thanks. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Pink Tile Lounge
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Friday. Early afternoon. I was driving back to San Bernardino from Laguna Beach. I cut through the weekend traffic. Massive Attacks'- 'Angel' throbbed in my ears, as I tried to beat the weekend rush. People jousted for position. I saw very expensive automobiles piloted poorly by many on cell phones. Women applied makeup, barely watching the road. Wanna-be gangsters threw hard eyes & rumbled to their Hip-Hop freeway soundtracks. I smiled grimly. "Just let me get my hands on a rocket-launcher.... !" I drove on. As I exited near the house, I decided to drive a few side streets nearby. I hadn't checked this side of town in awhile. Within thirty minutes, I was standing in an awesome amoeba pool. It was insane! I took photographs & drove home to Ridiculous. I was excited. I had found a gem. When I phoned Salba, he told me that he had located an amazing pool that day as well. A friend of his found it while working for the power company. We traded notes & the next day, went to them together. Salba had found a huge left-hand kidney with pink tiles. His pool find easily trumped mine. It was so fun & user friendly. We couldn't believe it. It was like a skate park pool in the deep end. The shallow was a bit steep but workable nonetheless. We rode it in stealth mode for a short while. It then became the rain season. I-- periodically-- would go back in the early morning & drain the rain water out. During the holidays, workers were painting & carpeting inside. They let us ride from time to time & we had pretty relaxed sessions on those days. Eventually, the owner would show up. He realised that we were riding the pool & became incensed. He swore that we were destroying the surface & bringing down the property value. I thought it strange that it never occurred to him, that by buying a rundown house in a crappy gang neighborhood, he was assured of low resale value. Regardless, he became hellbent to catch us. I befriended an old man that lived next door. He let us skate & I took him some aloe plants for his front porch. He told us one day, "The owner is really pissed! He came by here about four times this morning. I think he's trying to get you guys arrested. I heard him screaming into his cell phone about calling the police." After that bit of news, we decided to part ways with the Pink Tile Lounge. Recently, I drove by & spoke with the neighbor. He said that the owner put water in the pool but still comes by frequently. I wish him well. The Pink Tile Lounge is gone. Those that had the privilege of riding there should remember its awesome surface & perfect transitioned bowl. We don't find them like that very often. Thanks to Salba & his good pal that clued us in. Thanks to MRZ, Dan Levy  & Brandon Wong for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: dark night
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Before night drew her veil across the lingering light of day, I slowed & nosed the car into a narrow dirt track beside a dead end. The LA river basin was down a steep rough concrete slope to my left. Barbed wire was heavily festooned across the fence top surrounding it & trash was carpeted thickly at its base. The winds blew hard through the area. I locked the car & peered about in the gloom. I heard voices muttering in the distance. I located them quickly. They appeared homeless & were unaware of my presence. I ghosted them & assessed for threats. After a time, they were gone. I walked up a short rise that looked down on the riverbed & nearby houses. In the middle distance, on a small hill, stood a burnt house--its windows vacant. The shell of the house resembled  a grinning skull. I smiled thinly to myself. Beyond, the waterway snaked its silvered way along the foot of the walled neighborhoods that rose against the skyline. I squatted there on my haunches & let my eyes adjust. I listened & let the dark seep into me. I am the intruder. I am looking for pools. I work in solitude. He travels fastest, who travels alone. I surveyed the yards below me. I studied the stretch of neighborhood that lay as pale as a silver stream beneath the wan glimmer of the far, uncaring stars. There were few sounds to break the hush of night-- the mournful cry of a night bird, and the buzz & chirp of nocturnal insects.  I could make out several pools. They were virtually empty. The area was downtrodden. I noted doghouses & homes lighted from within. I must be cautious. Invisible. I scanned the area once more, checking the horizon. I threw my sweatshirt over the barbed wire--covering the spikes--and pulled myself quickly across. I moved down the hill. The swish of the long grass marked my passing. Skate- Ozzie

item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Suffering is common to all humankind. It seems that skateboarding is plagued by addiction, alcoholism & mental illness much like the rest of society. Many of you out there -I’m sure-have watched as a friend drank & used drugs; skating less and less, to eventually be overcome by their own particular inner demons. ﻿ I can think of many examples. Tony Alva has shared his tormenting battle with alcohol while Jeff Grosso & Duane Peters make no secret of their own past drug hells. You have examples like Christian Hosoi, Ben & Tas Pappas & Gator…all torn by inner turmoil, virtually defeated by the dark pull. Alcohol & drugs always left them wrung out ... like water from a twisted rag. A short anecdote. I was standing on a corner covered in sweat, the salt leaving white crusted spots around my armpits and on the back of my once dark blue shirt. The midday sun hammered down like a lead pipe on my skull and I whimpered like a small animal. People were passing me; a mass of humanity, colors, races, ideologies mingling by in waves. It seemed as though a thousand languages reached my ears and smells of roasting meat came to me. Nausea tore at my guts and my stomach-- in a convoluted mess-- emptied itself across my shoes. How I arrived here I couldn’t say. What I’d been doing was -–likewise- - a mystery. All I knew was pain, confusion and that I was in the grip of an existential panic. Meltdown plagued me… and still the throngs on the colorful streets trundled past me, seemingly unaware of my drunken, chaotic and deteriorating mental state. The pills I had taken- like a handful of ‘Skittles’- made me numb and unable to feel my legs…I stumbled and careened down the sidewalk periodically leaning against light posts and such to wipe my face and get a grip on myself. I saw wads of chewing gum on the concrete sidewalk blackened by the countless summer seasons and boots that have trodden over them. I felt comforted by these forgotten wastes…I was of their kind. I was forgotten; a nameless, faceless hole in the city. I was a cipher in a land of concrete, chrome, glass and sex-ridden sensationalism. A land of make believe where no dreams came true and there really was ‘no place like home’. Peering under an overpass I saw red -spattered graffiti that called out to me of forgotten debaucheries, a mantra to pagan gods. Broken glass of brown, green and clear yellow littered the gravel.  I wanted to lay down and roll in it. “Breathe”, I found myself muttering, while looking into the storefronts that were selling the same tired things. Women rolled by en masse, draped in black polyester and silk. Burgundy -threaded gold pumps and Gucci bags with scarves of turquoise and cornflower yellow made the contrast all the more noticeable. The air became crisper, the dirty sunlight sagged onto my shoulders like a farmhands’ tiring load and I found myself winded and mumbling again. I saw a crumpled newspaper bounce by and felt its desperation. Its breeze-blown trip was halted by my foot, I scanned its headlines. “Baby –killer executed”, “Dow plunges for second straight day”, “War of attrition escalates”, “AIDS killing millions exponentially in Africa” I screwed my shoe onto the ugliness I read there and twisted its print into torn ruin. Gods! Shuffling down the broad expanse of urban street, I saw myself reflected in the glass windows as I passed into the bowels of the city. I wanted a drink…seemed like a great idea. Only a lush like me would awaken from a blackout & proceed directly to finding a bar! Even the store mannequins seemed bent, depressed and dressed in ill-fitting clothes. The air held little except a sense of desperation. Desperation. Emptiness. I knew those particular feelings well. I am Ozzie. My story may be your story. I know that some of the details will differ, yet the unfulfilled longing, the black hole and all-consuming emptiness is shared. We are one and the same. We have skin; bones, brains.  We function with varied peculiarities, yet most of us share this terrible need for ‘something other than this’….and it will possibly remain –forever-unrealized. I am no longer that empty husk. I am no longer that monster. I have come a very long way. I have been clean & sober for three years. I've never been more at peace in my entire life. I may not have much in worldly possessions, but I have quite a bit where it counts... I just thought I'd share that with everyone. I never have hidden my afflictions. I am only as sick as my secrets. I have become a positive force in life. This has been my greatest accomplishment. If you have the same problems, just remember... you are not alone. Get help, get better & skate. Thanks- Ozzie

item.title: Supper-bowl Sunday
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Most skaters don't care about the Superbowl. We are not really into football. I know that I am not. Jocks had made my teenage years in Pennsylvania a living hell & I've never really subscribed to their point of view, with the Budweiser, locker- room mentality that is all pervasive in organised sports. Growing up, I was a pariah... an outcast. At this point, I think I will stay that way. There was a van with a heavy crew of round wall rippers headed up from San Diego, piloted & led by David Hackett. The van included some of the greatest exponents of vertical skateboarding on the planet. They had wanted to ride pools but I couldn't accommodate such a large crew except here at Ridiculous.
They decided to hit Lances first then maybe come our way. I was going to meet them at Lances, but had previously arranged for Scott Coopers rain out session to take place Superbowl Sunday. We had invited a bunch of other riders as well. I stayed put & bought some food & drinks... washed down the pool & waited. It wasn't long before the house was full & we were having our kind of fun. Music vibrated through the yard. Smiles were everywhere. There was probably thirty plus people in and out during the day. Salba came & fought the good fight on his birthday. He spent the session killing himself to get onto the VSL (very short list) of those that made it over the stairs. I'd like to say he emerged victorious. It was a long afternoon for him.
Josh Skreech Sandoval was there & rode better than anyone on the planet. He is a truly gifted human being. I think he is one of the best pool skaters ever! It was intense. Dusk was coming & the San Diego crew contacted me to say they had just finished Lances & were opting out. It was cool. We had a bunch going on anyway. Dave Reul showed up & ripped it then played some Hank Williams songs as the sun burnt itself into the sea. John Torchia brought a huge bag of delicious OG carne asada for the grill, we cooked hot dogs & Louisiana hot links as well. It was a rad day & after we rode the bowl, we fed everyone supper. Someone told me that the Green Bay Packers won the Superbowl & I just stared at them blankly. I don't know about anyone else, but I think we were the winners on Superbowl Sunday. Thanks to Brandon Wong for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: 'Swallows': a porn pool problem ?
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Most women love skateboarders. They should. We are the coolest things on the planet. Some women get near a skater & you can almost hear their ovaries rattle. Many skaters love porn... but more on that in a minute. Last week, I received a phone call from Tony Alva. We hadn't talked in a few days. We caught up on things & TA told me that he knew of a pool near his house. His friend-- Eric -- had told him of it. It was permission. It was also a swimmer, but we could drain & skate it. I told him that I would be there the next morning bright & cheerful. About an hour later, I received an email from Nick Gates of Broken Magazine. He said that he had a pool that needed to be drained & wondered if I could help. Of course! He gave me a guys name & number. Eric Staniford. I started putting things together. Unknowingly, we were all trying to get the same pool going. It was rad! I placed calls, made arrangements & a time was set up.
I called Kevin Burke & the next day, we drove to Los Angeles. The house was in a sleepy canyon. A big stone wall surrounded the property. It kept the place away from prying eyes. The air was cold as it was early. Huge trees overshadowed the pool. It looked like a sun-splashed, little blue wonder. The pool sprawled out from the patio- glistening. Eric & Nick were there with their friend- Jessie Hotchkiss. We grabbed the pump & set everything up. My Yamaha pump is the absolute ruler! It can remove 260 gallons of skateboard-inhibiting water a minute. I call it 'The Straw From God'. I told the guys this & they smiled but I don't think they understood. They soon would!
My pump started & I stick tested the pool. It seemed pretty good. The lip curled around and up in the morning sun. The hip was cocked out smoothly to one side. The box was slightly out of reach. I ran my hand over the smooth skin. As I stick tested it, I noticed it seemed a bit vert-like pretty far down the trannies & this worried me. I also felt the plaster under the water. I was dismayed to see a heavy white film on my hands. Damn! We were going to have to scrub while we drained & probably CLR the pool to remove the paint scum film. If not, the pool was going to be like an ice skating rink. We continued with the draining & cleaning.
Eric & I, left to go to the store & buy coffee & CLR. Enroute, I questioned him about the pool, the porn & how that all came about. " It all started with a Dominatrix." He stated wryly. "One of my best friends in Florida is now known as --Mistress Baunfire. She was a model for the website-Deviant Nation. When I moved from Florida in 2008, Deviant Nation was a major competition site with another website-Suicide Girls- showcasing sexy naked tattooed girls. I was a staff photographer." I nodded & remarked that naked tattooed girls are generally pretty sexy as far as I was concerned & such a line of work seemed pretty interesting. He smiled & continued. "This introduced me to many models in L.A. Even after the site's collapse, I was being contacted to shoot for the models as a freelance portfolio- building photographer. The model --Aries-- asked that I shoot some portfolio shots at her friends house. This friend was Hustler Porn Star- Jayme Langford. "
"At her home, we shot some images of her in the dog pen and the full pool. I saw the pool and my first thought was "I have to drain this." I shot the portfolio photographs at the house. After months of planning, taking photographs for Jayme and asking a lot of questions, I got the okay from Jayme to drain the pool." I smiled. Eric had played 'the long game'. Sometimes, time takes time. We gathered our supplies at the store & were on the way back to the pool. Eric told me that he hadn't been able to get the pool drained. He trolled it around & finally I took the bait. Quickly, we were back at the porn house.
In less than two hours & it was no longer a swimmer. It was now in a state where it could be utilized for a wholly different purpose. After it was empty, I began a thorough inspection. I felt the face wall with my foot, dragging it down toward the drain. I immediately noticed a jolt. The wall bellied out. Not a good sign. I thought we might be able to carve across it wide & minimize its abruptness. TA showed up. Some other pals came as well- Pat & Erdy. We sat talking & let the pool dry. We had CLR'd the pool & scrubbed it. The paint film came off milky white.
Being as it was a porn house, jokes started flying. 12 year old adolescent banter quickly filled the air. Someone called the pool, "Milk Bone" which brought quite a few howls of laughter. Kevin Burke sealed the deal when he named the pool, "Swallows". Perfect. We let the pool sit & then took a few runs. It was tight & tiny. The kink on the face wall was very difficult to get over. A few of us grinded it & photographs were taken. I looked around & smiled. We were at the porn pool.
We had drained it, cleaned it & now we were riding it. It was imperfect, like much of the world. It sounded like a dream come true for most skaters. Here we were. A sunlit Los Angeles morning. The murky, exotic world of beautiful porn actresses. OG Tony Alva. A permission pool to skate. Good friends... and the pool ended up being less than cooperative. For some, the pool would seem a problem. When I looked around, I quickly saw what I already felt inside. It didn't matter if the pool was great or not. What mattered is that we did what we did. The look on everyone's faces & the vibe told the story far better than I ever could. As I looked around, I could see that there was no problem at all. Thank you to Eric Staniford & Nick Gates for setting it up & the porn girlies for letting us in. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: I'm going anywhere but here...
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_6296" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="forkliftboy"][/caption] Tired. I tire of the struggle. The abstemious and solitary life is difficult. I have done so much, for so long, with so little, that I can do anything with nothing. I was driving the forklift...  it's called an OP. It has a platform on the back & you can raise up to fifteen feet above the floor of the warehouse. It is a great tool for reaching things far up. I was standing there, putting big wooden doors away. I looked out across the building. Rows & rows of unending stuff, was stretched as far as I could see. I thought, "How did it come to this?!" By the time I put the doors away and returned to the floor,  I couldn't find a single reason to want to stay. The hours are terrible, the pay negligible & the only redeeming thing is my co-workers. The people are cool. I think that I'm ready for a different line of work. I have already put the plan into action. This job reminds me of a really bad pool. It looks good from a distance but --under careful scrutiny-- I see the kinks, cancer, pitfalls & muck. I'm going anywhere but here. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Pil pool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Back in 1983-1984, we discovered and skated our first pool. Here-- we learned how to go over the light, smash, crash, hit the hip, etc... For us this was around 9th-10th grade. Right next door to this house was a dirt BMX track. Well, we found the pool more interesting at the time. We had this pool for a good 6 months at least! A friend from Jr. High in the city of So. Pasadena shared this pool with me and other locals. It was a great spot for partying at the time and taking our licks. We called it the PIL pool. Someone put the sticker up, thus the name. Back then we did our best. No f/s airs or any of that, just pure fun and rolling around in the pool. This pool put the bug in me and has lasted ever since. My buddy and I, headed south after we got a few years older and hooked back up 25 years later or so. Since then, we have skated a good 20 or so pools in the last couple of years. It's great to see a bro from back in the day, that still wants to charge like I do. We are in our 40's now and have the skate stoke just like way back when. The lady at the house was kind enough to let me into the yard and take a look at the pool a couple years ago. It's still there. It's just a nice pool frame with sod covering. Good times remembered and more good times in store!
Photos Mike "Screwloose" Korner and Mark Phillips

item.title: "...my state of mind."
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I worked until I was broken & cold. It was late... dawn was closer than dusk. My life slipped backwards... I squinted into the headlights on the freeway. My eyes & brain were burning. Sleep. Oblivion. I wanted to go away. Tom Hanks. Castaway. No people or speech. My current life --seemingly-- is in disarray. I wish I was able... and stable. Sometimes, I think I'm really fractured & I've lost all the parts. Incapable of repair. I tried sleeping; a restless paper tiger under a wool blanket. My heart kept getting in the way as it bled on my sleeve. I awoke. Silence. The world held its breath. A spider slowly crawled across the ceiling. I think he looked at me with disdain. "What are you doing down there?" No matter how low you go, you can always find someone to look down upon. I read a short passage in a book by- Norman Vincent Peale. He wrote of a quote by Dr. Karl Menninger. "Attitudes are more important than facts." I suppose we can change only certain things in our day to day lives. We certainly have no control over others! A friend once told me that "I only give up control in order to get a better grip!" Needless to say, I see him often. His therapy appointment is immediately following mine... If I can change anything, it will have to be my attitude. I must never take counsel of my fear. My doctor at the VA hospital recently told me that there wasn't too much wrong with me... except my thoughts! Funny guy. I gave him the finger. He gave me one right back & told me.. "don't change a thing." I guess it's like the song I heard recently by Anna Ternheim. 'Today is a good day.' It's all in how we define our state of mind. Skate- Ozzie
It's just a matter how i define My state of mind.
Today is a good day
Just a scratch on my ego I get up in the morning With a good plan tomorrow I'll be keeping my mind cold Until the evening When the hours forget me and The waiting awaits me and voices of madness from my subconscious singing songs of the sadness Today is a good day.- Anna Ternheim

item.title: Royal Love
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Being as tomorrow is Valentines, I thought I would tell a pool story. It's about a love... of sorts. I have a theory.  It's better to be the hunter than the hunted. It started out as a rain day grid search. Riverside Shawn & I  loaded up the pumps & various tools needed to do this thing that we do. 'Mi Numi'. We left under an iron sky. Dark clouds hung thick & close to the hillsides. We drove & found a few unmentionables. We were having little luck. Shawn suggested a drive over into an area that we seldom search. I nodded & banked the truck hard to the right. The off ramp went down & the freeway went up. We looped about & found ourselves crawling through a 1950s neighborhood that squatted flatly in the shadow of the freeway overpass. The area reeked of poverty. I saw faces dark with fear. The sidewalks were drowning with the destitute. It seemed that people waited ... for nothing. We stopped to look at a potential foreclosure. The rush & snarl of the highway traffic came to me from the nearby roads. I pulled myself up over a block wall & squatted on top. I was frosty... every nerve alive. I assessed for threats. I listened for noise & dogs. Nothing. I jumped inside. An old Anthony left-hand kidney pool lay tiles-deep in black muck. I stick tested it & found a huge love seat pinching the face wall. The shallow transitions were like a shoebox. Dejected, I went out & we drove away. We were cruising a side street & Shawn nudged me... pointing to my left. I saw the top edge of a blue sliding board jutting above an ornate decorative block wall behind a house. We turned left & drove around to the front- facing street. We laughed & my pulse quickened because as we pulled up to the front of the house where we saw the pool slide, we noticed it was empty. We checked for any sign of people or possessions. Nothing. Foreclosure. I hopped the wall & cut the lock. We had found a good Royal pool. It was a strange shape but the transitions looked stellar. We grinned & decided to empty it right there. The skies were ominous but we drained it regardless. As we emptied it, I kept looking at the love seat. I have always had a hangup about going over love seats. In years past, I couldn't stay on my skateboard to save my life. Skating over one... just  seemed too much for me. I had been afraid. I pulled this one in about six tries just as it started to drizzle. Those conquer, who think they can. Shawn put his trucks on coping  & we were stoking. The pool was challenging because of its weird shape. It was fun. I came back a week or so later with Ray Zimmerman & Jake Reuter. We had a rad session & these are the pictures. I wanted to do the death box frontside, so Jake & I tried. He sailed over it & I landed my next one as well. It was his first real love seat that day & my first love seat grind. The Royal Love was good to both of us.  "Fear is never a reason for quitting; it is only an excuse." - N.V. Peale. So this is the story & this is where it ends. Thanks to Shawn, Jake & Ray Zimmerman. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: I'm getting weird...
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I ran today... I worked out. I have been sick & haven;'t had the energy,.. until today. I watched a film that has been banned for years... Uhm, it was a liberation of a Concentration camp taken by the allies... I was shocked & sickened by the depravity of my fellow man. It made me want to die in shame. Hoess stated that "does a ratcatcher think its wrong to kill a rat?" They had to Bulldoze bodies into huge ditces..... BULLDOZE!! are you fucking kidding me?! I almost wept.... and everyone wants to forget... how can we forget lest we risk its horrible repetition. The rate of recidivism on hatred is usually 100%... we are totally lame.

item.title: aesthetics II
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Everyone is an explorer. How could you possibly live your life looking at a door and not open it? --Robert D. Ballard
I love to explore & find pools. I really love the aesthetics of swimming pools. I love the shape, the curving lip. I love the palm trees whispering overhead in the breeze. The light blue tiles & the death box remind me of being a kid & looking at Skateboarder magazine. I would lay on my bed while snow piled up thickly against my windows. Jay Smith was pictured. He was balled up tight, knees tucked to his chin, lapping a frontside grind onto a hip in a San Fernando valley pool. I saw the cactus & palms in the background. The blue tiles & deep end radius mocked me in my winter sleepy season. I wanted to be there with Jay. I love hunting for pools. It is a passion.
I have found that many people really don't have passion for things... except escape. I understand that all too well. Passion dies in people, as the weight of responsibility & the desire for respectability dwindles that once- bright flame of discovery. It is sad. However, people must be allowed to live & let live. Who am I to say? I am speaking from observation. I have seen friends be so very passionate about things... art, creativity, change & ideals. As they grow older, this seems to die & excuses flow from their tongues at every opportunity. Its as if they are trying to convince themselves & justify their own neglect of everything that once made life beautiful for them. I guess needs & passions change. Life: it's a heavy burden.
I admire pools & the way they were built back in the 1950s & 1960s. Pasqual Paddock, built some of the first 'inverted dome' pools in Bel Air & Beverly Hills back in the 1930s... He had tried making pools square but the California soil was unable to contain & hold the form & water. The pools fell apart for some reason. Maybe construction has changed since then. Once he made the inverted dome pools & found that they worked, he started developing differing shapes. Kidneys, capsules & amoebas followed. Pool companies took the ideas and ran with it. They added slides, palm trees & gave people a miniature oasis in their backyards. An aesthetic was born. It is this aesthetic that I have come to love. It is my passion. Some pool riders collect light plates & various items from pools. We have a funny rule on light plates. Find it, drain it, grind it, claim it. Otherwise, it's a no-no. But, that's just us and even we don't always adhere to it. Funny. Anyway, here is a few images I have collected. Aesthetics. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: RTMF Bowl / Red Bull Generations
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: On December 14-19th the Red Bull Generations contest was held in Brazil at Pedro Barros bowl. It was a contest bringing together three generations of riders: Legends, Pros and Ams. The event was quite a success. My friend Heverton Ribeiro sent me some images that he took & I am thankful. Enjoy. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: monster
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: The media followed his work. They took to calling him a 'maniac' and other such hurtful things. He shrugged at himself in the mirror. There was something wrong with his face & he turned away. After he painted a hotel room with that girl & left her incomplete a month ago... they started with the name- calling. He was confused & his head hurt. He heard whispering & looked up at the ceiling in pain. Didn't they know that he would never do something like that to dogs or real people!? His guts were gnawing & cramped. He was starting to crave Dahmers bounty. He never saw his sickness in diagnostic terms. No labels. He read widely. He was part anti-social, part narcissistic, part histrionic, part god-what-have-you... yet he was none of these things for far too long. He was definitely not the sum of his parts. He would never change unless he wanted something. He was whatever his particular audience wanted him to be. Normal things didn't prime his pump. Like the song says, ".. I get my kicks above the waistline sunshine." He knew early on that this was his way. Furtive, dark, feverish, frenzied, immoral, unspeakable, then tucked away in the secret places of his mind. To him, life crawled by in steel coffins, rattling trains, shrieking horns, hurried faces scurrying toward some unfulfilling obligation, propelled by a sense of responsibility. Most folks tried to appear normal & upstanding in the eyes of people they could barely stomach... life truly seemed an exercise in futility. He idly wondered why people function the way they do.  When stripped of all their self-bought trappings & hubris, he knew they all ended the same. Gurgling. He shuffled across his room & ran his fingers over a glittering glass bottle of Stoli vodka ... then decided against it. He had built himself with cruel purpose. He needed a clear head. Soon, he would sit among the gruesome lifeblood... pumped across the walls like some medieval painting of the gods. Surely,  there would be no gods there. Just the man sawing with the silver blade in a frenzied motion. He reached for his shirt & jacket. He needed to gather his art supplies. He wondered where he would find her tonight. Cutting people was best. They stopped talking & all were the same inside. Thanks to ScabbedAngel for the image. - Ozzie

item.title: bart
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: In the summer of 2008, I phoned Salba. I was living in the Signal Hill area of Long Beach and was planning an early morning drive & recon of the Badlands. He asked when I was coming out & gave me a few addresses & streets to grid search. Early the next morning, I found myself driving into the sun. Trucks & cars vied for supremacy over each other, in the long dull drive to whatever fate awaited them. I smiled. I had other things going on. I was on the hunt. In a few hours, I had found this huge amoeba pool. It was deep with black water. There was a Bart Simpson doll in the yard. I sat him up so he could watch. I didn't hesitate & set up the pump & hoses. The pool turned out to be fast & smooth but very steep in the deep end just left of the light. I put Bart Simpson in the deathbox. He kept an eye out. We rode it briefly & the real estate folks quickly threw a garden hose into it. The next week, I came by & the pool was half filled again. Bart was floating face down. I guess he swims in the same deep dark water as the rest of us. The filter & pump were not functioning & the water was already starting to grow algae. I pumped it out again & rode it the next day with Sam Reed & Adam Morgan. A week later, people moved in. It's a swimmer now but I will always remember the Bart Simpson.

item.title: Ralph
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: The tremor began in Ralphs right leg & moved up into his chest. He coughed & his lungs heaved once... then twice. He opened his eyes & groaned. He tried to move but was unable. His eyes were sticky & his vision blurred. He felt like he was looking through thick ice. He strained his eyes downward & saw the brown leather strap across his ribs securing him. He then felt the leather straps holding his wrists & ankles. "Ughhh!" Realization hit him. He'd been in this situation before. His mind was cottony & thick... his thoughts confused & scattered. The old Cherokee Indian was gone. Ralph had lost track of him in his mind somehow. He came to him sometimes... he told Ralph things. The wrinkled old Indian sang songs of pagan nights amid sparking fires.  Periodically, Ralph had joined him on the thirsty hunt.  Ralph forgot about the restraints & tried to move his arms again ... cursing at his immobility. He bucked the straps. His voice & grunting sounded echo-like. He smelled chemicals... disinfectant. "God!. Thirsty... "  Sweat poured from him. The ceiling mocked him with its chipped & pale painted skin. Ralph thought of lungs & rusty coat- hangers. Bloody. Bubbling. A voice called to him. It was nearby. He heard it in the corner behind his head. "Ralphy.... I know what you are ..."  He strained & gibbered. His eyes rolled back & upward, straining to see the source of that sibilance. Ralph yelped then as a thick black worm crawled across him. Its rows of teeth gnashed & its wet mouth took sharp chunks out of his shirt.  Ralph--  spasmodically --chewed at his tongue, as the worm squirmed up across his neck & crawled into his ear. "Ralphy...  I am here to help."  ...  it  purred. The worm took up residence.  A scream sounded throughout the room.  It wailed like a lost soul among the seven hills of Hell. Ralph could not know that it was his own.

item.title: Minds eye.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: The hand hit him hard. Adams baseball cap went sailing across the kitchen, while his eyes & face burned. He pulled himself away from the cool linoleum floor---scuttling crab-like--- away from his mothers kicking feet. He spotted his 'Orioles' cap in the corner and foolishly wished he could lie there with it-- forgotten & still. "You little fucker!" She shrieked & spat. Adam howled when her foot connected with his battered ribcage. Floundering around the kitchen, he pushed a chair between the two of them and scurried around the table. Adam bounced off of a door frame and careened down the long dark hallway. He took the stairs two-at-a-time, mewling softly, hands holding his ribs tightly. His eyes & face felt like they were on fire. As  he went into his bedroom, he listened for her, but evidently, she hadn't followed. He heard her slamming around the kitchen in her rage and 'bad nerves'. He paced his room, crying & cursing God & the devil below....in a continuous litany. Adam stopped, as he suddenly realized that he'd pissed himself. Removing his wet jeans & changing, he curled up on the floor by the radiator. In total mind-numbing humiliation, he wondered when it would end. One of the things that Adam waited for, was the inevitable patter of his mothers feet on the stair tread, as she'd come crying & clutching at him. She'd hold him against her, in her tight, acrid sweaty grip, slobbering her tears and snot all over him. She would weep about her 'nerves' and how sorry she was but, "Why did he provoke her so?" As if this was Adams idea all along. He would stare at the blue embroidered flowers on her apron & hang in her arms like a tattered flag...drooping & lifeless. He would think of something...anything but this. He added another brick, and pretty soon nobody would get in. Adam lived behind a self-made barricade. He swore that he'd never grow up & be like her.... His skateboard stood against the wall. His salvation. Always there. Always ready. Rolling wheels. Freedom. It was just him & it. No angry words or draconian punishment. His was a world of darkness. In his  mind, he lived in a dystopia;  wrapped in a blanket of Christian family and hard-working American values. "Such a lie" ....he mumbled.  Pulling on his jacket, he looked briefly at his reflection in the mirror. His eye was partially swollen & he felt mangled. He reached for his Santa Cruz 5-ply with its big soft Kryptonics wheels. Freedom. Escape. The door closed behind him.

item.title: restrained
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Mustiness. Cold sterile walls. Metal locks & thick windows. Shuffling. Vacant eyes. Plastic trays, institution food  & despair. I saw & felt these as I hurried to the lock-down unit to start my shift. I approached the door of the crisis unit & looked through the small window. Sometimes patients rush the door & attempt to escape as staff unlock & enter. I peered through & saw it was clear.  I entered. Purgatory...  Our unit handled only the most dangerous & deranged patients. The psychotic. These poor people were dangerous because they could not differentiate between the real world & the imagined. They saw, heard & felt things.... often, these things were not very good.  Hallucinations, delusions & paranoia were the norm. I heard the screaming & involuntarily shivered in spite of myself. Dr. C looked over at me & said nothing. He shrugged & raised an eyebrow as if to say, "Sounds about normal for this place on a Monday morning." I didn't share his cavalier attitude. One of my co-workers saw the questioning look on my face & jerked a thumb in the direction of the isolation room & stated tersely, "Ralph."  I set my backpack down & looked at the assignment board. I had been assigned to take charge of him. I heard him wailing. Ralph was clearly lost to the living. He was certainly not a bedrock of mental stability. He'd been here before. He was what we referred to as a 'frequent flier'. I briefly rested my eyes on the doctor as his pen scratched & scrawled across his charts & papers. It was not right to dismiss  suffering in such a fashion. I guess Dr. C had seen this a million times. I heard him tell another doctor that the medication should be diminishing Ralphs psychosis shortly. We all hoped so. It was disconcerting to hear that soul-wrenching wail of mental torment. He sounded like he was being ripped apart by large horses. I checked the monitor that let me view directly into the isolation & restraint room. He was quieting down... panting, chest heaving, sweat-soaked. I walked in quietly & came up to where he could see me. His eyes were clamped shut as he watched his own particular demons march across his psyche & wreak havoc on his poor broken mind. I softly called his name. "Ralph." He opened his eyes & blinked numerous times. His eyes darted madly about. He couldn't seem to focus on me at all. "Is it...  Its  not in  here... Is it in here?! " he gasped. Ralph panted & peered behind me. Unknowingly, I must have taken a step back, as I felt the wall behind me. I stepped toward him again...  speaking  soothingly. " Who do you mean, Ralph? You are in the hospital now. My name is Ozzie. Do you remember me at all?" His eyes probed the room behind me... looking frantically. He mumbled incoherently &  I knew that he was still in the grip of his torment. He briefly mentioned 'It'  & bites he had received. He said it was behind me.  "It must be!" Not wanting to enter into his  madness with him, I told him that I believed that he saw 'it',  but that I hadn't worn my glasses & could not. He lowered his head & grimaced.... He seemed to calm a bit. I pulled a chair up to the bed & quietly sat by him.  Soon, his breathing slowed, he ceased struggling & slept.  I monitored him & read his current intake & case history. Periodically, I evaluated others on the unit & admitted a very paranoid Schizophrenic man. He thought that he was John the Baptist.  At days end, Ralph still slept under the peaceful umbrella of medications. It was a long shift. Later-- driving home-- I shook my head grimly. I didn't know why, but I always took my work home with me. It was terribly unhealthy.  I just couldn't leave my work at work. I was consumed. Foreboding. Something monstrous loomed on my horizon. At a stop sign on a nearby hillside, I looked out over the sleepy city. The night was a black blanket drizzled with diamonds- a lovers sky. I pressed on the gas pedal and --like the car-- tried to move forward. I wasn't feeling it.

item.title: nobody
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Sometimes I want to kick myself, for letting things go too far. I'm a fool in search of wisdom. I feel at home in the night. It is something that I cling to. Darkness & fear that follows. Walking in & crawling out. Easily led. Maybe we are just lost in this stupid life. ... trying to get out of our heads. Maybe.... I saw a lady crying today outside of the store. I asked her if she was okay. She answered, "No" and ambled off in tears. It left me twisted up. I could do nothing. I felt like I feel when I am broken & unable to fix myself. Nobody.

item.title: down the drain.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Skateboarders. We must be masochistic. Destroyed. I --like others of my kind-- learn through pain. I feel broken, like a misused toy. When I climb out of bed in the morning, my joints crack & I sound like some strange anatomical popcorn popper. I have used up more ice taking care of my injuries than I have ever used drinking glasses of whiskey. My liver tells me that I've consumed about half the whiskey in Ireland so... ! I only heal so I can hurt again. It's the game we play. While the world has their noses buried in TV, computer & cell phone screens, living their lives visually through others, skaters live our lives viscerally. We participate. Often such participation is at our own peril. In the eyes of the world, we always play the wrong card. The idea of sitting on a couch in front of a TV idly thumbing the remote, fills me with a self-loathing not easily transferred into language. People watch and believe the lies the TV continues telling us. "Only money will make you happy." " Only money will make you happy." Reprehensible. People buy the same tired things in the same boring fashion. Toe the line. Appear important. Go broke, appearing rich. Skateboarders reject such nonsense out of hand. Krishnamurti wrote, "The greater the outward show, the greater the inward poverty." I would have to agree. We walk our own path. Skaters have found the anti-authoritarian ideal that pervades skateboarding & the lawlessness of it, a warm embrace in a cold distant society. Like Peggy Oki said, "The differences between us feels very real." We continually battle with fear & ourselves. Society shuns us unless they are prostituting us for monetary gain or 'core' credentials... It's enough to make one sick. I battle with advancing age & physical decline. Injuries & societal norms have forced me deeper underground. I no longer try & explain myself. I am persona non grata in polite circles. I ride that useless wooden toy. I can't imagine my life without a skateboard. I wouldn't know how to live. . No drug, booze, sex or respectable endeavor has ever fulfilled me the way skateboarding has. It is lawless, unconventional & anarchist. I went into the military & served my country with honor, went to college & earned a degree, received a few letters after my name & gained the coveted 'respectability', yet remained empty... unless I skated. It is the one true gift of my existence and -- in the eyes of the world-- has sent my life straight down the drain. Until the distant shuddering stars burn out & all of the buildings crumble into the earth... I won't change a thing.

item.title: A day at Dave's
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: My pal Patricia (PK) wanted to roll someplace today. She was off work & wanted to skate. I tried to think of somewhere in between our houses & the 'Bible Bowl' came to mind. PK had never been there so I set up a session, phoned a few pals & met up today. The skies were blue & the sun spilled through the trees making really cool shadows everywhere. It was a fun session & everyone was pushing themselves. I -- as usual -- got super stoked & was my typical self. I encourage a bit too much it seems. PK took a high line in the deep end, put her trucks over & folded her ankle. Bummer. Dave grabbed some ice & I helped her out. She told me that it'll be awhile before she can ride. Get better... Cheryl drove up special from San Diego & threw down some grinds & Amy 'Frontside' Bradshaw lit it up as well. Jake & his pal Carlos came by & trucks were heard on coping. Everyone had fun.... That's what its all about... Thanks to Dave, the Bible Bowl and our pals ice & Motrin. Get well soon PK.- Ozzie

item.title: Extra Royal Love
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: The Royal Love is gone. Full & refreshing ... it's sad really. I preferred it 'empty & dangerous' ... but I've been that way inside myself so .... I guess some things are better- 'full & refreshing'. Regardless, a few pool pals had the chance to get a bit of love. I took Brandon & Kevin there one weekend. We were actually going to ride a different pool & found that people were there working on that particular house. I approached the workers. They were distinctly 'Anti'... They made it abundantly clear that no shenanigans were occurring while they were there! I walked away mumbling. "Can't get no love!" Then, I had a thought. I have all the love I'll ever need. So, I gave Brandon directions & here we are. These are the images. Thanks to the Royal Pool Company for supplying us with good loving. Thanks Brandon for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: hindsight
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_6457" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Tony Alva"][/caption] I am looking forward to looking back on this. I've been feeling everything these last few months. Without the soothing comfort of booze pissing down my spine, I really feel the entire experience of my life!  Some of it has been wonderful & other parts truly painful. When it hurts, it's like nails under my skin. I need some time.... I will be able to see with clarity & the distance that is required for things to be understood ... pain leaves & all that is left are scars & memories.  Some good & others... Why am I so impossibly impossible? I simply didn't get the 'chip' when I was hardwired.... Whatever. When TA was skating this pool, I bet he wasn't thinking of the future at all.  He was a bit ego maniacal... but those days have fallen into the mists of the past. He is a soulful guy. I asked him about this image... he recalled sessions & things but was pretty vague. When it's all good, perhaps we just accept it for what it is. A moment. Perfection. Another second of our life passing by with no thought for tomorrow...  Still, when there is pain & difficulties, those moments etch themselves into our minds all the more. It is this way for me. Anyway, enough nonsense out of me. Enjoy the J. Grant Brittain image, shed light on your better side & go skate- Ozzie

item.title: Bones Brigade
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Van Nuys. Lunchtime. Red brick buildings. Production assistants. Craft services. A film set. It was all here. Stacy greeted me with a smile- his long hair hanging in his face. He was holding a bowl of chicken, rice & vegetables. He wore faded jeans & scruffiness. He looked like he hadn't slept in awhile and quickly admitted that he was on a heavy deadline. In between mouthfuls of lunch, he gave me a hug & we caught up on things. Stacy pointed to a thick black curtain. " Go on in. Skip Engblom is just finishing." I nodded at Stacy & slipped inside. The aluminum girders & rigging on the set, framed the skateboard collection of Dale Smith & Todd Huber. I saw a Hobie Weaver Woody & smiled. Animal Chin stared out from a 'Have You Seen Him' poster. A TV hissed snow & static into the room. I peered about. Skateboards, trucks & wheels bled from the walls. Every era, everything, everyone. A day-glow yellow Powell-Peralta Double Beamer hung above my head. Perfection. I ran a hand over its edges & thought of Alan Gelfand. Jim Goodrich image- 1979. Timeless style.
A half-dismantled car sat askew in a corner with a skateboard sticking out of its windshield. It reminded me of the first street contests in the early 1980s. Lance & Steve Steadham ate lunch with the others. I walked through the set while everyone was out. There were old trophies on the walls. One dust covered trophy had an inscription. 'Rusty Harris Pro-Am, Skatepark Paramount. Most 360s- 3rd place'. Another- 1979 Skateboarder Poll- 'Coach of the Year.' It was awesome! After the interviews started again, I noticed a timelessness slip over me. My lifetime beliefs & everything I am, comes directly from what I was seeing & hearing. I felt like I was 12 years old again. Alan Gelfand came in & smiled. He sat next to me. I was happy. I skated with him at Cherry Hill in 1979. Ray Barbee & Lance took photographs as Mike McGill took the hot seat.
Mike talked about his start & reason for choosing skateboarding. He spoke of his feeling of isolation in Florida. Peering at the floor, Mike explained, "I felt like an outsider from day one. Once parks closed though, I never thought of quitting. Skating was just what I did. We had a relationship within the Bones Brigade & that always gave me something to look forward to." He built ramps & persevered. Mike talked about the feeling of being on the Bones Brigade. "It was the best! I had to do well in competition even though I didn't like them. I stressed. I even threw up behind the ramps sometimes." Stacy reminded Mike that Tony Hawk --in his interview--had spoke about the need for doing well in contests back then. Tony said that this was the only way to really succeed because videos were not yet available. Mike stated that he tried very hard & learned the 'McTwist' so he wouldn't drift away & lose his dream. "I had to invent a trick. I had to become known for bringing something new." Mike then spoke of learning the 'McTwist' & its subsequent impact. He ended by stating that, "Stacy was the glue that held us together. Without him, we wouldn't have been what we are."
His interview was stellar & insightful. The room took a break. Group photographs were taken. I sat & scribbled away. Lance was next. I looked around. Craig Stecyk was there along with a host of notables. The room grew quiet as Stacy & Lance reviewed a few things together. "Quiet. Rolling." Lance started by talking about his early start & reason for choosing skateboarding. For Lance, the 'movement' of skating is what did it for him. He said that, "I was miserable at everything I tried... until I skated." He spoke of being very magazine image-driven. " I loved the style & photographs. I liked the romantic idea of skateboarding." Stacy asked very good questions & Lance spoke on his history within the Bones Brigade. Lance stated that he felt like he didn't belong. "Once I was on the Bones Brigade, I felt like I had to prove something. I was on a team made up of the best. Prodigies. I needed to win a contest & prove that I had a right to be there." Lance went on to become one of the most popular riders. Stacy reminded him of this & his place in the Bones Brigade.
Lance spoke of his desire to do well & be an influence. He wanted to help others love skateboarding like he did. The interview grew serious & personal. Jealousies, grudges & travel stories were told. Everyone was moved & affected by the truth & heartfelt emotions brought into the interview. Lances words & honesty reminded us exactly why he is so admired by skaters worldwide. It was a great day & I feel blessed to have been included. I am looking forward to the finished product. We can be assured that it will be an awesome film. It will be a testament of the most influential team of skateboarders in the world. Thank you to Stacy Peralta, Lance Mountain & the others there today. Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: booking number: 11043110010
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="self flagellation"][/caption] Will someone tell me when this misery is going to end? I will go to sleep & wake when it's over, because I can't see much reason for the things that are happening to me. Sometimes, I don't know what I'm living for. The day started fine. The sun was out & birds  dripped from limb to limb,  pouring from the trees. They sang & answered each other. I loaded the truck with the pumps & assorted tools. Grabbing a coffee, I drove through the early light listening to Peter Yorn & scouted some pools. We would be riding on Sunday & I wanted a few fresh pools readied for the crew. At one potentially good left-hand kidney, I was struck with a problem. The house sat on the top of a hill with properties surrounding it on the hillsides below. If I drained the pool-- which was huge-- all the water would probably flood some yard below. That would not be a very neighborly thing to do. It would make for a bad day. The property was huge & the pool sat way back in the yard. It was a long way to the street.  I knew that I needed longer outlet hoses for the pool so I could get the water all the way out front to the driveway & gutters. I would check with Salba later & see if he had any extra. I left & drove around a bit more, checking a few old favorites & new foreclosures. Salba had told me of a pool nearby that needed to be checked. I cruised up a wide tree-lined street & banked the wheel of the truck. I soon found myself coming to a stop. I backed into the driveway of a faded foreclosure. The house was pale & lifeless. The trees sagged in the morning sun. It was a picture of emptiness. Whatever miracles of home & family that once existed here, were certainly long gone. I saw the locked gate & the pool beyond. It had a wooden frame over the entire thing. This frame was covered with plastic sheeting & a metal grid was stapled over it. I grabbed my three foot bolt cutters & was quickly inside the property. I  pulled back a bit of the plastic by the deep end & found that the transitions looked pretty good. There was very little water in the deep end. The plastic had done its job. I knew that I had to get inside for a better look. I took my bolt cutters & cut away a small area around the shallow end & shimmied down inside. It was like a sauna & mosquitoes quickly bit into me. I took  a few photographs & realized that the shallow transitions were kinked & the surface was pitted. It wasn't worth the work. Pulling myself up out of the pool through the hole, I saw shiny boots & knew the game was up. Police. The two male officers questioned  & immediately hand-cuffed me. They were pretty mellow & seemed like they were going to let me go.  They looked through the images on my camera & saw that they were all pool images. They looked through my truck & saw that there was nothing out of line. I have no record. Then, a female 'Watch Commander' arrived. I overheard them  explaining things & when she saw my bolt cutters, she started swearing. "This is bullshit!"  was one of the nicer things that flowed from her profane mouth. It turns out that this was her 'beat'. These guys were her backup. She called the shots.... and she did. She quickly had me placed into a cruiser after informing me of my lowly place in her grand scheme of things. "You need to act your age!" She spat this at me as if the words were leaving a bitter taste in her mouth. As they hustled me into a cruiser, I saw her frothing her fury & thumbing through my possessions. In about an hour, they had read me my Miranda rights & had the truck impounded. I winced inside as I watched the flatbed towing vehicle roll away with my truck on top. The male officers transported me to the correctional facility. I was searched, finger-printed, had photographs taken & was led to a stinking concrete cell & locked inside. My wrists were sore from the hand cuffs. I looked around in the cell. There were five of us & the faces that turned toward me were unfriendly. One sucked-up scrawny guy rocked in the corner mumbling to himself. He looked like a rumpled bag on a dirty sidewalk. It was a long day. I spent five or six hours in that reeking concrete cell. They finally let me out. They called us up one at a time, had me sign some forms, gave me a court date & my wallet then turned me out into the street. I had left my cell phone at home. I walked to a payphone & called Salba. His was the only number I remembered. He asked my room-mate Michael to come pick me up. It was almost dark. I phoned about my truck. It's going to cost me $349.00 to get it out on Monday. They kept the bolt cutters (obviously) & my camera or I would show you a few pictures of the pool. It was an expensive day. When you do this thing we do, it can be dangerous. People don't react well to someone found lurking in their yard. Dogs & violence are an ever-present danger. Law enforcement is as well. People have a misconception. They think that we just show up, sweep the pools out & grind away the afternoon.  People think that there  is no muck, filth,  danger or hard work. Well, I am here to show you-- as I often have-- that this is not the case. I took one for the team yesterday... and it really hurts. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: win some, lose some
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: About a year ago, Salba & Riverside Ed had found a big Blue Haven over in a nearby neighborhood. They excitedly told me about the deep end bowl & how perfect it was. I had to go to work, so I made note of its location & decided to drive there the next day. I couldn't get there that day but went by a few days later. A garden hose snaked along side the house & disappeared over the coping into the pool. As I approached, I saw that it was nearly half-full of water. I was bummed. They had been right. The transitions & bowl looked unreal. Again & again, time proves to be a great ally. This past winter, the house popped back up on the grid. Foreclosure. Salba & I drained it one weekday morning. It was a shit pit. Dog crap, broken glass & stinking refuse was shoveled away. The pool was subsequently sessioned for a few months but is now gone again. Here are some stellar images from the various sessions. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: acte cruauté
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
"... take me as I am, for I shall not change."- Marquis de Sade
For all of his shortcomings & reprehensible behaviors...the man might have been on to something. Let me explain. For those of you that are not familiar with him, the Marquis de Sade was a French nobleman who wrote extensively about his perverse sexuality & criminal exploits. His very position in the nobility allowed him to remain at large & hurt, maim & torture numerous people... but not for long. The Crown caught up with him & he was imprisoned for long stretches of his cruel & useless life. A scumbag is a scumbag-- no matter what sort of tinsel & pretty lace its wrapped up in. I read an interesting book by the German physician- ' Krafft-Ebing'. It is entitled 'Psychopathia Sexualis. In it, the Herr Doktor describes real case studies taken from patients throughout Europe in the mid 1800s. He describes all of their pathos & horror in excruciating detail. He is the person responsible for giving us the term 'Sadism'... after he reviewed the Marquis de Sade life story. A 'Sadist' is a person who tortures others for their sexual pleasure. It is not the torture itself, but the fear & suffering of the victim that gets these monsters off. Weird. The major point I am trying to make is his findings.
He found a 100% rate of recidivism. These inhuman scum are operating from the limbic system of their brains & will do it again & again ad nauseum... until incarcerated or killed. Sad. I wonder then, can we fundamentally change? Can we change our innate behaviors... sexual or otherwise? The whole idea of change is of profound importance. A person --that I know --was whining & cursing his luck. "Everyone's against me! The world is giving me nothing but bad luck & it follows me everywhere!" He looked over at me ... as if seeking my support & affirmation. I said nothing. He asked me "What's wrong?" I replied somewhat testily.. "YOU! You're what's wrong!" We can change our appearance, location, home & job.. but we always end up bringing ourselves along into the mix. Can we change? I don't know. I try. I am at a constant war in the fight to find my true self. I hammer myself with iron will & determination. I am spartan & stoic. Yet... have I changed? I am unsure. My responses to things are clearly healthier. I attempt to think of others before myself.. at all costs. Sometimes, I fail. Sometimes, I get in my own way. I am my nemesis. A life without vice. The unforgiving void.
I guess there is nowhere to go, when you're drowning in a river. I leave my house where I am doing time. I walk up into the hills & trees. It seems hostile up here. It's eerie how silent the woods become. The birds cease chattering & the animals raise their small brown faces & peer intently into the gloom. Damage. Danger. Decay. It's all here in winters hungry engine. Change occupies my mind. I wonder. I think. Alone. Darkness descends across the tragic treelines. I stop on a nearby ridge & peer out over the city below. A distant helicopter circles hungrily... its headlights probing & fucking the city below. Humanity. I continue down the path & as I'm swallowed by the night.

item.title: BD Wong
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Brandon Wong was having a difficult time. He was trying to choose photographs for his upcoming photo exhibition which was approaching quickly. Like all talented young artists that are fairly new to their field, Brandon had reservations. Was there enough quality work for an exhibit in the first place? Was the work good enough? Would anyone even come? The committee of 'misgivings & self-doubt' plague all of us. I get the same thing sometimes when writing something important. It's human to be human. We all carry such a committee around in our heads. They --sometimes-- tell us we aren't good enough etc etc... It's a good thing that Brandon chose not to listen to the committee. Brandon selected his images & had them enlarged & mounted. He spent a long night attaching & placing them in the gallery. It was held at Tattered Photography & Design Studio in Anaheim. I arrived early & checked a few nearby neighborhoods looking for pools. Around 1:00pm, I drove back over. The gallery itself was small but well-suited. There was a carnival-type atmosphere around the place. Tents had been erected & skateboard rails & quarter pipes were strewn across the parking lot. Kevin Burke backed his big white truck into the parking lot & unloaded a serious kicker box. Skaters began launching themselves off almost immediately. A grill was lit at one end & burgers sizzled while the PA system echoed pop tunes. Young kids were in abundance & more than a few parents pushed mongo through he crowd. People had set up the tents as booths for the various businesses & artists that operate in the local area. We saw happy faces, tattoos, skateboards & fun. The weather was stellar & the day sparkled. Brandon need not have worried, as the turnout was excellent. Old & new friends arrived to browse through the gallery & view the images he'd prepared. I overheard many comments regarding his great ability to convey feeling & the 'vibe' of the particular session. He has a keen eye & wonderful sense of composition. It was good to see & mingle with everyone. Thanks to Brandon Wong for the great work & exhibition. Thanks to Ray Zimmerman for the images of the event. Skate & support your friends. - Ozzie

item.title: On any given Sunday
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
The sunlight glittered off the ocean as I eased through traffic on the PCH in San Diego county. It was Sunday morning. There were joggers, people walking & bicycles everywhere. I stopped at the Pannikin & had some coffee, then headed out to see Bucky. He lives in the Encinitas area, but as I was driving out there, it seemed far removed from the row-on-row, sun-baked cottages & general grittiness so prevalent by the ocean. Giant trees & heavy undergrowth hung on the rolling hills & large houses on walled properties spread out into the distance. The area spoke of privacy & affluence. Family. Tradition.
I downshifted & nosed the truck around a hairpin turn. Horse trails & an Equestrian riding club meandered off into the treeline on my right side. I saw dark brown horses running in the morning sun. I seemed to be far from the beach. Slowly cruising up the sleepy street at Buckys house, I smiled to myself. I was very happy for him. He has come a long way from his humble Baltimore roots. A product of the Maryland watersheds, Bucky has been through all of the ups & downs associated with the skateboard community & its often -- volatile-- industry. Skateboarding can eat its own. I approached his home.
A huge stucco wall loomed on my right hand side. Giant palm trees hung under the sun & draped over the top of the wall. The house shaded itself within. I pulled past, noticing the automobiles that squatted across the driveway. Glass, chrome & polished silver metal. Freedom at light speed. They glimmered. The cars looked like powerful angry animals. Bucky races cars & he's become quite good at it. The air was still & quiet prevailed. I walked up the trail toward the bowl which perched on a hillside above the house. Mature landscaping separated the two. Purple bouganvilla & birds-of-paradise bloomed all around. A regular swimming pool glittered wetly below. A few childrens toys lay abandoned & contrasted with the green lawn. It appeared much like any other well-to-do family home out here in the area... yet I knew different.
This was the home of one of the greatest exponents of vertical skateboarding on planet earth. As I looked around, I was struck by something. I noticed a hawk circling the property below. I smiled. Bucky has a great group of loyal friends for a good reason. He is down-to-earth, humble & approachable. Bucky is the kind of person that looks you in the eye when he speaks with you. He listens. Bucky seems very grounded to me... as are most of the people he skates with. On any given Sunday, these friends can be found trudging up the bark -mulched path towards the bowl. Smiles are evident & an easy camaraderie prevails. Bucky told me that his bowl is his salvation sometimes. He can have his friends over to skate, relax & work on tricks & lines.
