On Sunday, he can leave his frantic, travel-filled busy life behind for a few hours. Friendship. Rolling. Fun. These are the reasons most of us started skating in the first place. Bucky has never lost sight of this.
After awhile, the Sunday crew begins to converge. I padded up & cruised the bowl before the A-Team arrived. It's heart-hammering fun. Paul Wisniewski, Owen Neider, Jeff Hedges, Tom Remillard, Peter Hewitt, Scott Taylor, Chris Conway, Tony Mag, Mike Owens, Zach & Chris Miller, Bucky, Cookiehead & Alphonso Rawls all lined up to cut speedy lines through the concrete corners. I looked over & saw Germ & Neil Blender walk up & take a seat. I overheard their animated conversation about the session. I asked Neil what he was up to. He told me that he was ".... watching. World watching." He laughed as Peter Hewitt heckled Owen Neider. "My how things have changed." I nodded as I thought of the stories I had heard of Owen, giving Peter & others a hard time when they were groms at the Del Mar Skate Ranch. Tough love. Role reversal. Tough love becomes mutual respect.
Bucky had stretched out & was carving the bowl at warp speed. It was almost like he couldn't differentiate between his time at the oval racetrack & his time inside his bowl. Two became one. The lines blurred. Bucky hit the lip with slob fastplants & alley-oop FS nosebone airs. Gosh! His sheer technicality & ability to string together the most difficult combinations, make Bucky Lasek what he is. Amazing. Chris Miller was just starting to skate again. He had been injured snowboarding, but it didn't really seem to affect him in any fashion. He still went fast, smooth & huge. The man can truly ride a skateboard! Gifted. Perfect style. Flow. No wasted movement. Zach Miller crushes it & his 'crooked cop' airs are something to be seen & appreciated. He is his own man. I like Zach. Good people. T-Mag pulled some huge airs & flowed fast through the pool. He is a vert master. Jeff Hedges stood up some of the tallest inverts of the day & everyone was happy to see it. Tom Remillard stood on 5-0 grinds through the corners & his tailslides were mind-numbing. Peter Hewitt would come to the Mission Valley YMCA back in 1999. He would ride the 110 foot vert ramp there. I ran the place & never could understand how Peter could run out of room on that ramp... but he did! He'd fly right off the end. At Buckys bowl, he didn't disappoint. Mach-5 speed & edge-of-the shoe airs were in the bag.
Mike Owens is a bad mamba-jamba. He's coming up strong. He tore the big pool into small pieces & it was great to see new blood in the mix. Scott Taylor, Paul Wisniewski & Owen Neider are regulars at the pool & it showed. They rode fast & comfortably... at home on the big transitions. They stood out. All-in-all, it was an epic Sunday session. There are a few other regular visitors that come out on the weekends. Bucky has provided a place for his family to live & for friends to come over & have fun. They gather on any given Sunday to skate, eat & laugh. I am reminded of the east coast vert ramps of the 1970s & 1980s. There was respect & a sense of belonging. It was a sane place to go in a mad world, where misfit skaters could gather together & ride. Laughter. Creation. Barriers destroyed & friendships cemented. Ray Zimmerman & Brandon Wong were on the decks & taking photographs. I owe them my thanks here & now. "Thank you." Thanks to Bucky for making it all happen. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: having a few friends over
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Some friends of mine called me about a month ago. They had pals in town from back east & they wanted a Ridiculous session. Being the charitable & gracious fellow that I am, I made plans. We hosted a large group of heavies for a Saturday evening session under the lights. Words are unimportant when dealing with the particulars of the session. These guys were top shelf pool skaters & the images tell it better than I ever could. Thanks to Ray Zimmerman for the photographs. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Basic Bowl
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Morning. The Basic clover bowl sat dark gray & still. Its white painted coping was outlined in red. Stickers & banners hung in a tangled profusion everywhere. This was my first time back at the Basic bowl since 2000. It had been a very long time. The whole pool looked like God had punched it in the nose. The entire left side of the pool sat about two feet higher than the rest... it was lifted out of the ground. The pool tilted like a half-capsized canoe. The shallow end was sunken slightly. Yup! I was sure. God had punched it in the nose. There has always been a bit of rumor & grit attached to the Basic Bowl contests. Some were great, some were wild & others downright.... well, let's be kind-- "Decadent" There has been a bit of bad 'juju' associated with the contest as well. Someone passed away at the home last year & the contest was held regardless. The point is this: anytime a human life is lost... its a sad thing. In the organizers defense, having spent all that money & inviting & planning for the contest... It must have been a tough call either way. Who can say? Over the years, there has been a great deal of things associated with the Basic Bowl contests. Greatness, hardcore soulful skating, beers, friends, scantily clad females, hubris, decadence, pain, conflict, legend, myth, scandalous behaviors & --unfortunately--death. Who knows? Who cares? Maybe, we can flip it... But we have to want to.
We have to ask ourselves this pertinent question. Is the Basic Bowl contest worth saving? Well, I asked myself that very question over the preceding few days. I was on the fence. I almost didn't attend. I recall the early contests in the late 1990s. I pulled out a few old faded boxes & found my notes from the 1999 contest. It was interesting reading. There were "hundreds crowded around the pools edge". Grosso, Hewitt, Salba & Partain were on fire! The list of attending riders was a --veritable-- 'Who's who' of bowl riding elite. Basic Greg told me that the bowl was built in 1993. "It went like this... Belmars was built, followed by Chickens then Basic. Buddy Carr was a really big part of having the Basic Bowl built. We did it together-partners." I nodded as I recalled Salba telling me these details back in the 90s. According to the ugly rumor mill, Dave Reul lived at the house & wanted to ride so bad that he plugged up the drain & skated it. When it rained the next week, water flowed under the bowl & it lifted out of the ground.. damaging it. Dave Reul- "People want to blame me for that but I wasn't even around. G-man was at the house & called me. He heard the pool 'pop' out of the ground in a rain storm. He quickly filled it with water to push it & weigh it down. He probably saved the bowl by doing that."
At this point it matters little. The pool was certainly much higher out of the ground than the last time I was there ten years earlier... It is still rideable & fun. Its an Orange County icon by this time. I looked at the pool. God had punched it. Maybe he was telling us something. Sometimes the world breaks for good reason. It gives us all something to do. We can flip it & make things right. Let's hope we can before it is too late. Contest day. Groms were everywhere alongside parents. There were far less drunken flat-billers & tattooed 'brah-brahs' around (a welcome change). Sasha Steinhorst, Dave Duncan, Fish (thanks for the Cherry Hill button) & Eddie Reategui took command of the microphone & judging. In these capable hands, Christian Hosoi prayed an Easter blessing over the event & it commenced. I started feeling better. The crowd was behaved & there was very little weed smoke & beer drinking. It was all about the skating & the kids.
The groms went & ripped it. These kids worked the funky lines of the clover bowl & the crowd pushed them on. Duane Peters & Micke Alba were in attendance & it was great to see some of our sports pioneers... NOT turning their backs on the groms & the event. Respect. Grom- Wilcox ended up in the top spot followed by Colby Frantzen in second & by Seth Sanders in third. The amazing music of 'Phat Reggae Dub' was pumping through the backyard. The band issuper great & you should try & see them live. Good stuff! The girls rode & were well-represented. Julie Kinstrand held court & proved herself an OC mainstay. The other girls ripped as well. The AMS tore the pool next. Pint-sized powerhouse-Asher had ther judges & crowd yelling as the eight year old pulled lipslides & blew through the deathbox. The AM-jam grew hectic. Kalani David- BS lip revert & lien to tail into a well-deserved first place. He was followed by Dante Overton & Gage- second & third respectively. The Ams were the highlight of my day. This was a hardcore contest day, snaking jam session. There were two guys in the pool at a time... it was exciting. The Pro list was small but good. Jake Piaseki was there. He told me that he recalled the year Grosso ripped it in 1999 as being his favorite memory of the Basic contests. Jakes FS air hip transfers were 'Miller-esque'. Jeff Wright from Palm Springs crushed it & his rooftop bombdrop was insane! Johnny Abernathy killed it but received the short end of the stick. He should've placed higher. He did some insane stuff.... Francisco was super smooth but inconsistent. Reuler rules. His place at the Basic Bowl podium is a given. He cruised fast & smooth. It ended up - Jeff Wright in first, Jake Piaseki second & Reuler third. In closing, I noticed a good deal of things this day. I observe. I remember. I saw a great deal of positive on this contest day. I saw happy groms & parents. I saw less buffoonery & more hardcore roots-oriented skating. I saw Basic Greg stepping up to the plate for the 16th time & holding an event. Maybe we should put the past behind us. Maybe we should flip it. Maybe this was a good start, rather than a bad finish. Thanks to MRZ for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: good things don't change.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_6584" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Jack Lovell - Then: Hi Roller -Boulder Co. 1979"][/caption] My pal Jack Lovell rode in the Hester Series back in the day. According to him, "I shouldn't have even been in there." Jack was provided with some wonderful images of the Hi Roller contest from 1979 by a friend. He is sharing them with us. I have been questioning, Jack, Salba, Duane, Henry Hester, Olson & Malba, on their memories of the event. I am trying to have it done by Friday. Thanks to those involved. It's going to be a wonderful little piece of our--collective-- history. Thanks to Jack Lovell for the images. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_6585" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="Jack Lovell- Now: Roxborough 2010"][/caption]

item.title: November 20, 1998
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_6605" align="aligncenter" width="450" caption="OG Pipeline Combi coping, 98 Vans Combi plaster w/ tiles & opening night pass/invite"][/caption] San Diego. November 19, 1998. It was a Thursday evening. I had to work at Mercy Hospital that night. Andy Mac came rushing into my room --all smiles. I can still hear his voice. "Ozzzzzzzz ! Combi opening tomorrow night!" His eyes gleamed. It was a moment all of us had waited for. He then handed me a pass/ invite to get in. I was so stoked. Unfortunately, it proved to be a 'no go' for me. All the anticipation & stealth missions to watch construction meant little on opening night. As the city slept, I lost a patient to AIDS early that morning & it threw me off my game. He was 26 years old. I lifted my red-rimmed eyes to the morning sun but felt little... Sadness. Why? Questions. One could go mad in this line of work.  I came home. I couldn't sleep. I didn't feel too social. So, I ended up helping a friend move instead. Regardless, the Vans Combi opening was a success & everything that has followed has helped keep the flame lit & bowl riding in the public eye. In the photograph, you will see an original piece of Pipeline Combi coping, a few tiles & plaster from the 1998 Vans Combi & my pass/invite that Andy Mac gave me. I keep these, much in the same way I keep photographs...  to remind me of all the good in the past. The young man died but his suffering is over. There is good, even in the bad. Thus endeth the lesson. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: clear the deck
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Grant Brittain
BTO: What are the Pros & Cons of shooting the Protec? Grant: " It's good a few days before the contest but on the day of the Protec it's just good to watch! There's so much interference from I-Phone users trying to get their shots that it sets off my flashes. (laughing) Just kidding. I shoot with lights so it's perfect. Creatively,m there are so many angles to the pool that you can get a good shot."
BTO: Favorite memories?
Grant: "The time Chris Miller won. No wait! that was FIVE times that he won.... I just love watching him skate the pool... It's all really good.
Michael Burnett
BTO: What are the Pros & Cons of shooting the Protec?
Michael: " I get to meet new photographers from newspapers, clubs & Facebook & then see the newest techniques in 'Not- looking -through- the- viewfinder' photography. It seems a shame that everyone in the crowd can't get on the coping to take cell phone pictures. They should change that.. it would be good." ( both laughing)
BTO: Favorite memories??
Michael: "The time Mike Smith enetered & almost killed everyone. He was rolling in on people. It seemed really dangerous but was entertaining to watch."
Chris Ortiz
BTO: What are the Pros & Cons of shooting the Protec?
Chris: It's all great but if there was a downfall to it, I would say that there are too many people on the decks shooting & filming. It makes it hard to do a good job & get good photographs. It's an elite event & is onbe of the most anticipated events of the year. It should be shot by three or four photographers working together to get the best coverage.... that's about all.
BTO: Favorite memories?
Chris: "The skating. It gets better & better""
Anthony Acosta
BTO: What are the Pros & Cons of shooting the Proterc?
Anthony: " The hardest thing is watching. Sometimes I am in awe. I get distracted by the skating & forget I'm shooting... especially in the finals.. It's best seeing it live because you feel the enbergy. You can't feel that watching it on a screen. It's awesome."
BTO: Favorite memories?
Anthony: " My first year shooting the event for Vans, I hadn't met Steve Van Doren yet. I was walking around on the dck & Steve came over to me & pushed me over! He was like- "Getr ouyt of the shot!" He thought I was a poacher or something. I said, "I work for Vans!" He came vback latrer & said... "Sorry man." He gott violent. It was so sick!"
Brian Fick
BTO: What are the Pros & Cons of shooting the Protec?
Brian: The hardest thing ius avoiding all the wanna-be photographers that only shoot digital! I think the thing I like most is getting to skate with some of my childhood heroes & it then makes it easier to ask if I can shoot pictures of them. I skate with them first, then shoot photographs."
BTO: Favorite memories?
Brian: Every year it gets better & better. I love seeing the skating. Grosso, Duane, Schroeder... just being on a first name basis with these people is awesome."
Gerorge Crosland
BTO: What are the Pros & Cons of shooting the Protec?
George: Its the most fun & most challenging. Its always different. I've done it seven years now. Its hard being in the right place at the right time. You set up to shoot & the rider does the trick elsewhere. There is no other event like this one. It's the best.
BTO: Favorite memory?
George: " Chris Miller riding. Watching Bucky, Rune & Bob in the same heat. It was just unreal!"
Ray Zimmerman
BTO: What are the Pros & Cons of shooting the Protec?
Ray: "It's an amazing event. It's the best bowl contest of the year. The energy is insane. I cover the event for Vans, so I am there shooting weeks ahead. I put in alot of time. At the end of it, I always say- "Never again" But then I always come back & do it because I love it. Contest day... is Hell! There is no room on the deck as everyone wants to get their shots. I can't do my job well... It's stressful. I just do my best."
BTO: Favorite memories?
Ray: " Red rolling around the deck in his underwear. Matt Boyster dropping in off the TV tower, shooting his board intio the lights & the riders continuing to ride through the glass. Cab knocking Lance out of his shoes when they collided..., gnarly! The girls--when they were in -- always had drama. Fistfights with each other.. it's crazy!" We are such a dysfunctional family. Put us in a room all together & the shits going to go off!"

item.title: Paying at Protec- Qualifiers
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Tonight was the Protec qualifiers. People have been getting wrecked. Sutures, blood, slams & pain. Tonight was no exception. What we go through to do this thing that we do! The jam format is taking its toll. Just how much suffering do we need before the cost becomes too high? Call me what you will... I see no need to put ourselves through this ordeal. Let the riders take their runs. Let them raise the bar & express themselves. "This is how I ride the Combi pool!" Let them take a run & show everyone another level of riding. With two or three people in the pool, it becomes a dangerous game of 'Hide & Seek'. It becomes a waiting game. The rider keeps a wary eye on the other... waiting to see a bail then the remaining skater can finish a semi-lackluster run. This method showcases nothing. Again, it is a waiting game. The riders wait for the other to bail & the sadists in the crowd wait for a collision. I speak only for myself, but I don't want to see ANY collisions or 'close calls'. I'd rather see my friends take the best run they are capable of, without worrying about who is going to blast into them. Tonight, Mike Owen qualified first in Pro division & Rob Sluggo Boyce qualified first in Masters. While the contest was going on , Josh Stafford was riding in the pool with Cookiehead Jenkins & they -unfortunately--collided. Josh Stafford was crushed into the Combi floor. Being an RN & concerned, I went down into the pool & checked on him. He was conscious & knew where & who he was. He was shaken up & his mouth & forehead were bloodied. He'd need to be checked out at the Hospital. He was helped out of the bowl & I peered down at the concrete. His blood was splashed across the surface. I took off my ALVA sweatshirt & cleaned it up. Kristy Van Doren threw me a bottle of water & we made it right. Cookiehead was beside himself... that he was involved in the collision. It was accidental, but an inherent danger & risk in this format. Later, I hear that Josh & Cookie were walking out toward the front & Josh asked Cookie - "Are YOU okay dude?" Respect. We wish Josh Stafford a quick 'get better' & to Cookiehead.... It wasn't your fault. We may need to get rid of the jam format to keep everyone safe & to maintain a high level of ripping. I --personally--think we will see a higher level of ability & individual excellence within the Combi. Thanks to MRZ for the images. Thanks to everyone that helped Josh tonight. Congratulations to those that made the well-deserved cut. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Rune Glifberg: Pre-Protec Q&A
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
BTO: How much do you still ride vert & bowls?
Rune: For the past 5-6 years, I wasn't really riding vert. I rode mostly bowls & pools. In the last 6 months, I started riding more vert. It was super fun again. I felt like a 12 year old on his first day at the vert ramp. Now that everyone is jumping in the bowl thing--to be cool--I've been riding more vert. It certainly helps with bowls & pools.
BTO With such a competitive scene that defined many vert contests in the 1980s, are you seeing more of that same 'vibe' in the recent Protec contests & are you experiencing other riders trying to 'get into each others heads' ?
Rune: I saw that a couple of years ago. There was alot of 'criss-crossing craziness' as Duncan puts it. But the people doing that were guys that had been riding together for years. They know each other & aren't out to hurt each other. You just don't drop in while someone is riding. It's an unwritten law. You simply don't do it. You must have respect.
BTO; Coming into the last Protec, did the new pool surface & changes throw you off your game/lines/ strategy?
Rune: No. I don't think so. It's better. The coping is bigger on the new one is all. It made it hard to do big airs. I like to find the flow of the pool & not manipulate my lines... if that makes sense. My approach is not to force anything. I like it to feel right.
BTO: How have you tried to prepare for the Protec contests in the past & this year?
Rune: I usually try to take one big slam about a week before the contest. That seems pretty regular for me... which I did again this year. My knee is sore. In all seriousness, about a month before, I come & ride. I work on getting used to the pool & its lines.
BTO: Would you like to see any changes in the contest & what are they?
Rune: The first year with a 30 minute open jam was best. There was a potential for collisions, but people seemed pretty respectful. You have time to do your tricks. If you fall, you know you get a second chance. 30 minutes works. I don't like the half & half thing. Runs then a 10 minute jam just doesn't work. You enbd up avoiding each other & not doing much. It's not really the best possible skating.
BTO: Last words?
Rune: Thanks to everyone for supporting this & I hope we have many more years of fun.
Good Luck Rune. Thanks to MRZ for the image. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: the deliberation
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
The Vans Protec Pool Party occurred yesterday. My brain was fried after about 14 hours at the park! I still had a hard time sleeping. This morning, I left MRZs house & headed to Ridiculous. We had stayed up late & reviewed the hundreds of photographs he had taken. The deliberation. Over the last year & going into this contest, I have heard a few minor rumblings. "Stevie Caballero didn't really win the last Protec. Chris Miller just didn't stay on & lost." I know & respect both of these gentlemen & I must say something here & now. On contest day, it's about who skates the best. Only the judges can really answer that question. It's not up to us. At the 2010 Protec, the judges thought Stevie Cab lit it up & skated the best. Chris Miller did not. Fini. Stevie Cab has been a skater his entire life. It's wired into his biology. When Chris Miller does a 12 foot FS air transfer into the round bowl, early releasing like Brad Bowman at 100 mph , don't think for one nano- second that Cab is jealous or gnashing his teeth in frustration.... He's as happy as we are! How could he not be!? It's the ultimate mastery & use of the Combi. That transfer of Miller's is art... timeless. When Stevie Cab throws down his Teflon-smooth lines, flowing through the pool--effortlessly--like water, oozing style from every pore, pulling FS inverts as only Stevie can, you can bet Chris Miller feels nothing but admiration.
This years Protec was unbelievable. I've been around skateboarding my entire life as well. I've seen more than a few contests. This one was truly epic. I deliberated on the results just like everyone else. BLKPRJKT had it right when he said that these guys are artists expressing themselves. How does one judge which is better? Picasso? Renoir? Van Gogh? I wouldn't have wanted to be a judge yesterday! Everyone has an opinion & a favorite. It's simply the way it works. The Masters was unreal. The deliberation. I actually had Lance in first place in my mind... but he is my bro & I am-- admittedly-- biased. However, Lance had some of the most amazing & varied runs I have seen him take. Lance has more lines than Disneyland! His first run out of the gate was purrrfection. His FS invert through the corner & his 360 lien air were inspiring. He had an almost flawless set of contest runs & I had him in first. I'm stoked for him. Stevie Cab was just about perfect. It really appears effortless for Stevie. That makes it all the more amazing when he strings 20 + walls together. His lipslides through the corners & his FS slide and roll were soooo rad! He threw down one of the most insane finger flip indy airs ever... I am proud of Cab. He prepared for this contest & rode better than ever.
Chris Miller came in hot. I must admit, his lines were fast & fluid. His blunt slide in the round is something to be admired. He pulled one after a seriously overturned tippy-toe indy nosebone... and everyone was like.. "Good grief!" He followed that with lipslides through the corner & huge FS ollies. Chris Miller won. He deserved a top spot. He displays a mastery & style unlike anyone in skateboarding. The tricks that he does are honed to beautiful perfection. Chris is truly a wonder to watch riding in the Combi pool. Chris Miller did take a few falls though. Tony Hawk rode better than I thought he would. I mean no disrespect. He is Tony Hawk. However, I don't think he has been riding too much roundwall lately & the Combi is a very different sort of animal. Tony dropped a 540 his second wall & I thought- "Here we go!" Tony did have slight trouble flowing through the Combi & using the corners though. He did well & stayed on ... stringing difficult tricks together. It was a treat to see him at the Protec. Eric Nash rode like a God. He had five great runs with power, speed & style. He rode the Combi. It didn't ride him. He deserved his placing... no doubt about it. The top five went like this: Miller, Caballero, Mountain, Hawk, Nash respectively.
The Pros were next. The weeding out process was gnarly. Again, I wouldn't want to have been a judge. Not on this day. Not at this event. The level of skating has dramatically increased since the refurbishing by California Skateparks last spring. They did a stellar job & the skating is better because of it. Pedro Barros is a ripper. He goes huge. He skated supremely well. His lines were fast & smooth. His tricks were ceiling high & he made me cringe a few times as he descended from the 7 foot to 8 foot mark on the edges of his shoes! He was hanging onto a 540 & bottom dropped it, landing low. He still managed enough speed to cruise a fluid Smith off the peninsula & continue on. He deserved a top spot. Pedro won the contest.
The deliberation. I had Rune Glifberg in first place. Rune rode the pool like a maniac. Although he fell, he did a switch kick flip, heelflips, huge transfers, tailslides both ways & through the corners... Rune is amazing. Taking nothing away from Pedro, I thought Rune had a better flow, use of the entire pool & more technicality. Rune had one run that was completely insane. Regardless, it was close & --as I said earlier--only the judges opinions really matter. Andy Macdonald. Andy is an old friend of mine & I was really happy to see him in the Protec. He is one of the most amazing skateboarders on the planet & I was glad to see him turn it loose in the pool & show what he can do. His FS blunt up the peninsula into the square pool was crazy good. He deserved his third place finish & I am proud of him. Nolan Munroe. I had Nolan Munroe pretty high on my list as well. He rode well, had varied lines, huge tricks & consistency.
Alex Perelson burned my brain last night. When you are that smooth & that powerful, you have the potential to display a whole new level of Kimchi. Alex threw down several of the most amazing walls of the night. When it clicks for Alex, the world of skateboarding is a much better place. The Pros ended like this: Pedro, Rune, Andy Mac, Nolan Munroe & Perelson.- respectively. There were some new guys in their first Protec. Young. Some are brash. They display bravado. Flushed with pride. "Look at me! Look at me!" We've seen them ride because they took every other run in practice. We know they can skate really well! The future is bright for them but they need to ramp it down a bit. Chill. Play nice. Respect. This is skateboarding. Regulate yourself. Skateboarders have long memories. A word of caution- The world of skateboarding is much better when you are 'in' looking out, then 'out' looking in.
It seems as though there is a changing of the guard. The pioneers of our sport are here in the Masters to show everyone how this thing was started & how it is done. Half-pipers are coming in & pushing them out. If you lose the lines & the flow, what's the use in continuing to do it? It's a tough point to deliberate & a bone of contention with many. Maybe it is time to pass the torch. But we must never leave those pioneers standing in the dark. They are the very reason we have all that we do. The Vans Protec Pool Party was a huge success. I heard that there were a quarter of a million viewers on the webcast. Thank you to everyone that came out. Thank you to Steve Van Doren & family. Thank you to all the skaters that rode & killed it! Thank you to MRZ for the weeks of hard work & for these images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Gonzales Pool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
The Kennedy clan has their Hyannisport, tennis has its Wimbledon, basketball has its Madison Square Garden & golf has its Pebble Beach. Skateboarding has the Gonzales pool. Almost all skateboarding that is seen & represented on the television, has its origins in the Gonzales pool. The Z-Boys, The Bones Brigade, The X-Games, The Dew Tour & everything in between & beyond can directly trace its roots back to the round plaster walls of this one special pool.
The Gonzales pool. There are several places that remain legendary as the ultimate early proving ground for our kind. Gonzo’s, Dogbowl, Glory Hole pipe, Baldy pipe, Wallo’s ditch will undeniably remain etched in the skateboarding collective memory as places we all should’ve had the chance to ride.
Gonzo’s was located in a quiet area of Los Angeles. The old spanish-style homes around it, had red- tiled roofs in abundance, well-manicured lawns and brightly-colored flowerbeds. Huge, shadowing Ficus trees lined the sleepy streets, looking like sentinals watching over the adjacent properties.
The ‘Gonzales’ pool. There are several places that remain legendary as the ultimate early proving ground for our kind. ‘Gonzo’s, ‘Dogbowl’, ‘Glory Hole’, Baldy pipe’, ‘Wallo’s’ and a few select others will undeniably remain etched in the skateboarding collective memory as places we all should’ve had the chance to ride.
‘Gonzo’s’ was located in a quiet area of Los Angeles. The old spanish-style homes around it, had red- tiled roofs in abundance, well-manicured lawns and brightly-colored flowerbeds. Huge, shadowing Ficus trees lined the sleepy streets, looking like sentinals watching over the adjacent properties.
The pool and property was owned by Mr. Jose Gonzales Gonzales. He was an actor on the hit TV show, ‘Bonanza’ and had many film credits to his name. ‘Mr. G’ had a large family and had the pool installed by the ‘Anthony Brothers’ pool company out of South Gate, California. It was constructed in the pool-building frenzy of the early 1960′s. ‘Gonzo’s’ was a huge ( I mean HUGE!) right-hand kidney. It had a very long deep end and a hip you could -literally- walk up. The transitions were big and mellow and the entire pool was surrounded with smooth bullnose coping.
The story that I was told of its discovery has always remained with me. It was a perfect tale. From sources like Tony Alva, Ray Flores, Wes Humpston and Stacey Peralta…I feel that it has to be the truth! They were the key players in its discovery and the formation of its legend. Ray Flores found ‘Gonzo’s’ in 1977. He was skating down a street and as he passed an alley, he noticed a heavy stream of green water flowing into the gutters, Following the water trail, he saw a door opening in the ten foot high block wall surrounding the yard. Stealthy as a cat, he approached and peered inside. The pool was almost pumped empty and the bright, white plaster glittered and hurt his eyes. It was perfect. As it turned out, he somehow knew a member of the Gonzales family and an agreement was soon reached.
Ray, Wes and others of the Z-boys, found themselves a permission pool unlike anything ever before. They brought TA over eventually and he showed them just exactly what could be done in such a huge pool! Jokingly, I was told that the Z-boys initially didn’t tell TA about ‘Gonzo’s’ because he usually travelled in an entourage and they didn’t want the drama. Truth or myth?
When queried, TA told me that back then, photographers always showed up wherever he skated. It was accepted by that time. He had won the World Championships and was the first to pull consistent tuck-knee frontside airs out of a pool.
Whatever the case may be, all the Z-boys were stoked to be riding ‘Gonzales’ pool and breaking new ground. After that, ‘Gonzo’s’ quickly became a staging area for the Z-boys to gather and push both themselves and each other.Limits were reached and exceeded. TA pulled back-to-back frontside airs, the others nailed edgers, hip rollouts, grind transfers deep-to-shallow, and forevers. New ground was discovered by all.
The ‘Gonzales’ pool. The transitions were big and mellow and the entire pool was surrounded with smooth bullnose coping.
The story that I was told of its discovery has always remained with me. It was a perfect tale. From sources like Tony Alva, Ray Flores, Wes Humpston and Stacy Peralta…I feel that it has to be the truth! They were the key players in its discovery and the formation of its legend. Ray Flores found ‘Gonzo’s’ in 1977. He was skating down a street and as he passed an alley, he noticed a heavy stream of green water flowing into the gutters, Following the water trail, he saw a door opening in the ten foot high block wall surrounding the yard. Stealthy as a cat, he approached and peered inside. The pool was almost pumped empty and the bright, white plaster glittered and hurt his eyes. It was perfect. As it turned out, he somehow knew a member of the Gonzales family and an agreement was soon reached.
Ray, Wes and others of the Z-boys, found themselves a permission pool unlike anything ever before. They brought TA over eventually and he showed them just exactly what could be done in such a huge pool! Jokingly, I was told that the Z-boys initially didn’t tell TA about ‘Gonzo’s’ because he usually travelled in an entourage and they didn’t want the drama. Truth or myth?
When queried, TA told me that back then, photographers always showed up wherever he skated. It was accepted by that time. He had won the World Championships and was the first to pull consistent tuck-knee frontside airs out of a pool.
Whatever the case may be, all the Z-boys were stoked to be riding Gonzales pool and breaking new ground. After that, ‘Gonzo’s’ quickly became a staging area for the Z-boys to gather and push both themselves and each other. Limits were reached and exceeded. TA pulled back-to-back frontside airs, the others nailed edgers, hip rollouts, grind transfers deep-to-shallow, and forevers. New ground was discovered by all. Trick to trick vertical skateboarding was born.
It was a place where anarchy & art collided, where the participants waved their middle fingers at the world & unknowingly created a signal that generations would forever follow. When they were doing this, it was a gesture of defiance at what was considered normal sports & accepted societal activities. Skateboarding was born here. For us to lose the Gonzales Pool & let it fade into the mists of obscurity is to make a grave error. This place is a monument & the birth of a movement. In every sport there needs to be someone to guide it. Skateboarding is lawless & anarchic. Its anti-authoritarian. Its very actions & the mentality of the participants make it an unstructured mess in so many ways. Skateboarders don't want it to be anything other than that. However, because it is being dragged--kicking & screaming--into the mainstream, against all its better judgement, it still accepts the paychecks that are handed out now. With the X-Games, skateboarders stopped driving Honda Civics & started driving Audi A4s. Families are now provided for. Health insurance premiums are paid. Skateboarders can live comfortably. Monetary compensation aside, Nike, ESPN & other mainstream sports authorities are making skateboarding an acceptable alternative for youth by a mass of people who in the past thumbed their noses at it. At Woodward in the late 1990s, parents told me that they would almost rather send their son to a thousand dollar a week football camp than a five hundred dollar a week skateboard camp. Degenerates. Social misfits. Such was the nature & collective impression of skateborders at the time. Now, in the last fifteen years, skateboarding has now become accepted & embraced. Gonzales Pool started this whole thing rolling. Someone needs to preserve & guide that history so we don't lose it. The Gonzales Pool property is located in Mar Vista in the Gregory Ain Mar Vista Tract

item.title: amazing
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Pain. In the stars, in the sun, in everything & everyone. Pain. I guess it's what we do about it that matters most. Humans recoil from pain. Skateboarders have a tendency to live in it. Pain comes with the territory. After spending too much time covering the Protec, MRZ, BLKPRJKT & I decided to cruise up & ride Venice & Santa Monica on this past Friday. It was early when we arrived & we were all excited to ride our skateboards. We carved the pool & had a blast. Everyone was grinding & flying... it felt so perfect. We were going to leave & I had been having trouble landing a BS air on the left side wall, so I decided to put one down before we left. I put one out of the pool, straight to kingpin lockup & directly drove myself onto the flatbottom like a nail. I couldn't catch my breath...the whole nine yards. Ouch! I --pretty much--knew something was highly wrong in my anatomy. I walked out of the pool & had trouble moving my arm. BLKPRJKT fetched some ice & Ray drove me back. A few times, I thought I was going to throw up on my shoes. It hurts when you break bones. We went to the VA Medical Center & after about 6 or 7 hours, I found out what I knew all along. Fractured collarbone two places & fractured elbow. The elbow is chipped but okay. They removed a couple syringes of blood out of my elbow & all. I couldn't drive & Ray & his family posted me up on the couch & looked after me all weekend. I can't recall ever getting this much sleep or watching this much TV! It's a weird world out there in TV land. Ray, Lance & I went to a movie Saturday... that was a nice diversion. I have been scared over these last few years. Since I became sober, I've been fearful that I may get hurt someday & need pain meds. I've been hurt in the past & always got around their use. I don't want to go there! I don't want to flip that switch 'On' ever again. This time was no different. Though the pain was nauseating & pretty grim, I sucked it up. I used ice & Motrin & that's really it. Once I made it past the first two days without pain meds, I knew I would be alright. I am happy to still be clean & sober. It is my greatest accomplishment. I am home now. Ice. Motrin. Rest. I'm glad I don't have cable TV & I have a bunch of new books. Thank you to those that sent me 'get well' messages & all. Thank you to Ray & his family for taking care of me. Thanks to BLKPRJKT as well. I'll be back. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: The Goldfish
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
It had been a busy work week. Friday afternoon, we unloaded the tools & I bid my co-workers a quick farewell. With a wave of my calloused hand, I climbed into the truck for the long Friday afternoon drive to Ridiculous. Departing from Laguna, I drove slowly; the line of cars crawling through the canyon like a cold metal snake. Hills were covered with brown, dead grass & the winter rains had left mud & puddles by the roadsides. Expensive cars gleamed wickedly as their drivers crouched behind tinted windows. They jousted for position, racing nimbly from lane to lane in their pathetic attempts to be ahead. "Ahead of what!?" They all seemed to want to be somewhere... anywhere but here. I smiled to myself & laughed out loud at their aggressive behaviors. The proverbial rat race. The desire for more. Better, sooner, quicker. The races of acquisition are always run in the dark. Greed & need. People find many things that will bring them down in the end. I know. I've been there.
With my 'give-a-shitter' permanently broken & my Orange County-induced misanthropy clouding my mind, I plodded along in traffic & listened to Jonsi. As far as I am concerned, Sigur Ros are musical genius. Jonsi- 'Kolnidur' is ethereal & timeless! I crossed the Anaheim hills & the sun glittered off the vehicles around me. A billboard for a strip club beckoned from a grassy hill just off the freeway. The huge photographic image was a red wet mouth; a well-manicured index finger vertically extended over it. "Shhhhhh". It spoke of beautiful women, unlimited pleasures & private dances. I smirked to myself in the rear view mirror. "Yeah right!" I muttered. "Until you run out of money....that's when the pleasures always end." I took a sip of water & decided to change my train of thought. Force Quit.
I made my way slowly home. After I exited, I drove a nearby side street & looked for foreclosures. Weaving through a neighborhood, I spotted one. A run-down camper perched in the driveway. It was sun-bleached & spiderwebs covered the tires & fenders underneath. Trash cans were piled with refuse. It had a certain empty feel to it. Windows were sealed up tight. Old newspapers soggily sat in the dead grass. I pulled up. After checking around a bit, I pulled myself over the left rear wall & froze. The pool was amazing. It was in the shape of a Pepperidge Farm Goldfish cracker. It looked insane. It was a Master Pool with bullnose coping & perfect transitions. The surface was unreal & pristine. There was some water in & I made immediate plans to come back the next morning & drain it.
I phoned Sallie & he told me of finding the 'Pink Tile Lounge' that afternoon. We were stoking because we both were pretty sure we had found one of the best pools in awhile. The next day, I was in the yard by 7:00 am. I bucketed it myself. I do this sometimes. It's quiet. It's like going to church in so many ways. I feel most comfortable around skateboards, concrete & plaster. A skateboard can never lie to me or strike me in anger. A skateboard won't tell me to get a better job, make more money or "grow up". A skateboard won't ever try to sleep with my friends or attempt to use me in any fashion. I bucketed. The morning sun warmed my back. It peeked through the purple-flowered trumpet vines lining the hedges & sent fingers of sunlight across the tiles.
It was very quiet & still. I looked at the transitions. I glimpsed the deathbox --hollow and dangerous--above me. I looked for lines. I thought of old Stan Sharp photographs. Skateboard World. 1979. Jay Smith. Jerry Valdez. Dave Ferry. Kent Senatore. Valley Pools. Elephant Country. The Fishbowl. The Buddha Pool. History. I bucketed slowly & sipped strong coffee. A small dog began yapping nearby & I heard a car alarm chirp. I paused to listen. Nothing. I continued on & drained the pool. It was perfect. I thought of the session to come.
Later, Salba, Riverside Shawn, myself, John Zask, Tyco, Adam 12, Billy, Badlander Chris & Michael Serna Jr. would christen the pool. Grinds & lines were in abundance & the Goldfish offered up new possibilities. Later, in the ensuing months, others would ride it with us & marvel at the amazing lines & fun found inside the Goldfish. She is gone. Dogs are kept in the backyard now. Pitbulls menace & growl their hostility from the poop-littered confines of a once-fun patch of foreclosure paradise. It sits there, light-deep in black water & dog feces. I find it such a waste of a good place. Thanks to JZ, Brandon Wong, Sean Peterson & MRZ for the images. Skate & don't ever give in to the great lie. - Ozzie

item.title: his father
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Upland, California. 1992. The car pulled to a stop at the far end of a culdesac. He locked the door & it sat in the heat... ticking & making the noises that engines make. The air was hot. It felt angry on his skin. He pulled his bush hat down lower over his eyes. He squinted in the suns glare. A rusting chain-link fence meandered off into the distance. It separated the houses from the federal lands, the dam & the spillway area. He shouldered his backpack & stood there for a minute, peering about. He shrugged, as if making up his mind & walked over to a small section of the fence. It was peeled back. It had been left hanging to scrape the dirt. He stepped over it & onto the boulders that led down the hillside.
Huge power lines hung overhead & were strung across the valley floor. The boulders & dusty path that he walked, led directly across the barren valley. The huge metal towers --that held the power lines--scraped the sky. A lonely hawk circled in the distance. It lived a solitary life. He trudged along & once he was closer --under the power lines-- he could hear the humming. It sounded like a million angry bees. He knew it was only the electrical lines, feeding the nearby cities. He thought of his father. He had recently seen a faded photograph of him. He was in uniform... a Marine Corps uniform. 1970. Vietnam. A bloody time. His mother told him that when his father came home on leave for the last time, he seemed hollow. He recalled looking at the photograph of his father. There was definitely something wrong with his fathers eyes. It was the image he held in his mind when he thought of him.
The boulders gave way to a dusty trail. He followed it for about thirty minutes. Cactus & bristled bushes stubbornly raised their faces to the desert sun. He saw trash, broken glass & old beer cans. They were remnants of long-forgotten drunkenness. His head hurt & he stopped to take a drink from the water bottle that sloshed at his side. He had drank-- more than a few --last night. He could smell the booze sweating out of him. It was one of the only things that brought sleep to him lately. Like his father, he was a Marine. Kuwait had been pretty grim & he didn't like to think too much about it. They never really told them about the dreams. The other guys didn't talk about it. He kept seeing things. Nights were the worst. The Basra road. Al Jahra. Oil rigs & fields on fire. Black columns of smoke reaching up forever... That smell...
He shook his head to clear it of uncomfortable memories. Strangely, he remembered that bumper sticker. "Freedom has a flavor the protected will never know." He hoisted his backpack higher & started walking again. His father hadn't come home. One day he was there, tall, sparkling, shining in his uniform... then nothing. His mother would sit by the phone-- as if sitting there would possibly make it ring. It didn't. She chain smoked & cried. He sat in his room & read. Quiet prevailed. One day, men in uniform came & knocked. They were grim-faced. Impassive. He huddled upstairs in his room. He heard the solemn rumbling voices. Mother broke & all the Kleenex in the world couldn't stop that tide. She never said much after that. She still doesn't. "She never even kissed me goodbye when I was deployed to the Gulf." He mumbled under his breath & realized he was talking to himself.
He crested a small rise & saw the barbed wire & fencing that crowned the uppermost edge of the spillway. "Baldy!" Quickly, he hastened down inside. Graffiti splashed across every surface within reach. He wasn't as young as he once was but he sure felt like he was twelve again! Skateboarding had always saved him. Once inside the spillway, he hurried & quickly found himself at the pipes opening. He walked up inside. It was much cooler inside the pipe. After all, it was far underground. The pipe echoed & was haunting. Sun filtered in & barely lit the middle. It didn't matter. He pushed towards the light. Avoiding rough areas, he carved & kickturned as high as he could. Freedom. Therapy. The ghosts disappeared back into the past. The moment was perfection. He wished he had friends that skated. He wished his father could be there to see him. He wished the world were different. He wished. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: trust
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
"It is a wise father that knows his own child." - William Shakespeare
I recalled reading this quote recently. It struck me at the time. Many parents don't really know their own children. They think that they do because they share the same biology & hardwiring. Although they are similar in many regards, there are definite differences. Yet, do we really know each other at all? The people we think that we know the best, sometimes do the most bizarre things. Have you ever looked at a family member or a long-time friend and asked, "Who is this person?!" I think that it comes down to trust. We trust in the people that we know & love to do the right things. We trust in our judgment. We trust that fate will be kind. As children, we trust in our parents. We trust that they will provide for & protect us. I saw this picture of my friend John Zask --and his daughter Marley--the other day. I was reminded of all this by the look on her face. She never even looks at him, as he speeds towards her, then towers above & blasts by... She trusts in him. She knows that everything's gonna be alright. With a name like 'Marley', that's kind-of what we expected anyway! Thanks to Vania for the image. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Riverside
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Riverside, California. Founded in the 1870s, it is the birthplace of the California citrus industry. Judge John Wesley North, from Tennessee --who was ostracized back home after he talked a crowd out of lynching a black man-- brought a group of associates and co-investors out to Southern California, and founded Riverside. A few years after, the navel orange was planted and found to be such a success that full-scale planting started. Riverside had then grown to become the wealthiest city in the country, due to the riches of the navel orange. The wealthy built huge houses throughout Riverside. Orange groves, bright-red bouganvilla & huge California King Palms surrounded these properties. In the summer, the heat rises above 105 degrees. Pools were quickly built on the spacious lawns of these homes during the pool- building flurry of the 1950s & 1960s.
At he end of a dusty dirt lane in Riverside, lies one of these pools. The Spanish -style windows & porches of the home are shaded by huge trees that almost hide the property from view. The home had once been a bright place. Family wealth. Assured destiny. No more. By the 1990s, the house had fallen into disrepair. Wooden shingles sagged & the sun-washed paint had blistered & faded. The trees & shrubbery had overgrown. The pool sat unused. Black water. Mosquitoes.
The home became a 'Halfway House' for men leaving prison. One of those paroled was a one-time skateboarder. When he saw the pool & its size, he made a few phone calls. Christmas eve 1998. Rhino, Andy Mac, P-Stone, myself & others, went up & rode the pool. It was unreal. The pool was named 'The Convict' & has since retained its moniker. Over the years, the pool has been an 'on & off' sort-of deal. Riverside Ed, worked out an agreement with the owners & it has been a 'permission only' situation ever since.
Chris Miller & I were talking during the week of the Protec. He said that he was interested in coming out & riding a few backyard pools with his son Zach. I phoned my friend Riverside Ed & he looked around & found a few permission pools for us to session. I made the arrangements & on Sunday morning, we met up in Riverside. The cars crept up the dusty driveway as a pale sun hung overhead. The Sunday crew was : Chris & Zach Miller, Peter Hewitt, Paul Wisniewski, Brian Fick, Tom Remillard, Riverside Ed, Kevin, Josh & myself. Once inside, we all swept & readied the pool. I am still on the mend, so I sat around & maintained the "peanut gallery".
Everyone cruised around & warmed up. Jokes were bantered back & forth & then the skating began in earnest. Remillard rolled in & flew through the pool. Lien to tails & FS Light/box were on his menu. Zach Miller cruised around & worked on FS ollies. Paul hit rock-n-rolls in the cup. Peter Hewitt worked the shallow end for FS grinds & Chris threw up a stylish FS air immediately followed by a FS lipslide. Gosh! Everyone was stoked & the weather was perfect. At the pre-planned time, we gathered our things & headed to our next pool.
Ed has some good pools & it was kind of him to share them. We drove over to a pool called 'Clays'. It's a deep old Rossmore kidney. The evaporation stains etched into the concrete make it clear that the pool probably hasn't been a swimmer for a long, long time. The surface is hard & fast though, and the loveseat was just sitting there waiting. An ice cream truck chimed outside on the street & Tom bought us some treats. The sun was beginning to scorch. There was a canoe propped up at one end of the yard. It made a perfect spot to sit under & was the only shade in sight. Some of the crew posted up underneath while Chris & Zach Miller took a few turns.
Father & son made a wager on which one of them could get over the loveseat first. $5.00. Zach smiled, pushed in & went straight over! Papa Miller was shutdown. We were all laughing. Peter Hewitt tossed up a BS air & the rest of the crew put some trucks on coping in the time that we had left. We then decided to try to ride Jose's pool. We drove in a caravan through the hot, dirty afternoon sun & when we arrived, received the 'go-ahead' from Jose. His relatives were there but he gave us a session. It would prove to be an amazing hour- long pool school.
We had to bucket some water & muck out of the pool & I am pretty amped when I see the images from that pool cleanup. Chris, Peter, Paul, Tom & Zach are all in the deep end bucketing & working. Zach Miller grabbed a Gatorade bottle, made a scoop & cleaned out the murky drain! It was great to see such skaters doing the work... paying for their fun.
Peter & Tom quickly conquered light/loveseat & then the tricks escalated. Peter concentrated on BS tailslides, Tom focused on FS lipslides over the loveseat & Paul pulled rock-n-rolls near the hip. Riverside Ed made it over the light/loveseat with a bit of encouragement & was rewarded with a heavy 'high-five' parade from everyone.
All-in all, it was a great day of pool riding & everyone left feeling tired but happy. Riverside had welcomed us. The pools that were built in the 'glory days' to help keep the heat at bay--at first glance-- had been used for an entirely different purpose. Yet perhaps, they are one in the same. They were designed to refresh & entertain. After the session on Sunday, I believe they did that very thing. Thanks to the crew, Riverside Ed for the arrangements & Brian Fick for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: aesthetics II
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I find it interesting, how many skaters love the pool aesthetic. Some scarcely notice & others can't get enough. I always hold certain skateboarding photographs close to my heart. I was heavily influenced by the magazine images. I noticed everything. I not only scrutinized the rider, the skateboard & the trick ... I saw it all. The entire pool. The shell-shaped stairs in the deep end, the radius of the transitions and sharp curve of the hip, the deathbox, the green palm trees overhead, the intricate blue tile work ... everything. Last week, I was browsing through some pool images of mine & then started wondering at what others see. I decided to go through some of MRZs photographs. I found some gems. It is amazing at how similar things stand out for us. This week, Chris Miller sent me some of his images. I decided to post them all together. The pool aesthetic. Perfection. Thank you to MRZ, Chris Miller, Peanut, Samwise & Brandon Wong for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: drawing a blank
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I was numb. I had been working back to back shifts. The Crisis Unit had been extraordinarily violent these last few hours. We had to 'put down' several patients that had become combative. None of us liked it. Danger. Psychotic people can be truly scary. Two weeks before, a young man diagnosed with Anti-social Personality Disorder had attacked a co-worker. The male nurse had let the patient get between him & the door. Grievous error. He kicked the door shut & kicked the nurse until his spleen ruptured. He broke his ribs & splintered his teeth. By the time we put him into restraints, blood was splashed across the room like a medieval painting. Sweat-soaked & howling, he looked up at me from beneath the boots & arms holding him down. He just smiled. I shuddered in spite of myself. The attack was fresh in everyone's memory & we were hyper-alert. I told the staff: "Stay frosty."
Tonight, I was just trying to finish my shift. I received the call. New admission. Diagnosis: Suicidal Ideation. He had come into the Crisis Unit on a 5150 hold. The local Police Department had brought him in. A 5150 is actually a 72 hour hold in a psychiatric facility. Lockdown. A 5150 is placed on people who are considered by police to be a danger to themselves, others or gravely disabled. They can no longer function in polite society & take care of themselves. There are such unfortunates. On a 5150, they are held & evaluated by psychiatrists. This particular man was suicidal. I had him placed into a solitary cell & his belongings were inventoried. I spoke with him at length. He was one of the doomed. Eye contact was negligible. He spoke in a monotonous voice. His answers were mostly one-word mumblings. The man told me that he felt empty & his world had become grey. Nothing brought him pleasure. Drugs & alcohol offered him little solace. He had given up on sex months ago & eating soon followed.
The man was terribly thin, his veins appeared like blue wires beneath his almost transparent sallow skin. If I didn't know better, I would've thought he had an eating disorder... He looked up at me. No fear. Acceptance. The finality of all things. The great end. We placed him on a round-the-clock watch & fed him. He received therapy & medications. His turn-around was slow. He slept & involved himself in nothing. Monosyllabic to the end. He was released by the physicians. I thought they were making a mistake. I couldn't do a thing. I worried about him for awhile & then he receded from my memory by the business of life.
Three weeks later, I was walking out of a grocery store & almost ran into him. He was dirty & disheveled. His greasy hair hung across his face. His eyes were dark marbles... sunken. He recognized me. Quickly, I got over my initial surprise. I asked him if he was okay... "How have things been?" He shuffled his feet. Blowing cigarette smoke out of the side of his mouth he murmured "Not so good." I talked to him a bit, urging him to come back into the clinic. We could try & obtain funds for him to stay longer & receive more aggressive therapy. He nodded. I asked him if he was suicidal & he stated that he had been.
My mind raced. I nearly buckled under the responsibility. "What the hell could I say!?" Platitudes. I told him that he was young. He had much to live for. His stood like he had a Volkswagen on his back. The poor man. He looked me dead in the eye. "Tell me one reason why I should stay." I hesitated. At that moment, I could think of nothing. He saw my hesitation.. ..... He spun on his heel & slowly moved off into the night. I tried calling out to him. I wanted to lie. My mind reeled. I didn't sleep that night. Discussing the case with the physicians at work, I was told that I did all I could do. "You can't save the world." I sat in silence & stared at my shoes. Two weeks later, I heard that he was dead. I threw up in the bathroom. I didn't come out of that bathroom for a long time.
I still see him sometimes. At night. In my room. Dreams are strange. He is moving towards me in that parking lot. He is crossing a line from there to here. I notice his hair. It is stringy & shadowing his eyes. His long dirty coat, swishes as his arms swing across his body. He lifts his head as if to speak to me. I hear nothing. No words come out. Looking closer, I see that he has no mouth. I awaken. I never knew that I could cry in my sleep? Skate- Ozzie

About me- This is not a resume in the official sense. I have an RN license in California & practiced nursing for over a decade. I have decided to put that on hold as it is a tough occupation. I have always been a skateboarder. I have 36 years of skateboarding experience. I know many of our sports pioneers & call them friends. I bring a great deal to the table. I am hoping that I can bring my daily blog & writing skills to work at Vans. It is a life long wish. If you need references, I am sure that Tony Alva, Steve Caballero, Anthony Van Engelen, Anthony Acosta or any number of people will vouch for me. Please call me with any questions. - Ozzie

item.title: Hester Hi-Roller in Boulder- 1979
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I love skateboarding. Passion. Writing the Blue Tile Obsession has been a really cool experience. Every once in awhile, someone reaches out to me & I always find it fascinating, when I realize that there are many people out there that view & experience the world in the same way. We agree. I received an email from a guy in Boulder, Colorado last year. Jack Lovell. He loved the old photographs & stories. He said that he also had some images from Hi-Roller skatepark taken during the summer of 1979. I called him & soon realized that we had a story that must be told. The Hester I & Hester II series were held in California. The only Hester contest held outside of California was Hi-Roller in Boulder. Henry Hester was a downhill racer. Jack Lovell had seen him in Boulder the summer before at a downhill race. When Henry was planning his Hester Series for 1979, Boulder fit perfectly. Hi-Roller. It was a contest where some incredible tricks were unleashed for the first time, a place where anarchy collided with conservative sensibilities & a place where nicknames & legends were born.
All roads lead to Henry.
After speaking with numerous people involved, I soon realized that all roads led to Henry Hester. "You need to talk to Henry." "Ask Hester!" I phoned around & tracked him down. He lives in Texas. I quickly told him my deal & he readily agreed to help, "If I can." Henry told me that he went to Texas for love & ended up with something less. "It's just the way it goes, I guess." I asked him about the Hester series. He actually told me some of the contest order but wasn't quite sure of all his facts. "Check with Steve Alba. I'm sure that he remembers." I laughed. Yeah, I would do just that. I'd hear his side of things... Henry said that he drove to Boulder in a pickup truck. In the back were the PA system speakers & all the stuff. "Duane was on fire that weekend!" he said hurriedly. I asked him about other riders practicing. Henry hesitated a minute, lost in thought. "You know, Eddie Elguera was looking for the overall win, but he missed a contest in the series & was out of the points. Micke Alba was determined... he really was! Micke wanted the overall win. He was skating so consistent. I remember that Peter Kiwi Gifford was really funny.They were all pretty nutty."
 
Henry seemed to think that all of those contests sort-of blended together over the years. Memories. The passage of time distorts & deceives. Henry told me that the skateboarders were crazy. Boulder was pretty mellow & probably wasn't ready for these behaviors. " Bert Lamar & Dave MacIntyre started a food fight. Bert threw something & then it just went off.... a 100% food fight! Bert just wouldn't stop. He was a devious little 12 year old kid. We knew this one skater who could vomit on cue. I grabbed him. Scott Holleman. He threw up in a glass in front of everyone. Bert was like.. "Dude -you rule!" and quit throwing food at everyone. It was so gnarly."
"Eddie would've won!"- Micke Alba
Eddie Elguera came up often. He was really ripping in the series. He looked like he was going to take the top spot. I obtained his number & called him. Eddie was gracious & forthcoming. "Hi- Roller was my first pro contest. Hobie sent us there with one-way tickets. It was Duane, Darrell Miller & myself. Gil Losi bought our tickets home, I think. I recall staying on the roof because we had no money. Somehow, we finally got into a hotel room. I remember it being really hot! Someone filled up the skate reservoir of the park with water & we all swam in it to cool off. The skaters were all acting crazy. Duane was pretty wild at that time. I do know that the Hi-Roller contest was the first time I did an 'Elguerial' in a contest. I had learned it about two weeks before. In the end, I think it was 1st- Micke Alba, 2nd-Eric Grisham & I got 3rd. That year, I received 2nd place overall in the Hester Series."
"Duane was always a hippy!"- Steve Olson
Steve Olson makes me laugh. He's a funny guy. I caught up with him & asked him what he recalled from the Hi-Roller contest. He responded quickly & to the point. "I don't know man! I fucked up my ankle, so I wasn't in good form. I went anyway. The reservoir had water in it. It was the most fun all weekend. We'd ride around the edge & just jump or ride into it..." He started laughing at a memory. "A-ha... " Olson then related the following story. "We were staying in these hotel rooms. They had this closet that went half-way up to the ceiling. You could climb up & see over them into the next bed. George Orton came in with some chick. I was hanging out. He wanted me to leave but I stayed. He took her in the next bed & started fucking her. I climbed up & looked over. She was on top & couldn't see me. George looked up & I started making faces at him & stuff... He got mad & chased me around naked. It was so funny."
 
Steve Olson & I were cracking up. I had heard similar stories from the others. Skatepark groupies, lost virginity, crabs... sounds like it was a blast! He also told me that skaters were wrecking themselves. "Dave Hackett slammed so hard, he flew home early"! Olson is a great history source. He rules! Steve Olson then ended with the following terse 'Olson-ism'. "All those new dudes were learning tricks. I didn't think that any of those tricks had anything to do with surfing... " Perfect. As I was thanking him, he asked me who else I was speaking with regarding Hi-Roller. I told him "Duane & others." Before he hung up the phone, Olson added with a laugh- "Duane was always a hippy. Don't let the uniform fool you!"
'The Master of Disaster.'
I saw Duane recently & we skated Ridiculous together. I asked him about Hi-Roller. He had similar memories much like the others. "It was my first Hester contest on Hobie. It was Darrell Miller, Eddie Elguera & me. We got one-way tickets. We slept on a roof for awhile & I think we had to 'place' well in the contest to get money to go home. It was pretty gnarly! The Hobie guys. All three of us pulled new moves in that contest & we were all on Hobie. I did the invert-revert, Darrell Miller did the Miller-flip & Eddie Elguera did the Elguerial! Ozzie! These were the first 360 airs in skateboarding!" I was thinking about what Duane was telling me. I found it hard to believe that these three amazing riders were throwing down historical maneuvers & were sleeping on a skate shop roof with no way to get home! My how things have changed... I asked Duane if he had other memories of the event or the skaters. He laughed. "Well, Darrell Miller & I were drinking beer in the days leading up to the contest. During those days, Frank Blood & George Orton were kind-of looked upon as jocks. They were staying in the same hotel room. The night before the event, we drank & then climbed up on the roof of the hotel. We started throwing rocks down at their patio window. They came out yelling. "Mother fuckers!" We hid & laughed... We threw more rocks & when they came out again, I pissed down onto them! They were so mad! We had to hide from them. Then, D. David Morin heard about it. He was announcing at the contest. So, when my contest run started, he announced me as 'The Master of Disaster'. That's how that whole thing started.
 
As far as the contest went, everyone ripped & placed. I think I ended up in 6th. Micke Alba won Hi-Roller. We all made it & got paid. We made it home. Duane shook his head & smirked at me. "It's hard to believe how gnarly the Hobie team was at that time. They just didn't see it." I filled him in on some of the other riders memories. We were laughing. When I mentioned the reservoir filled with water, Duane lit up. "Oh-yeah! Olson went into the water & came up naked! His shorts were ripped off of him. He was like... "Oh-fuck!"...."
"My brother, Duane & Olson would vibe ... just to do it!"- Micke Alba
I skate with Salba often. Everyone knows this. He is a mentor in some ways. All that I know of pool riding, finding & draining, comes from him. He taught me the basics & I took the-- proverbial-- ball & ran with it. I talked with him numerous times about the Hester Series & his brother Micke. Sallie filled me in on the Hi-Roller contest & the days leading up to it. "The Hi-Roller pool was good. We went up there often, because Kryptonics was there in Boulder. Micke was really rad. He was super consistent. Back then, a rider had to stay on. If you fell, you left the door open. A skater could do three or four gnarly things, but if he fell, it wasn't considered as good as someone else who completed an entire run with some rad tricks thrown in." Salba remarked how fast skateboarding was changing at the time. This is a major point that other riders expressed. Skateboarding was evolving very rapidly. Salba pointed out a few facts regarding the Hester I & the Hester II. " In the Hester I of 1978, it was a contest consisting of street, banks & bowls. The differences between Hester I & Hester II were insane. Skateboarding was totally changing. There were guys riding in the Hester II that hadn't even rode in the series the year before. Guys from the Hester I were brought up skating streets, ditches, pools & pipes. The riders in the Hester II --- Grisham, Hirsch, etc.--were brought up in skateparks." I remembered living through the evolution of skateboarding at the time. It was changing rapidly. Salba told me that Brad Bowman had such a rad style. His frontside ollies were particularly awesome at Hi-Roller. Salba remembered some shenanigans. "Steve Olson had a rental car. We were all drinking beer & stuff. We started doing donuts with the rental car in the parking lot beside the park." I told him about Duane & Olson's memories & stories. Salba nodded & smiled. "It was a pretty rad time."
"Micke Alba wanted the overall title so badly..."- Henry Hester
I caught up with Micke & finally sat down with him. He had some fantastic memories of the Hester Series. He told me about how it was growing up in the Badlands with Steve as an older brother. " Duane, my brother & Olson were so gnarly. I was really young. They would vibe & heckle everyone. Intimidate. They did it just to do it. It was the way they were. I looked up to them so much. Back then, you had to stay on your board. I wanted to be the most consistent. My brother & the older guys would give me a hard time. It just made me focus --even more--to get better. Kryptonics was our sponsor at the time. They were located in Boulder & we went up there a week or so before. We got to ride it early. For its time, the pool was good. It was wide open with a good shallow end. I had learned backside airs & did them higher than most riders. I also learned inverts. I worked on consistency." Micke also emphasized what others had told me. Back then--in contests-- staying on your board was paramount. Micke continued. "I remember seeing Ray Bones Rodriquez & Steve Olson ride from the deep and into the shallow end. They did rock-n-roll boardslides in the shallow. I wanted to copy that. Before the contest, I worked on my deep to shallow skills. I also saw Kevin Reed do something really rad. Kevin Reed always wore shorts over his sweatpants when he skated. We always laughed at him. At the contest, he did the first 50-50 grind that I've ever seen. It was unreal. I really recall the contest being super rad! Many of the guys were ripping. Ray Bones, my brother, Olson, Chris Strople, Duane, Doug de Montmorency, Rick Blackhart. They all rode well. Bert Lamar was riding great too. I always had a rivalry with him. We were both really young."
 
Micke sat & rubbed his chin. He was sitting there lost in thought. I -- personally-- remembered some great Jim Goodrich images from that time. I wasn't at Hi-Roller... but I wish that I had been. Micke looked up at me. I shifted my pen to my other hand & asked- "How were the finals at Hi-Roller?" Micke shifted in his seat. He answered- " It really came down to Eddie Elguera & me in the finals. Eddie had the frontside invert & the Elguerial. Eddie would've won. He fell in the finals." Micke shook his shaggy head & shrugged. "I wasn't the best, but I was the most consistent. That is how I won the Hester Series that year."
"What are you doing in this contest?"- Micke Alba
Jack Lovell was the starting point on this entire continuum. He was an amateur rider in the Hester Series. If you look at the point standings that are included here, you will see his name. Jack Lovell is legit & I thank him for his contributions. He told me that he was riding at Hi-Roller the week before the contest. Steve, Micke, Ray Bones, Duane, Eddie & others were practicing. He took a few runs. Micke came up to him & asked, "What are you doing in this contest?!" It defied a polite response. Jack told me that he didn't feel like he should be there. "Those guys were so gnarly. They rode so well... It felt weird being in there with them." Jack Lovell admitted an interesting point. "At Hi-Roller, Craig Miller & I were some of the locals. We had the park wired. We were 'the guys'. Then, the Hester Series came too Boulder. Once the whole circus came to town, we realized-- all to quickly-- that we were not 'the shit'. These guys were our heroes... It was pretty crazy!"

item.title: the sentinel
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: It had stood there for many years. Night after night, the cold face of the moon grinned its pale white light down over him. It stood watch over his life & he stood watch over theirs. The concrete, brick & wood box below him had housed more than a few humans. Big, tall, black, white... many languages, many tears. He liked the tiny humans the best. Children. They were untainted & untrammelled. They laughed & hid behind him. He wished his face were lower to the ground so he could shade them better. The concrete pool sat nearby. In certain afternoon light, he saw his face reflected in the cool water. His own mirror. He thought he looked majestic. The children  splashed & screamed in delight. Happiness & laughter. He smiled deep inside himself. Sometimes at night, he heard them cry. The raised voices & the striking hands of the big ones. He stood over their life... a gaunt stoic presence. One day, the big trucks came. Activity. Bustling. Yelling. Boxes & trash... then silence. All life left & he remained. Birds cawed & fluttered among his green fronds. They sang in the early morning sun. Heat came. The long thirsty wait. He pulled water deeply into himself. He held it there, much in the same way the puny humans kept a grip on their pride. His way was healthier. It was of the earth. The sleepy seasons were long behind him. Noon burned bright. No breeze stirred. Then, the dark, smoke & pain came. Fire washed across the nearby grass fields. He saw it coming. Hot flames licked his trunk. Soot blocked out the life-giving sun. Pain & sleep followed. It was a long silent wait. Months. Finally, the sun --once more-- was a presence. It shone on a world gone wrong. He was torn & blackened. Fires had consumed the structure below. From his height, he saw it all. Devastation. Many other distant trees looked back at him. They shouldered the sky & shrugged. They had withstood the ages. The comings & goings of humanity meant little. They were & always would be. For many long hot months, time crawled slowly by. Then, they came. The new ones. They cleaned up the area. They were happy. The new ones drained the pool of its muck & debris. They rolled around in it. Happiness & laughter filled the air again. It rose up to him like the sweet smoke they took into their lungs. He smiled again. All life moved forward & he with it.

item.title: Bones Brigade - documentary update
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Last week, I talked with Lance Mountain. He was going to be taking his photograph archive up to Los Angeles to meet with Stacy Peralta & Craig Stecyk. They were shooting digital images of old photographs for use in the upcoming documentary. I contacted Stacy & he gave me the 'go ahead' to come along & write a brief account - " Sure. Whatever you want." I met up with Lance & we drove to LA. The freeways were a blur of metal under an iron sky. City life was fast-paced. Frenetic. Savage. Traffic was gnarly but it was okay. Stacy had pushed everything back a few hours. Lance downshifted & eased around a huge truck. The city skyline towered in the dirty distance. Graffiti was splattered everywhere. "I think we will stop over at Venice. Pat Ngoho is going to meet us there. Maybe we will cruise around & get some food." I nodded in agreement with the 'food' part of that comment. I wouldn't be skating Venice again... healthy or not. I am done with Venice for awhile! My collarbone ached, as we pulled into the parking lot nearby. Bennett Hirada, Eric Tuma, Pat Ngoho & Big Al Glasco were there. Lance rode around with them & a dorking session ensued. We were all cracking up. After a bit, Lance, Pat & myself ended up at a quick lunch spot. We talked about religion, politics & the debacle in the economy. It was very interesting. We were at varying levels of agreement through most of the conversation. One thing we all readily agreed upon: We love our country, yet fear our government. We said our 'Goodbyes" & headed to the studio. Stacy & Craig Stecyk met us there. Lance made several trips to the truck. He brought in huge boxes of photographs, magazines & albums. As I shook hands with everyone, I almost tripped over some boxes on the floor in the hallway. Mumbling my apologies, I glanced down & saw an image of Kirk Talbott. Closer inspection revealed several boxes of Stacy Peralta's Skateboarder magazine collection in pristine condition. My heart fluttered. "Oh my....!" I thumbed through the top few magazines. I saw Deanno Mueller, Micke Alba, Pineapple , Per Viking & Wally Inouye. "Good Grief!" Everywhere that my eyes roved, they were greeted with piles of old photographs, magazines, binders, newspaper clippings & old Powell Peralta memorabilia. Craig Stecyk & Stacy sat down with Lance.
